V7299V0Y2NOtk8Dyu7uaKw.text: For those who rate this spot anything under 5 stars does not know how to appreciate decent dim sum in a valley with not many Cantonese dim sum spots in it. I have been coming to Great Wall since I was a kid and it is something I would look forward to on a holiday or Sunday morning. Their hai gow and sui mai are pretty damn good when hot and fresh. You have to try going in the prime time of like 11am when they have all the carts out and rolling around. Although the wait may be an hour, it's worth the wait. If you go to early to beat the crowd you're only going to get a few variety of the different foods on the carts. I may be biased cause I have been coming here since I was born but everyone I have taken here have loved it!

tLHnfUr9tEb1i_H-0nrFdg.text: The food is 5 stars. The restaurant atmosphere is 3 and the service is 3. I love their green beans (sauteed in garlic, yum!), kung pao chicken, hong kong noodles (these are the best pan fried noodles I've ever had) orange chicken, and hot and sour soup. I've had a ton more things there, but those are the recurring favorites. Everything is super flavorful and fresh. It comes out pretty quickly too, which is great.   We always hit this place up when we have all of our family around, because it's great for groups. The one unappealing thing for me is the large fish tanks in the back -- they literally just stick their hands in there, grab fish, and cook em right away. At least you know it's fresh!

nbxBiMv1hG64sF5oNZL73Q.text: Amazing food! For the dim sum they come around with carts and you pick what you want. Loved it!

hktbZaQt-Id2tP1O78DbxA.text: Celebrating Chinese New Years of 2017, Gong Xi Fa Cai. Came here early at 10:15 am for lunch and this place was happening! I heard this place is one of the good dim sum in Phoenix.  We sat for couple hours enjoying every meal that they served us, oh boy it was good! Our table favorite were some sort of sauteed green collard in hoisin sauce, shrimp dumplings in clear rice flour wrap and bean curd dumplings. Our least favorite we're the sticky rice rolled sushi like with bean, it was mushy. The chicken wings were OK, but otherwise everything were good!  I wish they had the Chinese music during the new year to bring the festivities more fun.  This place doesn't take reservations, so if you are in large group is better to come 30 minutes earlier because there are lots of people waiting for the table.  I will definitely come back here again in the future.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Lots of delicious food for everyone.
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Enjoying the dim-sum on Chinese New Year!

tkxtyhHDxMBobafr2w-uPw.text: Hands down the best dim sum in Phoenix. The 3.5 stars doesn't reflect its authenticity. Growing up in Los Angeles, CA I can definitely say I am a veteran in eating dim sum and authentic Cantonese/ Hong Kong Chinese food. I took my mom and Grandma to this place when they visited from California and they said the same. This is the best one they have had in comparison to other places in Phoenix. On Sunday it's pretty packed so arrive early. We ordered Togo for dim sum that day and when we got home it was still good ! They really say  a lot  about the cooking skills of the chef.   We have also ordered dinner here plenty of times. Still good when we got home and the next day.   Our favorites for dim sum:  Xiao mai  Baked bbq pork bun  Dinner favs: Sweet and sour cod E fu mein  Roast duck

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

lznknkRRt-DRyQdl4o135Q.text: Great Wall is pretty much the only dim sum you will find in Phoenix and it's legit and as good as LA, 5 stars for PHX, 4 for overall in my life ha. I judge dim sum places by their bbq pork buns and shumais and both those items are really good here! They have all the standard dim sum dishes and their versions of the "specialty" items. We always order shumais, shrimp dumplings, shrimp rice rolls, bean curd rolled with pork, chicken feet, and sometimes a noodle dish off the regular menu. The shumais are some of the largest I've seen, EVER. Food is always good and never too salty. With any dim sum place, sometimes you have to wait for the cart you want to come around. Dim sum is also reasonably priced, table of 4 can reach food coma level of fullness for $45-50.   The restaurant itself isn't fancy and is in an old strip mall next to GCU. It gets PACKED on the weekends so definitely go earlier on Saturday and Sundays. (review is based on dim sum only, haven't come for dinner yet, although I hear good things)

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shumai
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shrimp rice roll

u66udvIHjYrpYFBmFDOuOQ.text: Solid, solid, solid Chinese! Period. If you are looking for authentic or close to--low and behold, the Great Wall!   If you don't believe me, come here on the Weekends between 10am and 12pm.  The sheer number of folks trying to find seats and the hustling and bustling from the staff would easily overwhelm your craving thoughts!  Dim Sum is the alternative to the usual brunch of waffles and hash browns.  Why have a sausage link when you can suck on chicken feet? Don't worry, not everything is that exotic.  Most items they carry are very feasible and safe.  Dinner is also another epic adventure in itself! The menu is very extensive and could take you a couple of hours to finally decide on something.  Or you can make it easier for your party by asking for the family menu that contains a set of items they recommend.  This route is typically cheaper and feed more if you have a large group.  If you are adventurous, ask for the family menu that is Chinese! Can't read, server can help translate.  Seafood is always fresh as they have live tanks in the restaurant.  Service is usually quick.  It always amazes me how fast I get my food sometimes!  I used to come here a lot for wedding receptions and other festivities.  Do not be surprised if you arrive and half the dining space is occupied.  I would come here over those buffets any day of the week.  I would recommend dining with a large group to not only help with the cost but be able to chow on more dishes.

MdDVy0FO-bXJDIl9U9DfqQ.text: In regards to dim sum... Food is good, but service is bad.  I give food 5 out of 5.   I give service 2 out of 5.  1 cart for hot foo, 1 cart for bakery type foods, 1 cart for soup, and 1 cart for other types of hot food...  those are the only carts that go around the whole time. Most of the time, certain dishes runs out before making it around... so people are left without food (if they are only there for certain dim sum). Once they run out of a dish, they typically don't make more after a certain hour even though they close dim sum at around 2:30pm.  FYI, if you go for dim sum on Sunday, you will be waiting to get in! It gets really busy. We waited 35 minutes this past weekend.

C53OSa7bD7sd4lSo1P3GCA.text: Thoroughly enjoyed the food and experience!  Very unassuming from the outside, in a strip mall, don't let that fool you!  Reminded me of San Francisco's Chinatown in the "good old days"!   Loved that they had the carts (that's a dying art form!), service was very good, staff friendly, always making sure we had "hot" tea and even was able to "order" one of my favorite dishes when I didn't see it on the cart, this was "low bac go" or turnip cakes, they came out fresh and hot, after 30 minutes, so tasty, worth the wait.  The "ha gao" and chicken feet were very delicious as were the rest of the dishes we had, too many to name, the sweet "don tat" and "jin doey" were a great way to end after all the savory dishes, 11 total and it was reasonably priced, such a pleasant surprise to find this restaurant in Phoenix as I was "craving" some good dim sum and this did not disappoint!  Definitely looking forward to coming back again!

_0p19M02dGfOX186MASiBA.text: Delicious! Dim Sum makes me so happy. I am here almost once a week. I love it. I only know of one other Dim Sum place and that's in Tempe but this location is awesome! Nice environment. Waiters are friendly. I love it here!

QlODNrdbxT2ZS6Fxv_cwug.text: I love this place a lot!! even though I have to come early to try to get the table. The first time I was here was the Chinese New Year weekend and we had to wait for an hour for the table. However the food were so good until we forgot how long we have to wait for table.  Since then I came early around 11am to my favorite dishes. Some times we got lots of plates on our table but we still wanted more. Enjoy the food so much and I could not believe that the price is quite good too (not break my bank).

spoPgtGJ4-yqiax8rDqpYA.text: So... this is what happens when you open the only Dim Sum restaurant in the dessert... utter chaos.  Dim sum normally has large quantities of selection of food constantly moving around the restaurant in carts. You see what you like, you pick it, you eat it. Portions are small so price is decent.  The quality of food here was terrible. But come on, you say, this is fracking Phoenix! What did you expect? Fine fine fine. I'll stomach cold dim sum that was suppose to be hot, chewy meat instead of tender, and bland instead of flavorful...  The place is a dump and the line is 40 minutes long. Well, it is the only dim sum place no?   The chaos though that is inside is what get's the place a 1 star. First off I don't even see how this place is setup for Dim Sum. The tables are arranged in a maze like formations where the carts can't even get to you.  Forget the fact that the carts can't reach you, most patrons got up and chased them down and brought back their own food. In the end we didn't even get most of what we wanted cuz they sold out. One of the employees shrugged his shoulders and told us next time to chase down we want to get instead of waiting.   Totally not worth the wait, especially since the food quality was terrible.

9ONCDm51GdXCyXPTBWKARQ.text: Very busy on the Weekends even as early as 10AM.  On Sunday,  I was alone and wanted Dim Sum but didn't want to sit by myself.   I called Great Wall and they said that they do offer "Dim Sum TO GO".   I wrote down my favorites to avoid a mix up.  Upon arrival,  I went directly to the Cashier to avoid the long line waiting for a Table.  The Cashier quickly wrote up my order and the wait was about 10 minutes.  The Order was 100% Accurate.  ***While waiting, I did pick up a Pink "Dim Sum TO GO" Order Form for future Dim Sum's TO GO.  They had them on the side of the Cashier Stand.***   My favorites include: Baked Custard Bun, Baked BBQ Bun, Roast Duck, Shrimp and Pork Dumplings & Shrimp Spring/Egg Roll.

e2g_03wQbKDI1TXbZQD7Xw.text: Glad to have finally found good dim sum in phoenix. Enjoyable. Great food. In a bland strip mall.

RbwDFskasjc_bkiZBu6ISg.text: I can't help but laugh at some of the reviews complaining about the decor and service.  Sigh...rookies.  Let me cut to the chase, you don't go to a Dim Sum restaurant for the service OR the decor.  You go for the FOOD.  That holds True for a whole lot of Chinese eateries really.  If you get great service or a clean, modern place, that's a bonus.  The more hole-in-the-wall, the better the food (none of that Panda Express Americanized junk).  I'd rather them save the money and keep the food prices normal than hike up the prices.  For those wondering, yes, I AM Chinese.  So on that note, I will have to say that while the dim sum was not the best I ever had, it was still pretty decent.  But that's not what impressed me - it was that they ACTUALLY had GOOD service.  That's what made me laugh even more at some of the reviews.  Try going to dim sum in LA, Houston or SF...  Here, ALL the staff was really helpful.  I mean ALL.  From the busboys, to the cart servers, to the head people.  You won't find that anywhere else.  Granted it's not top-notch service that you expect but compared to other dim sum places, this is actually pretty good.  I came with my aunts and uncle and they would ask for things like more tea, a specific item, hot mustard, etc. and either someone would quickly get it for us or the cart servers would leave their carts right in front of us and go in the back.  You can't find that at most normal dim sum places.    Oh my, and they even speak REALLY good English and so patient!  They even explain what they have instead of huffing and puffing and quickly opening and closing up lids expecting you to figure out what that dish is and if you want it.  They may not have the biggest selection of choices but if you can't tell, I was more impressed by the staff and that more than blew me away.  One cart lady even recognized my aunt and uncle from another dim sum place that they used to frequent but now closed.  That's pretty good.  I will def. be back.  Dim sum is like comfort food.

ao-RH7zVfwn40dApvtPeig.text: Been here since I was 10 years old, food is great but customer service is so poor, they are rude n most doesn't speak English, I don't like when they write my bills in Chinese, also on mother I went with my family of 10 I had reservations still didn't get my food til an hour later not only that service is horrible n they have the nerve to add $60 tip in my bill. I don't recommend this place at all. The only reason I go because my step mom doesn't like American food that's y I took her here.

nLb7leaS5ixy7NapAAji8A.text: The dim sum here is good except the soy sauce stomach. It's smells like the farm. Their food is savory and good. Service is not good. I would recommend this place for family dinner courses.

IPTsEiluda0CWTt2FPPtBQ.text: The food is good but the service is horrible horrible.  I really really don't like it when I'm still eating and the waiter or waitress keep on reaching their hands to get the empty dish from my table.  They couldn't wait for me to put them towards the end of the table.  I just get really irritated that people's hand are over my food.  How many dirty dishes have they touched?  They always take forever to bring out the tea and the drinks.  The food is good though they are kinda pricey.

wW5A2wMoHsboLdLyPdNzOQ.text: I still need to try the dim sum! But the Hong Kong Style Beef Noodles are so good. I love the potstickers and the house fried rice as well as the egg rolls! Everyone is so nice and everyone helps each other out!

cwxCXx6oIifARiLDWaRMhQ.text: I'll give it four stars for Phoenix dim sum. Price is reasonable. Most dishes were hot and fresh. There were a lot of people both before and after we arrived, which is a good sign. Go between here and Phoenix Palace, depending on which is more convenient for you.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Too hungry to snap photo before eating began

ruKDkpIZ4EeZEKhxAPRkpw.text: I frequently go here for lunch when in the valley. Their Chinese broccoli is just excellent and the service ok. Their rice rolls are quite flavorful and you can also order from the menu if someone doesn't want the dim sum. I've had much better dim sum in Hawaii and Hong Kong, but I'm happy to have this option while in Phoenix.

LLTBWXgOOcx8DZf7aS3N0Q.text: Took a long time for the food to come, customer service was ok, and there was a bug on the food but the waiter did not care

qZSRiNH6ezLHGGx8fEJtvg.text: Good food. Service is bad. I asked for a refill of water and never got that refill the entire time I was there. The waiter was rude when I ordered. I guess the only way to get your waiter's attention is if you are in a suit and look important or speak their language. Other than that you are invisible till its time to pay.

vXMKHJ3kLNdwYtWvNLj9YQ.text: Worst place I have been to ! I am really not sure why they have almost 4 stars. We went here because of the ratings. The food was greasy to the extent that I preferred wasting half of it when I had the option to pack it to go. I never waste food but this one was just too bad ! I guess this area in Arizona has no good restaurants hence the standard of food works for the local residents. We are from Seattle so used to great quality of food.

dOOFzUOCj97tZh0AF3uhcw.text: The girlfriend and I love getting dim sum here. Honestly, it's really busy on weekends unless you go early in the morning (right after they open), so I wouldn't even bother coming here then. The service is about 10 times better if you go with someone who speaks Mandarin, as we did one time. Sometimes you genuinely feel like you're being discriminated against if you're not Asian, but I think it's just the poor service. One time when we went during the summer, it was incredibly hot, and we all drank our waters incredibly quickly, and the service was so bad that servers never came by again to give us anymore. After a while, it feels like carts avoided us and we were not sure if we made sort of faux pas.  Just don't expect great service. The food is generally worth it though. If you've been to other dim sum, you'll know they don't have the most variety in the world, but hey, it's cheap delicious dim sum.

ebG2FD1JD7OV5QX3TH49Ng.text: Having toured Hong Kong and China are times and moving from New York this is the only place I have found in the Phoenix area that holds a candle to the authentic flavored you would get over seas. Must tries are the roast suckling pig, Peking duck, any of the dim sum is superb, and the noodle dishes are always fantastic. Also having live prawns, crabs and geoduck is a real treat I. The dessert

7LTS3iv1ZSTSA5y954GIdA.text: The food was terrible and was expensive bad service and excetera I will not go there again

N9LADEuUzmJV_pYE3mpwNQ.text: My very first dim sum in AZ ever, pretty darn good.  Probably will be returning back since the food is delicious but FYI it's a hole in a wall kinda deal so don't expect much for the ambiance.  Btw they only serve dim sum on the weekends all day long which is pretty nice.

1Hf8WllJiL6bErwejnXRYg.text: Amazing dim sum!!! The wait was about 40 minutes but totally worth it. I'm from LA and Dim Sum it's very popular there and available 24/7, going to the Great Wall has been a great experience that reminds me of the amazing Dim Sum in LA. Will definitely be back!!!!

0AXzWO2TpNfkECM87Uhu4A.text: been going here ever since I was a kid but despite the wait the food is always amazing!!

jaAVX9q09k7boB-amrYQdw.text: Good dim sum for Phoenix, not the best if you're used to a city with a greater Asian influence. The service was excellent - every person we interacted with spoke English (coming from the Bay Area this is very rare), empty plates were picked up quickly and the dim sum carts came around often. We arrived on a Sunday morning around 10am and we were seated within 5 minutes. However when we left 45 minutes later, there were several parties waiting to be seated. Parking is ample and located in a relatively large shopping center. Overall, good experience and we would come back for more!

VTohPmDCIZOtDFwd5hqE8A.text: My favorite spot for Dim Sum!  Beat the Sunday rush by arriving at 10am.  Otherwise, you'll have a potentially long wait depending on the size of your party.  Great for groups with a the lazy Susan available at tables seating large groups.  Otherwise, snag a booth or table and flag down various carts to suit your taste.   Favorites:  Sweet coconut buns, chow fun (pork, but also come with either shrimp or beef), gyoza, calamari, eggplant, sticky rice in banana leaf, egg custard, and gai lan (Chinese broccoli).   Wash it all down with some hot tea, pack up the leftovers and your set.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Aftermath! Dim Sum for breakfast.

a28Rc7RyfjqqO59tsl_2sg.text: I loveeeee Great Wall!! I've gone to the restaurant many times and it never fails to disappoint. They have a great selection of dim sum and their servers constantly return for more food. They definitely always satisfy when I want to get my dim sum fix. Wait time can be hit or miss depending on how many families decide to show up for their Sunday brunch. I showed up around noon this time and I waited around half hour, but the previous times I didn't wait at all. I definitely suggest people to show up early to avoid waiting to get seated. Overall, defff a great place for dim sum!

5LG8NSolk_wiOAJoJPxjDg.text: After all the hype of Great Wall being "the best" dim sum in AZ, I'm still not convinced. It's GOOD but definitely not the best. My husband and I love dim sum, we're regulars at C-Fu and Mekong, which in my opinion are both way better than Great Wall. After dining at Great Wall twice, I've concluded that it's just not worth the drive or wait time. Seriously. If you don't arrive as soon as they open be prepared to wait. The first time we waited for almost an hour, the second time we made sure to get there right as they opened and were sat immediately. However, we were placed in a corner booth where all the carts bypassed us which was very frustrating, especially with a hungry toddler.

f8lqk68918n06POKJmPuDg.text: Legit Chinese for the pros. Umami flavors that pack a wallop that will leave your tongue swoll up and barely usable for speech. Win!   When you walk in, the aromas are already piquing your palate.  We were the only non-Asians in the place. It's a sign that you're in the right spot.  Legit like China Doll on dim sum Sunday used to be.   When you get the menu, skip to the back page where the real food begins: -- shark fin soup -- salty fish fried rice -- clams with spicy basil -- Hong Kong style noodle dishes -- lobster or oysters or both! -- crispy fried intestines -- golden mushroom with spicy fried tofu -- the list goes on!  Don't let the cafeteria feel of the dining room put you off. You're here for the best goddam Chinese food you've had in a while!!  *** the best jasmine tea at $0.50 per person for unlimited pours *** clams with spicy basil. Epic.  Take it with a glass of plum wine for perfect balance.   * sticky white rice that goes perfectly with every dish. Save for last after your plate is full of sauce. Devour.   ***** golden mushroom with spicy fried tofu. Leaves you gasping for air as your tongue goes into overload with umami.  * delectable plateful of orange wedges to finish.   Wow. Just wow.  The neighborhood may be a bit ghetto west of 19rh avenue but this one is worth the trip. Don't miss!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chicken chow mein. Too bad about the chicken, but great flavors!!
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Spare ribs sizzle plate. I would love to try this one with proper beef.

kKC92dFFQD7h3tsKarVacg.text: My best friend and I love dim sum so much! We usually get there early so were able to get seats  on a Saturday morning! The food is delicious and not that expensive at all!  The waiters were very nice and were taking the plates when we were done with them and checking if we had drinks! Even though the place looks a bit off the food is good and the staff is very friendly!

Gr0PHdVlL0bvy2Ut1yipRA.text: Best place for dimsum in Phoenix ! Try to make it around 10 when you can get a table quickly . They have more dim sum variety during weekends.

xPP1iidNdvgvrSHLUO9r0A.text: Omg we asked them to limit the msg in our order but it ended up to be loaded with msg. After eating the food my throat felt like it was goin to close up. So beware

c2Tl9oaAZs1M3-9u6p374A.text: Old school Chinese dim sum. Best on west side of phoenix by far. Shrimp dumplings were the best, we had 6 servings...Everything else came out fast and tasty.

2fgYkdrDXM9wGAbAR_s2-w.text: Hands down the best dim sum you will find in AZ. As someone who is fluent in Cantonese and very familiar with Hong Kong cuisine, I can tell you that everything here is 100% authentic. If you aren't familiar with dim sum or don't speak Cantonese, bring a friend who does :) You may encounter a long wait time especially around holidays (ex: Mother's Day) or during the weekends.

1qqUtf6eGs0M1yTTwCtEfA.text: The dim sum on the weekend is great and reasonably priced. Go early because they get busy. My favorites are the shumai, the shrimp dumplings, and the chicken wings.

WW70azAdsbX5BzZ-KyboYg.text: Probably closer to a three, but dim sum is too scarce in the valley to star too harshly. Definitely not as good as Phoenix Palace, but still okay. We didn't get in until after 1:00pm, so selection was limited--no potstickers or Singapore noodles without ordering full size/price from menu. My favorite baked bbq buns were too bready, with almost no bbq paste and even less pork, and the sticky rice and steamed buns had a bit of an unpleasant aftertaste. Everything else was as expected but just overall underwhelming. Atmosphere and food just better across town.

QBFNmVV9kjyJwI6fz_fXEQ.text: So dishonest! Just went there today, what a disappointment! I just want to warn people about their dishonesty. Be real careful when they circle what you order because the lady that was pushing the dim sum cart kept circling on my order paper. I thought that was strange, so after she left, I checked my order paper, sure enough, she added a few more dishes than what we had ordered. She was very defensive when I pointed out to her. The supervisor came over and made us feel bad that we didn't catch it when it happened.  I told him that I shouldn't have to catch your employee being dishonest. I trusted them to be honest. I shouldn't have to pay for their dishonesty. I have never checked my order like this before but that lady was just too suspicious. I am reporting them to the BBB.

--2JNWfwcbPf_LMWQhTlvw.text: Food is really fresh and delicious and never salty which i find to be a problem at alot of Chinese food restaurants out here in AZ but not here tho. Dim sum is delicious and they pass by several times in case you decide to try something off their cart.

faWBUWGLgMrsl-pjtDK4Zg.text: With a hankering for Peking duck and those fluffy pancakes- the struggle is very much real here in PHX. Great Wall does a good job, but my roomie and I were fooled to think two small Asian girls could eat a plate of Peking Duck & an order of Hot & Sour Soup in one sitting. Nonetheless, the meal was good, crisp duck skin, good sauce but the soup was mediocre at most. Just remember, it's family style here.  If you come here, you should be for their Dim Sum! They get pretty crowded, but it's worth it. I always get the basics when it comes to Dim Sum so I get the Ha Cao, Siu Mai, BBQ Pork Buns, Soft Tofu dessert, shrimp noodle. I got the chinese broccoli to try last time, but the oyster sauce was way too salty- so pass on that one. Other than that there's not much to it, just point to something or ask for what it is. A word of advice, drink tons of tea! I must've drank a whole tea pot to myself while dining here.  Pretty good service, carts rotate quickly and are friendly. Love those old Asian women willing to have small conversation either about food on their cart or their business.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shrimp Noodle (Cheong Fun)
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Ha Cao, Shu Mai and BBQ Pork Buns are basics to order
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shrimp Cilantro Dumpling (Gow Choi), BBQ Pork Steamed Bun (Char Siu Bao), Shrimp Dumpling (Ha Cao), Pork Dumpling (Siu Mai)

zlnY-TyTIDb9znbHvQe-kw.text: Best authentic Chinese food in the Valley! Worth the drive to the Westside. Steamed talapia, stir fried oysters with ginger and green onion, seafood hot pot, fried tofu, snow pea leaves, fish maw soup, crab, salty fish fried rice, egg plant hot pot -all favorites! Dim sum is also good! Service and ambiance are also authentic Chinese...no nonsense, fast, and usually efficient!

Y0Bc2kMar9_DR3bZs8oJqw.text: I absolutely love the food here but it saddens me that I have to rate this place so low because of the service. Waitstaff is extremely rude and can care less about you. Forget about drink refills and expect to either die of thirst or choke on your food unless you flag them down and beg for a drink. They don't really speak English so ordering is virtually impossible. During dim-sum (11am-3pm) they push around steam carts with Chinese delicacies which are truly delicious but half of the time they are out of this or out of that and it's hard to get what you want unless you're there as soon as they swing their doors open at 11am. My table and I have also heard one waiter that did speak English complain about not being tipped and how cheap everyone is nowadays. We were like, wow! So basically if you're looking for AMAZING food but don't mind being treated like a dog then enjoy!

IacIygqHb1s-o7xChXBagw.text: Finally made it out to Great Wall for dim sum. I've been hearing so much about this place but I am hardly ever in this area so it was sitting in my "to try" list for quite some time. Walking in, I thought, this is gonna be legit. The place was packed to the rim with asian people waiting to get their dim sum on. The decor and vibe reminded me a lot of dim sum restaurants in LA's chinatown circa 1990's (ABC seafood to be exact).   We didn't have to wait long before we were seated. We tried their sui mai, shrimp rice noodle, deep fried shrimp and chives wrapped in bean curd, and honestly I forgot the rest because it was all nothing memorable and I usually have a great memory. The chives and shrimp bean curd roll was probably my favorite of the bunch but I'm a sucker for any dumpling, cake, roll with chives :) It was something I haven't seen at other dim sum restaurants before so I enjoyed that.  In summary, it was okay. It satisfied my dim sum craving but... would I come back? Probably not. I live in Chandler and I find my two go-to dim sum spots there (Phoenix Palace & China King) much tastier. && I only have to drive 5 minutes to get there. Actually, if I lived near Great Wall, I'd probably make the drive to Phoenix Palace. Yep.. I think it's that much better!

qNdFreiY-TxqsyxCJeXLLw.text: The lunch dim sum was greasy almost all pork and limited to one cart and a dessert cart.Service was slow and not very pleasant. I would never go back for the food. Spring rolls fried to a crisp belong in a bad fast food restaurant .

mb9Ppqjymn1b2g-vraniuw.text: Not the very best dim sum, but decent. We went around 10:00am on a weekend with a huge party and had no problem with being seated. The servers circulate fairly often and we were happy with the quality of the food. Nothing stood out as amazing (or not great) to me. I did miss my lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice, but maybe I just didn't see it?

E318u7hnKQHm449dlSRDRA.text: Best DimSum bar none! Seems all the negative comments are from Scottsdale snobs and whiney little spoiled people.

ReL5h8wv1qou4ZwkeFfSHQ.text: So so so disappointed!  Was so excited about dim sum since it is not common where I live.  I found them on yelp and drove the 20 minutes there.  Walked in and was told no dim sum.  Ok, disappointed but I was starving and was eager to get some authentic food.  I asked the waiter if the eggplant was good, of course he said it was.   It was not!  I struggled to eat enough of it to get full!  I almost stopped by a drive thru bc I was still hungry!  Service sucked as well. Not one person came to check on me or to ask if everything was ok.   I'm from the South and I grew up waiting tables at my family's Chinese restaurant.  I did not leave a tip, and I always tip, but I was so disgusted with my experience I could not wait to leave!

1g61zpUo5QW68aPK6tqPBw.text: Best advice I can give you about Great Wall is to BYOA.   Yep.  I said it. Bring your own Asian.   Thankfully our group of 10 had two. It was critical in navigating the ENORMOUS amounts of food and certainly critical in deciding which things the gringos could handle.  Thumbs up to postickers, egg rolls, chow mein noodles, shui mai and other various dumplings.   And a big phew for a tutorial on how to eat fresh shrimp. "Peel off the shell, suck out the brains and then eat the rest."  Yep.   This is where I swig down a cold Tsing Tao  And the chickens feet. Oh for the love. The freakin' chicken feet. "Just suck off the skin and throw the foot back on the plate."  Yep.  BYOA! I'm telling ya.  I had a BLAST. Carts were everywhere. Service was friendly and swift. Ten of us ate and ate and ate for $200 including tip. Oh. Also one of my Asian American diners informed me that the one man pushing the "porridge" cart only stops at the white people tables because the "porridge" is absolutely frightening to see. Sure enough. He stopped by our tables and scooted quickly by those tables full of Asians.   I love a place with a sense of humor.   Great food. Great fun. Great Wall.

xz5CZCWhUO--kVroDa-f_w.text: Hands down best Dim Sum in town.    Daily Dim Sum!!!  Super service, great value, terrific food.   Try the fried noodle chow mein, too.   Bao ( bbq pork bun) is the best!  Dessert coconut bun, even better.

Vna7Np3RMTO8qJ8UKH28GA.text: The dim sum is perfect. They have everything and they are very quick in getting to all tables. Great weekend brunch idea. From the pork buns, noodles, sesame balls, chicken feet, pork ribs, sticky rice, etc. it's all good!

xMfEMmC0kF6OqBRh3HL-Yg.text: Great Wall is all about seating. I have been there, gotten a great table and been visited by the dim sum carts promptly and frequently. I have also been seated at the large round tables on the front wall of the restaurant and watched for more than 30 minutes as dim sum carts paraded through the rest of the space and never once breezed by our table. And when you are finally starving to death and watching a party of 6 who literally just sat down start ordering off a cart, don't think you can walk over and try to carry anything away, because the servers will not have it. You will return to your table hungry and sad, wishing you had driven to Chandler for the cornucopia of dim sum carts that is Phoenix Palace Buffet.  The food is fine, the service is below average, but if you see them leading you to a front wall table, just run.

7fxaj6fj59-BkEfyo5PI5A.text: Well I'm afraid I cannot give a fair review. We arrived shortly after 8 PM and there were slim pickin's left on the buffet and they weren't in any hurry to put fresh food out. What little food I did try was OK. Will have to give it another shot at an earlier time I evening I guess. Very disappointed this time around.

BU1aoGSgxZUz0wvXXn6tDg.text: -Soooooper oily, straight inedible softshell crab -cold, dry roast pork -cold, soggy skin roast chicken -oily pan fried noodles -cold chinese broccoli  Saving graces were the rice noodle, which is hard to fuck up, the kongee, and the coconut bread  won't be back

qb23x1lAnuWp1JBKiPcjWQ.text: We came here on a Sunday morning on recommendation from the waitresses at Asian Hong Kong restaurant. This place was a ZOO!! I'm used to seeing big crowds outside of dim sum restaurants but this place was SO unorganized and chaotic. There were 4 of us and we agreed to share a big table with another group of 4 to cut down on the wait time. After being seated for over 20 minutes and not one waiter coming by to take our tea order, my mom had to chase on down near the back of the restaurant.  The tea was too strong but most of the food was good. The haw gow (steamed shrimp dumplings), spare ribs with black bean sauce, jook (rice porridge), nor mi gai (ti leaf wrapped rice with chicken), and taro crisps were all good. The disappoints came from the sweet sesame balls and don tot (egg custard tarts) which we had to chase down a waiter again to procure.  Overall, I'd say give this place a try but perhaps during the week to avoid this chaos.

RAWosEkSf_FxLSr6RQhn2g.text: I've been here twice.  Last time was three years ago, most recent was last week.  Both times it was excellent.  My favorites are the congee (with century egg!), the taro, the tripe, and the Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce.  Tea comes promptly, food is always hot and carts come around every minute or two.  Staff is nice--always cute old ladies.  How they manage this with the hundreds of people who show up on a Sunday is amazing.  There's always a line, but it moves quickly.  Much faster than a TSA line for a flight to China anyway.

RkMM4vk-vMeAkLbrcvSgbw.text: I rarely write reviews but this place deserves a review. I am Asian and I know Asian food. This place has Yummy authentic food. Went for dim sum and it was awesome. It comes close to home cooking. Best Chinese place I've been in AZ. Service was great. Very friendly and helpful staff. Downside, this place is so popular that there is a loooong line to get in. But I've been told that is only on the weekends. Weekdays are not like that. It's a must go to restaurant!!!! I highly recommend it!!!!

CghgtzIURb1K1WoeAtAnBg.text: My kids and I love coming here for Dim Sum. I was confused by some reviews saying the staff was rude and did not welcome white Americans. We have experienced the complete opposite! The staff was very friendly even considering the language barrier. My children are in a Mandarin Immersion program at school and love to come here to practice ordering food. The staff embrace these little American  children even though this is a Cantonese restaurant and switch to communicate with them every time. They were helpful with explaining the dishes that we were unfamiliar with and even recommending what we might like. We have been dining on dim sum for years but if you have never  experienced it, coming here is a good way to start this addicting adventure! You need to come early if you don't want to wait.

fKpefFnQ6TsBUSZyP4YAVg.text: The food is really really great, but HOLY CrAP it is crowded.  You have got to be ready to eat like a turtle:  stick your neck out a long way, snap a bite, retreat, repeat.  It is seriously tight in there because it is both social and delicious.  Just one time I'd like to go with enough space to have both arms free, hear some conversation, and taste every interesting thing that comes by on those glorious carts of food.   If you have a large party, and don't mind noise and extremely close quarters, this is an all out winner.

HJQ9IO6EQVF7GcB-EqzPXA.text: There is only one place in AZ where i'm a regular dim-sum-er and that's Great Wal!  Also- fun fact! 85% of Vietnamese weddings happen there (The other 15% didn't happen there because there was a wedding that is booked at Great Wall that day). So Great Wall is not only a Chinese restaurant but also an important part of the wedding culture in AZ.  Go Great Wall!!  Who knows...if I ever get married- it might just probably be at Great Wall.  Come to think of it, three of my older siblings' wedding was where?  GREAT WALL!!!!!!  I am getting a bit sentimental with this review.  So lets get to the food.  Shumai= BOMB!!! I can eat this all day and all night.  I just love Great Wall's dim sum.  The only place that beat out their dim sum is a place in San Francisco- that tells you how great Great Wall is.   They recently remodeled their bathroom - thank Confucius!  It is now nice and clean.  Hopefully stay nice and clean.   The only staff I love there is Jimmy, this tall man who speak both Chinese and Vietnamese.  He crack me up everytime!  I don't know him personally  but coming to this restaurant so much, he's like a Chinese brotha I never have.  The service there is mediocre- if you need something, call them out and you get what you want.  Not bad though- maybe I'm used to it.   Sunday dimsum line is looooooooooong, so come early to get your number.   I really don't have much complaints about this place except the occasionally long wait if I decide to grab dim sum on Sunday.   It is always a pleasure coming to this place.  Good food at inexpensive price.

VKeDN2-qs3SmL7zKloyQMg.text: There are bad eating joints, and then there are REALLY BAD eating joints, and then there is Great Wall Cuisine - it stands proudly at epitome of BAD eating joints, and if I know correctly, it would rule there for a long time.  Where do I start - hmmm.. let's begin from the beginning -- On 28th April 2013, me and wife had quite a hectic start to our day and we were really starving by 2pm or so when we searched for some Asian food joint and we stumbled upon this place. In fact we called the hotel to check whether they serve viet food as well - and the lady said "YES", and excited we drove to this place. Easy to find/locate on Camelback rd.  So we reached and were "unpleasantly" surprised with pungent smell of dead birds/animals. For first 40-60secs it seemed as if we have entered a poultry farm or s laughter house...  Yikes #*&#(!?? BUT as I mentioned we both were starving and were impressed by the ratings of this place, so we decided to sit through and have food.  Then came "unpleasant surprise" # 2... the waiter told us they don't serve viet. burrrrr... but we still persisted and decided to order simple mixed veggie food and hong-kong style noodle soup with tofu. the food looked horrible, smelled like shit and tasted like vomit. It was HORRIBLE... I just can't put it in words how horrible the food was... it was so bad that it would probably take me couple of months time to try Asian food again, if ever. It was a huge mistake to have persisted and continued, on the hindsight I think I should have left the premises the very moment I entered.  Well - the waiter and all were very respectful and spoke very fluent and good English, which was a little comforting. BUT then there was "unpleasant surprise" # 3 - the vacuum guy. This gentleman was hell bent to clean every nook and corner of the section where we were sittings with his back turned towards us which was supporting a backpack full or dirt/crap. He probably didnt realize that it smelled bad and even after couple of bad facial expressions from our side - he continued till the time we left.   I can't believe how is this place still running.  HORRIBLE FOOD, HORRIBLE SERVICE, HORRIBLE PLACE WITH HORRIBLE SMELL!!

eCakkfNAsXFExYDoShxNFw.text: Food taste great. Ordered at once please. If you try to order to go when you are done eating. Prepare to wait another half hour or more. Under staff but place is packed. Staff are friendly but the wait for getting a check or to go box. I suggest you help yourself and wait by the door. Dishes are delicious tho.

5G7MTWbgI8Ox02_aficrYA.text: I have been going to Great Wall for years!!! Back when I was still in high school (which was almost 10 years ago) yikes.   So here I am writing a review. The first few years of going to Great Wall, the service was...scary. But all good places have terrible service right? haha not the case! I believe part of it (at the time) was just a cultural difference and appropriate training on service.  Well here we are years later and they have made some major staff re arrangements. I see changes to the staff pushing the carts. They are definitely more engaging and interactive with customers. They offer suggestions and answer questions too. This is a major change to what it used to be back then.   The rest is still the same: clean, quick, spacious, big family settings, amazing food, mouthwatering food and did I mention delicious food?   This place gets packed so don't forget to arrive early. You can order to go as well/pick up. Sunday mid afternoon is definitely busy so plan accordingly. I'll be back whenever I visit family in Phoenix. Happy Dim Summing.

dcfpZ5L52jXsgD0z2sbcyQ.text: It was really good, just a little run down.  It did remind me of my time in China. Wasn't too busy when I went, but got plenty of food for an okay price.

49JzprgMJnQVp9TVD17XLw.text: My go to place for dimsum here in Phoenix. Probably the best compared to the other places. It's always fresh and there are many options to choose from. It can get very busy during the weekends because they offer the most options during this time. They have dimsum everyday until like 2 or 3 pm. If you come in before 11 there's no wait time.  Staff can be a bit more friendly but I don't really mind. The regular menu is also good if you're not feeling to do dimsum.

1gNcJTIICK5JIYmH4iTSOQ.text: This is literally one of the greatest culinary experience of our lives! Tip: Get there early on the weekends - as early as possible - and try as much as you can, even if you find you don't like it, the experience is completely worth it!

3NXKZ-C1cjRFTMVfibokKw.text: I'm still going to give this place a five star review because I have been recently to Los Angeles Dim Sum and Seattle dim sum ( harbor city ). My favorite has still been Great Wall! Their tripe soup is on point and our favorite that we have tried. The service is as great as it could be. Yes, you have to ask for water and chili sauce but that is most great dim sum cart places. You need to be assertive and not timid don't be afraid to ask questions etc. Go early on the weekends like an hour after they open... you get all of the fresh dim sum and beat the rush... If there are things you want and they don't have out yet be patient or ask someone ( we tend to get the most result out of tommy an older gentlemen that is on top of expediting). Great dim sum!

DNUTr75fR_iHmfmBn7s7Bg.text: This place is always busy which just shows how amazing the food is! Best dim sum I've had in Phoenix and always plenty of options! The fried taro is one of my favs along with the lotus rice!! My husband personally could eat 10 plates of the shrimp dumplings. Staff is always friendly and ready to help...

1onhfessI4Jf4AG0FmHEJQ.text: Not sure what the big, "ta do" is about this place. In my quest to find good Chinese Food everyone tells me to go here. I have gone several times and The staff is not friendly and the food is just not great. Also, the place is dingy and dirty.

wYnMtvcPvidqJy8wEo7KOg.text: They have great dim sum but the rest of the food I found was very salty. I only come for the dim sum or the hot and sour soup.

-BUBr00V57v0YWVDkJThNQ.text: My favorite Chinese restaurant in Phoenix, the food never disappoints and the kids like looking at the fish.  Really solid dim sum.  I just wish you could order sesame balls for dessert with dinner - only with dim sum. Otherwise, perfect.

IN1a9xQZOuRrLUPGPvAaTw.text: The best option for dim sum in Phoenix, plain and simple. Come on a weekend and you'll see why. It's not uncommon to have to wait for a table  but be patient because it's worth it.   On the weekends you'll get the full experience with the crowds, the rush, and the loud din of servers telling you what's on their cart for you to eat. Don't like what they have on their carts? Not a problem! You can order off the full menu if you'd like as well. You can choose anything from steaming hot dumplings or massive plates of chow fun. It's always in your best interest to go with a bunch of people so you can order a lot and share.   Servers are good, friendly, and efficient. This is the place to go if you're in a fix for dim sum.

8PCBXcFyARi9pi2l4ssEIA.text: Today was the best I've ever had it here today. Calamari was tender. Shrimp dumplings, bok choy was crunchy, great sauce. I love the hustle and bustle. The service was top notch today. They had everything on the carts today you could hope for. If youve necmver been, get there at 11. We were # 15, when we left, they were going on #60 with a wait.

fu2RNWqe5OdWt17tntHEBw.text: I have looked and looked for good quality dim sum in AZ and I think I've finally found it! It's comparable to dim sum in CA, but definitely not as fresh. I typically have very low expectations when eating Chinese food anywhere that isn't along the coast. I was very impressed with Great Wall!  When I walked in, I was surprised to feel like I was back in LA with my family. There are tables everywhere that can seat large parties. Along the back wall, you can look at live fish and sea creatures in holding tanks. There were people everywhere, and the food smelled delicious.  They have cart dim sum on the weekends. Be prepared to get there early, or wait to be seated. They have a reputation for a long wait, but it's worth it!! They have great radish cake and BBQ pork buns! I also liked their shrimp and pork shumai. The service is good. There are always carts out, and the staff is attentive. From now on, this will be my go-to place in Phoenix for dim sum!

SfKFQikEiV93CD9v-pGW8A.text: Very authentic and good dim sum. Plan on waiting for tables during the busy times, but worth the wait!

g9EdgliB9IUJs42QiVshLQ.text: Customer service is horrible. The employees  are rude! I asked for an extra bowl and the lady slam the bowl on my table like we were a bother to her.

5jMTv8lkpBaleZ3gt-G4lQ.text: This was one of the worst dim sum I've ever had. They have an organized system for seating people which is nice. The service was VERY good surprisingly for a dim sum place I'll give them that, but the food tasted stale. The shu mai and har gow were standard, I never complain about those. The BBQ pork bun I could tell was old and was served cold. We tried shrimp, pork, and beef noodle rolls but these were bad. I felt like nothing went together and the noodle rolls were bland/stale. They also do not have the Chinese donut noodle rolls which is my favorite dim sum item! The egg tarts had wayyyyy to much dough, the outside wasn't flaky at all and each bite broke apart, moist, as if they were soaked in water. The fried sesame balls were good though. The stir fried veggies were way too salty. We got banh bo aka steamed rice cake aka cow cake and it was COLD, legit just cold. We had to ask them to re-steam it.  What I didn't mind here was the sweet tofu, the stir fried noodles, cha siu, Har Gow (hard to mess up, and the beef tripe.   Will not be back.

Kzx2jp53mJFOFBj_1hhbJA.text: Cool Chinese joint in Phoenix. Can't really miss it. Plenty of parking outside and definitely seems like it can get busy real quick.  Walking inside, you will find a typical Chinese decor. It's very spacious with plenty of seating. Accommodate medium to large party as well. Service is pretty rapid with a host seating you and waiters at your table pretty quickly.  Now for the food, we ended up going with the dim sum menu. They have your typical shiu mai, ha Cao, shrimp rolls, tripes, fried crab balls, veggies. Everything tasted pretty authentic. And it was pretty flavorful.   Overall, this place was pretty typical of a Chinese restaurant, food was simple and good. Good variety of choose. They also had a standard a la carte menu too. Waiters are pretty friendly however we had this one that was actually super chatty and pushy that kept pushing us to order more and more, which almost made it a bit uncomfortable... but besides from that, I think that it is pretty decent and I would give this place a 3/5 stars for everything. If you've never been, it's not a bad start, if you have, well this can take away some of the cravings. Either way, good enough but nothing too special. Cheers!

uMZqvJEAj8qUPhXMjBnggw.text: We had so many wonderful items. Attended this establishment  for an awards banquet. Wow, we were all so impressed. The amount of food they were able to push out at quick speed and excellent  flavors. We had 7 courses all better then the first. The walnut chicken was my favorite.

blhM7Trskklddu3S3VX1nA.text: The best dim sum in the city! Weekends are crazy busy. I love love love their Shu Mai! I always pair it with the sauce that's in the kettle. The regular soy sauce and vinegar just won't do for me. The last few times we went,  the fried noodles from the humongous plate weren't available and we were pretty bummed. Good service is inconsistent here. Tip is added already for big parties.

Oxj85QAjJkjZWpKYk9EUig.text: Best Chinese food I've had in Phoenix so far.  I can't wait to go back this weekend for another Dim Sum fix!  I used to live in Honolulu's China town and this place is just as good!  What a find.  I'll be back twice a month fosho!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Awesome roast pork

wF9ZeC68SXnzVzToRi22Ew.text: Great Wall is good. The food is good especially if you know what you are receiving from the carts that pass by. I enjoyed it. For people complaining about the restaurant being crowded/loud it's typical of a Dim Sum restaurant. Especially since usually those attending the restaurant are doing so for family reunions or special occasions.

z0-C_L28dKLpTLI8f5ELIA.text: Lets face it...it was the yelp review's about Dim Sum that made me give this restaurant a try. It was not to distant far from my hotel, but not next door thats for sure. In any event, I had a taste bud for Dim Sum...so off I went...!!!  From the outside this restaurant does not give the appearance of something grand and unique, however upon entering, it is spacious, warm ...and empty...  Upon being seated and handed a menu, I asked for the Dim Sum menu...sorry, Dim Sum stops being served at 3:00pm....I almost walked out...I could have had Chinese food almost anywhere, but Dim Sum...thats hard to find and that was what I wanted. Okay, I'm here lets see what you have...  The menu was loaded with so many of the dishes that I truly like that it did become somewhat difficult to choose....but I managed...I ordered hot & sour soup (the bowl), chicken chop suey...and while I wasn't sure exactly what Salt and Spice Shrimp was, I was hoping it to be salt & pepper shrimp.  First out of the kitchen and onto my dinner table was the hot & sour soup...a huge steaming bowl. Let me say, I have had hot & sour soup all over this world and while it varies in taste and consistency, this soup tonight was outstanding...absolutely outstanding. Next out of the kitchen was this salt & spice shrimp...wow, these were not shrimp at all...these were gulf prawns...huge...took two hands to pickup. The shrimp came with the heads and tails, and shells...not a problem for me, but perhaps a bit squeamish to others. No issues, I hoisted up one shrimp and gave the head a slight twist pinched the tail and dropped it into my mouth. Oh my goodness...these were awesome. Perhaps the serving was a dozen shrimp, I didn't count them, but there was quite a few. Remarkable...!!! Last out of the kitchen was the chicken chop suey...let me say that this was not the actual name on the menu, that escapes me, but it was a chop suet. It was also fantastic. But to be honest, with the soup and the shrimp, there wasn't much room left for the chicken chop suey. I needed a "to go box" to bring the left overs back to the hotel.  So while i was not happy to miss the Dim Sum, and I hope to go back and enjoy that one day, I was not disappointed with the dinner that was chosen. Did I say earlier that the restaurant was "empty" when I arrived...well, it filled up while I was there...and I know why...the food selection is very large, and while I of course have not tried many of their offerings, what i did choose was absolutely outstanding...worthy of 5-stars for sure. So why only 4-stars from this review...I need to try your Dim Sum then lets talk.  This is a family owned restaurant...these are your friends and neighbors, give them a try. I plan to return...!!!

Delicious dim sum, noodles, the deep fried chicken wings with curry were incredible. Can't say enough about the friendly interactive staff, ready to explain all the menu items and make sure you had anything needed to leave full and happy.

QWjCR3Us1xOMhhwiR8sm1Q.text: Get here early because it's really really busy. Really good dim sum for cheapppp! I love the pastries. They clearly make the food there! Everything you would want in a dim sum place!

o6uyswCybyAbj-YbZ-13rw.text: WORST SERVICE EVER!!!!!   We got seated right away but no one came to take our drink order, we had to wave down a man who was not happy to do it, then we asked a lady who works there for sate chili oil and she responded "ask someone else"! Not like I even have high expectations for Asian restaurants but this was REALLY bad. Also, the restaurant was full but there were only 2 ladies pushing the carts of dim sum around.
