v-660papPWrqZOx2Qer51A.text: When you answer your phone you should probably answer hello "great wall cuisine" and you probably shouldn't advertise that you offer delivery when you don't.

IpQUpF-3zYJCAtglEtzCdw.text: The dim sum was okay. Not the best, but not the worst. I've had some really good dim sum before so perhaps I've just been spoiled. We ordered char siew bao, shu mai, har gow, egg tarts, and a few more others.

4_CDRxNZ5p6LpX_QxF3TWQ.text: I like how I came here for the lunch specials that end at 3:00 pm and they wouldn't let me order lunch specials at 2:30 pm. I kept telling him it wasn't 3:00 pm yet and they just ignored me and told me it ended at 3:00 pm. They must do not know how to tell time. They were out of their dim sum which I heard a lot about. Staff were rude to me and my family. Completely disrespectful and have no manners, can't even say you're welcome. Not once they came around to check how we were doing. Environment smelt pretty bad. Restrooms were a nasty mess. Food took over 30 minutes to come out and when it did they came all out at separate times, 20 minutes to be exact. One of their staff was picking her teeth with a toothpick and didn't wash her hands after serving food to another guest! How nasty! Food was overpriced for what the quality it had. I would never recommend this place to ANYONE! Please avoid this place. If I could give this place negative stars I would.

dDgtOgkca9Js6hKR9WXdig.text: So there is not much I can say here. Went here because I was told they had Dim Sum and I was in the mood.   So to start the place was about half full so maybe that's considered busy to them. We were immediately seated in a booth but that's where the service ended. The first food cart came by and the waitress or server pushing it was immediately demanding and pushy that we just pick and not look. Personally I was just waiting for someone to ask what I wanted to drink. So after making some selections I realize the food had hair on it so I showed her and she took at. The issue is she didn't adjust our ticket and I had to tell her. Instead of her removing it from the ticket she said she would find more food to replace it. My stomach was not feeling that I wanted more food but I let it go. So three more carts come by and we get food items. Each time I'm asking for sriracha  or sweet and sour sauce and each time they tell me to ask my waiter. Wish I knew who that was because no one has showed and I still haven't gotten a drink. Finally I grab someone running by and they bring us some water. Still no sauces. In fact one girl I grab has no clue what sriracha even is. Finally someone brings some hot sauce and some other sweet and sour.   At this point I get a work call on the cell so I walk out the door to take the call. Luckily my work date paid for the food and took it to go or I probably wouldn't have gone back in.  End of story, do not go to this place under any circumstance. Horrible service won't even let you get to the point if the food is any good. First and last visit in one.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Variety of food

yEFvNX8OMpptaCl0S7Q2rQ.text: The customer service here is complete garbage. I hate to sound like the middle aged mom who asks to speak to the manager but I couldn't deal with how horrible this place is. We waited 10 minutes just to be seated, take point that only 5 tables were being used out of 30 or 40 tables that they have. I would never come back here to be completely honest. No one bothered to ask us for drinks, we ordered egg rolls, and a type of bread. What we ordered was good, but the lack of respect was just too much for me and boyfriend so we just decided to leave. We paid, the cashier charged us for drinks when we told her no one served us anything. She turned her back while we were talking to her, I've never been this disrespected in my life. We will not be coming back, they need to work on their customer service, if I could give this place a zero I would, me and my boyfriend just laughed about it in the car after, but damn. If they could fix that issue than maybe I wouldn't talk so bad about this place but it's just horrible.

xbnAtLBYRdQNNxd8J-5HSA.text: Literally (3) minutes from my house! This is the TO GO place for DIM SUM - It gets pretty packed on weekends so get there early!   They have a huge selection of items... Everything nice warm & delicious! You can also order to go: I saw acouple of people picking up their orders.  The place itself needs a upgrade - the furniture seems old... The carpet (yes they have carpet all over) look super antique & not so clean

QLKlGBupOqcXsQqLKQRLSw.text: Went for Sunday Brunch of Dim Sum, great food, very fresh. Will return in the future. It is a bit of a wait but understandable considering its quality.  Tip: Less of a wait if you are willing to share a large table.

msEOQSkT9-qFJ3E0RuTekw.text: Worst place ever!!! Staff is so rude. We came at the restaurant last Sunday at 1:30 for 16 people food is limited and staff told us "we don't have anymore food, next time you guys come early" it's only 1:30, dimsum close at 3!! Dim sum cart should go around us but we have to call them just to get food and every one was so hungry! And even thought they close at 3, they should let us know and get our order of we want anything else.. Mekong is still the best place if you don't mind traveling far. Never will come back to this place! Also some of there food are TOO OILY.

CHU1rL0e6fso3JDreaqulA.text: I've gone to Great Wall for years. But the best thing that impressed me lately? Going there for Dim Sum at 12PM on a Sunday with a party of 8. We were seated INSTANTLY despite the huge line outside. Why? My family has serious connections! It's like the Asian mafia of food.   The Dim Sum dishes are good. Not too greasy. Baked Egg Custard Buns make me drool. Everything else is great too. They have a huge selection served in carts.  The dinner menu is very good too. Live seafood. Lots of servings. Family style.  If you come here, be sure to bring a big group. You will leave full and happy! As for the pricing, I can't comment on that. My Asian Mafioso mom usually fronts the bill.

cQ5T6dS2SXhBPN0eiMrBeQ.text: Well I went to try the wall and feel like I got hit with it. I did not go for the dim sum. Not a huge fan of dim sum. We went to have something on the regular menu. The restaurant is huge. It was busy the entire time we were there. Many of the patrons were Asian which in my opinion is always a very good sign when dinning in an oriental restaurant. The staff is friendly and very attentive. I think we had 5 different people serving us.   I went to try the walnut shrimp with mayonnaise. Some call it crystal shrimp others mayonnaise shrimp. One of my fellow yelpers had mentioned it was her favorite here. So I had to try it out. Well it was ok, the walnuts were odd almost praline. The shrimp seemed on the verge of being undercooked and a couple of the shrimp were not cleaned well. That just stopped me in my tracks and I couldn't finish. I guess I have been spoiled by my beloved Gina (Big Wong) her walnut shrimp with mayonnaise was incredible!   We also tried the fried rice and was not impressed here either it was very bland no flavor at all. They served a mountain of it but it just didn't have any taste to it. The egg rolls were crisp yet greasy, they were small and the inside was mush almost liquefied. My friend experienced the same problem with her dish under seasoned.   It was a little like dinning in an Asian old folk's home; you know no salt everything bland, edible just not appetizing. : ) I really wanted to like this place. I will not be back.

MXoXzfI3To0ThmopkydTtQ.text: This is as good as it gets for the Phoenix Valley, Brings authentic feel, with its service, design and especially food. Treat your self to Chinese food they way it should be prepared.    Menu is very large and has authentic dishes so bring a friend with knowledge.  By service I mean you feel like your at a Chinese restaurant the staff is not there to make you feel like fine dinning. I mean they don't speak a lot of English and are fast to serve but fast to vanish.    Sat and Sunday treat your self to dim sum. This is "a touch of heart" eating a very traditional Chinese style eating.  Dishes are brought out in small quantities of delight.

WkfQmX0Fl9crjq1JHb883w.text: Consider this a 3+ or a 4- for me.  Its in a very unappealing strip mall. Interior is sparse and ball-room / banquet hall like. Bathroom was very clean and nicely remodeled (Surprisingly nice).  Initial service was slow.  10 minutes before we spoke with anyone. We were certainly among only a handful of non-chinese speakers and some of the employees tended to avoid us because of the language problem.  Had only a few different Dim-Sum plates.  A few bun things that were ok (sparse filling).  A few egg rolls (Shrimp only and my dining partner doesn't like exoskeletal creatures).  Shumai were tasty.  Then for a change we ordered Veggie Fried Rice.   This was definitely a 4+ on the Yelp scale.    Would I go again?  yes, probably maybe. Best to go with a group of 4+ for more options.

sX5dSkglQ2Q8tqI3xKuMUw.text: I have since gone back with a crowd of friends for dim sum. It was very tasty and they weren't bothered in the least that all through out our meal we kept having more people show up.We started with one table and by the end, we were squeezed into three. The service was much better and friendlier this time around.

8P-lBI49oWHbqU40zz039w.text: I came here because a friend of mine recommended it.  It's old, grubby and kinda smelly.  I could probably overlook this, if there were any kind of service to be spoken of, but there wasn't.  Half an hour of waiting (and not another customer in sight) and I decided Panda Express or Pei Wei deserved and probably would appreciate my money more.  Even when they're busy, they don't ignore customers.

R-kKaK_aEcCCCDVVB24mbg.text: I'm disappointed to report that dinner last night was underwhelming. Maybe the time to go is for Dim Sum.  Pros: *a huge dining space            *a huge menu            *a good selection of vegetarian options            *Pepsi products, including Mt. Dew  Cons: *fish tanks with dead or dying seafood (isn't the point to keep     them alive?) I nearly squealed when I saw they had geoduck, which I have always wanted to try, but then was repulsed when I saw the glazed eyes of the red fish all around them in the same tank.             *too many servers for each customer. I think we had a different person bring us each item. Doesn't this add to the confusion when there is already a language barrier? There were several errors made (I was brought the wrong entree, they forgot our soup, etc.).  I know we'll try Great Wall again, and here's hoping that someday, some restaurant can replace our beloved Big Wong. Maybe Great Wall will grow on us...

HWbrC1eUbk70-pfvg9wHsA.text: My dad and I decided to try Great Wall because he had heard many reviews about the place and everyone insisted that you had to come try the Dim Sum.  Since I was in town visiting, it gave us the perfect excuse to go.  I'm happy to report that the experience was most excellent at Great Wall and that it lived up to the hype.  Upon getting there, we were given a number to wait as the restaurant was completely full, there were probably 150+ people there dining, however, we were seated within 15 minutes.  As soon as we  sat down, the carts started rolling by with various plates of items to try.  The pancake, shu mai, shrimp, duck, and sliced beef inside a wrapper are highly recommended, all were excellent.  I did have a bit of trouble taking the shrimp out of the steam container because their rice wrappers were sticking a bit, but that does happen.  I would advise that if you have an allergy to shrimp that you make sure to ask the server what is in some of the items because they do come with shrimp, including their egg rolls.  Since my dad has a shrimp allergy we did have to watch for that.  I did want to try their egg rolls but I would have been the only one eating them, and they were big enough to make a meal in itself.  The sliced duck was one of the best I have had at a restaurant, well cooked with crispy tasty skin, and not too many bones to get in the way, and very reasonably priced at $6.25 for a plate.  Most other Dim Sum plates are $2.25 or $3.15 so you can end up eating a lot for a very reasonable price.  If you love Dim Sum and are willing to wait a few minutes for a table, but you will get fast service afterward, this really is the place you want to go to.  There are still so many more dishes to try as well, but that will be for another trip.

1V8bTjNs9clXf9ZZMJJydQ.text: I decided to grab dim sum after I watched Bizarre on the food channel and Andrew was in China eating all these delicious Chinese dim sim. Typically, I go to Golden Buddha in the Chinese Cultural center, but I was recommended that Great Wall has better dim sum.   Please keep in mind that I admit, I went during the end of the rush (1:00pm) on a Sunday so I had appropriate expectations. However, there was only 2 carts going around trying to sell their leftovers from the rush and was really disappointed. We ordered the chicken feet, pork bun, hak-kwah, bok choy and it was just okay. In fact, I would have to say it was quite bland and the sauce on some of the dishes were salty and tasteless. The chicken feet I usually get is cut into pieces and not battered but the way they served it at the Great Wall, compromised my gag reflex. I am not one to be shy of eating different parts of animals, in fact ox tail is one of my favorite meat but my stomach could not handle their chicken feet.   I would assume we would have received better service and tastier food if we had gotten there a little earlier but I think I am going to stick with my usual place. Flagging the carts down continuously was a little more stressful than what I want when eating dim sum.

c1Sqfp3-Dv4lbdyoktVrlA.text: I think you have to be a Dim Sum lover to overlook the long wait and crowds at this place. But many people are! Went the other Sunday with a party of 10 and waited for about 45 minutes, The Chinese American Doctor who was our host actually visiting from Texas had enough and according to his words "used the old language persuasion" to get us seated asap! I am not such a fan of Dim Sum and this being only my second time was amazed at the speed in which the dishes started pouring out. I had this delicious shrimp and pork dumpling, sweet bean cakes etc and Chrysanthemum Tea! It was really wonderful and the veggies were so green and fresh--yumm, would certainly like to try it again if we get a very big party together.  Beware! It's in the ghetto and Chinese / Asian service and crowds might get to you if you are used to Western fare. The Chinese / American people love it though--there were tons.

DosdDya6eoUenTBvnCC_zA.text: Hello my fellow Arizonians.....  My review gets 3 stars but I really should give it 2... I am being generous.  I will start....as always, by saying I am the pickiest person I know and although food is a preference.... I know what I like!   We went on a Saturday around noon and it was packed!  There were several larger tables open but nothing to accomodate 2 people so being the outgoing person I am, I invited a couple people to join us so we could take a larger table.  What a great way to meet people, and they were great tablemates!  The food is good, I only have a couple CONS....  No low sodium soy sauce and most of the food is VERY salty!  The selection is not great, no calamari or bbq pork and several other items I enjoy.  The only dim sum restaurant I have experienced out here is C FU Gourmet,,, their selection is greater but their downfall is the food is usually cool to warm and the place has been steadily getting worse. (bummer) and the owner just doesnt seem to care.  If you enjoy Dim Sum...I reccomend you give it a shot and see what you think.  And until then.............  Bon Appetite'

0pA3F-ZtXPGzxXZhPdtXuQ.text: Dim Sum on a busy Saturday.  I have been to C-Fu, China King, MeKong Palace, and Phoenix Palace.  Unfortunately, this is my least favorite place.  The Dim Sum is not fresh (except the dumplings in the tin covers, and these were mediocre at best), and a lot of it was greasy (deep fried).  What a pity considering all the rave reviews on this site.  The eggplant with the shrimp on top was old.   We tried the deep fried soft shell crab, and this was greasy and salty, the deep fried egg rolls with shrimp; again greasy and cold.  Even the Chinese broccoli was old and over sauced.  There was one shinning dish:  the tripe was delicious.  Overall, much better food quality at other places.  I hated to say this as I really wanted to like this place, but it is what it is...very mediocre

DIUV-wsKghxpVXJalUsclQ.text: The fried crunchy fish was SO GOOD, along with the fried tofu w/ the soy sauce. I couldn't stop eating the fish no joke. It is just that good. I can't eat shell fish so this place would be perfect for lobster and crab lovers because it is one of their main dish! I usually come here for dim sum too! The ladies that push the cart are really attentive. The price is just right! I came here the day after thanksgiving with a party of 12? The bill came out to be less than 80 dollars during dim sum hours. MUST TRY THIS PLACE. However, the one thing I don't like is, they don't ever bring enough water for everyone at the table and that they don't give us the yummy saute oil spicy peppers. We always go up and get it ourselves.

0Um7jyAjSxbxUMeGASkwyg.text: I was fortunate to have a good friend take me to this little gem of a place last Sunday.  When we arrived around 12 the place was packed with a decently long wait.  This didn't realy bother me because it likely meant that the place was legit.  I never see a chinese restaurant with a wait.  Also large asian population of patrons which is also a good sign.  This was only the second time I had experienced dim sum.  It was an awesome experience and everything I had was soooo good, even though most of what I put into my mouth I had no idea what I was eating.  Didn't care.  This place is fantastic and I can't wait to come back and try more things or even their takeout menu.  Most authentic chinese food I've found in AZ thus far.

8D7iBUKBgt0EwG0olANc3A.text: Maybe it's a medical student thing, but I've been hearing about dim sum at Great Wall since shortly after I started school here in AZ.  This was my first experience with it and, after all I heard, I wasn't unimpressed.  When you show up somewhere on an off night and there's still a wait of around 20 minutes, you know that something delicious is inside.  From the moment my group and I were seated at one of the huge round tables inside, foodstuffs of all sorts kept appearing on our table.  I have almost no recollection of the various things my palate was treated to during the course of that meal, but I know I enjoyed pretty much everything on the carts that we pointed to and said "I'll try that".  So why only 3 stars?  The biggest reason was simply that I felt it wasn't worth what was paid for it.  There were 5 people at our table, True, but I still remember looking at the bill and wondering just how expensive each of those little tins were.  On top of that, nothing stood out as at all noteworthy.  Nothing was bad, but nothing was strikingly good either.  It was a big filling meal of better-than-generic asian cuisine.  Worth going to again, but I'm not running.

7drNg_VGgnxpK6KWwKz4OQ.text: I give Great Wall three stars because of the obnoxious service I tend to experience when I'm there. Some of the staff are super nice, some are are just plain rude. Otherwise, Great wall is about the only Vietnamese/Chinese restaurant that I could tolerate in Arizona. I'm an extremely picky eater and coming from San Diego, I must say that this restaurant didn't disappoint me. It's busy every time I'm there, what I like the most about it is the quality is consistent. The Dim Sum is mediocre, it seems as though they add too much MSG nowadays.   My favorite entrees so far,  - Shrimp fried rice - Roasted  duck - Orange Chicken - Walnut shrimp - Fried tofu

isdPDAVyLi40rPuT_7gPPg.text: I am by no means any expert on Dim Sum... in fact, my first experience was at Great Wall!  I enjoyed it so much, though, that I went back the next time I was in town.  They have a wide variety of dishes to choose from. And I must admit that it would be helpful to go with an experienced 'Dim-Sum-er' because some of the dishes can be intimidating! I don't eat any meat except fish, and they had plenty of delish options for me. The broccoli, noodle, tofu, and sesame balls are by far my favorites.  They can get really crowded, as both times I was there (Saturday and Sunday), they were packed. Plenty of parking in the lot, though. The inside is massive and nicely decorated. I never made a trip to the restroom, but I did hear that they are very nice too. :-P Each time I've been there, all 4 of usl left completely stuffed, and we each spent about $12 for the food we shared.

HsF_WrPRJL-q1zqyeR_Udw.text: Average chinese food, no comparison with NYC or SF. Was there for a nine course xmas party event. (70 [people)  Soup & fish were o.k., walnut shrimp was average, Roast duck & chicken were good. Service was adequate and place was clean.

B4WFS7NznOQ0EZJxDuETzQ.text: I've been to china town in california and in new york everyone. Great wall is still the best chinese that I've ever tasted!   I actually give 5 stars for the food. But minusing one star because of service.  Hey  but people who have usually been to china town or any authentic chinese restaurant should know that service is always going to be bad. They don't mean to be that way. That's just what they are used to. LOL   So just go for the food. It's worth it.  Oh and I will add, that the have the best dim sum in the valley.

uTTYTWCGRF_niDf8b6xG6g.text: Tried this place out for the first time. It reminded me of home back in New York City in flushing or Chinatown. The dim sum was pretty good. For two people I spend about $22 for roughly 6 dishes which is not bad at all. I would definitely go back.

wuDXUP7vHM4Qaz7VmNafiA.text: This gem on 35th Avenue and Camelback is one of the most traditional Chinese restaurants (American) that I've ever been and the food is super delicious. Five stars, hands down.

J1P_Ao7w7lTqVWhVY8ML7g.text: I hadn't been to the Great Wall in YEARS! My husband planned an outing for Dim Sum for my birthday. We've talked about doing this for some time but we finally planned ahead, had the time and found a restaurant that serves Dim Sum.    Before deciding where we should go he asked a student, who is Chinese, where his family preferred to eat Dim Sum. The recommendation was the Great Wall. It was a drive for us but so worth it!  Reading some of the reviews here, and having mentioned our impending outing to a friend who has frequented the Great Wall, I was a bit apprehensive, but I am adventurous by nature and willing to try it. If it didn't work out as hoped all we would lose is a bit of time and money.  If you're into a well-mannered, quiet dining experience this probably isn't the place for you.  If you don't mind a bit of noisy conversation, you're adventurous and willing to try just about anything once, you'll love the Great Wall.   Loads of carts come by with a variety of items. Some of them we knew what to expect and others we tried.  Again, you have to be a bit adventurous.  We asked one gentleman what he had in his cart (it had trays with lids). His English was a bit broken but we determined that he had tripe. Now I'm not a fan but I did try a piece. My husband, on the other hand, loved it. He ate almost the entire serving (quite a lot actually) by himself.   The pot stickers were enormous and so delicious. We tried noodles (pretty basic), great shrimp dumplings, noodles, wonderful yeast buns filled with almond paste, and too many other things to remember.  We were thrilled to see so many families (many of them Chinese) dining together.  Obviously this is a go-to location for family gatherings. Even though we went on one of the hottest days of the year, there was a line by the time we left around 12:30 pm.   One website about Dim Sum Etiquette recommends that you have a group of three or more so you can enjoy many different items. If we can find another three or four people who are willing to take a chance to try new things we'll be back soon! If not, we'll be sure to arrive early, with empty stomachs ready to eat!

6f2e8FpglhqkVLav4AKllw.text: This dim sum place was definitely different from the first place I tried here in Arizona.  I came here on Easter.  The area is definitely not nice compared to Scottsdale area.  They open so much earlier than here in Sacramento. I don't think there is enough lighting inside.  One of the workers told us to move faster.  Rude much?  Food was mediocre.  There's a long ass line though, not sure why.

3jyfsFLE4exDzWw00Kwoag.text: Pretty good dim sum. Good service. Good food. Gets really packed on the weekend.

xwJUDl32329vT2zntE_mBg.text: This must be a dim sum hot spot because we had to wait 20 minutes or more for a table.  I was weary after stepping in to this dingy place but the crowds of Asians reassured me that it must be ok. The carts were few and far between. I wasn't impressed. Maybe I was so hungry and crabby by the time we got seated.  Who knows?  Nothing stood out as great or horrible.  So, take your chances and try their dim sums.

xsuxmkNBZQl5qFBJXNZYnA.text: I was not a big fan of dim sum like my wife was. After dinning several times at the Great Wall I'm certainly a big fan now! The food is really consistently excellent and there is quite a extensive variety to chose from. It's really great fun selecting dim sum as the roving carts of cuisine are presented. We emphasize both selections we have had previously & one or two new ones each time we're there. The prices are quite moderate and it always seems like we get a nice bargain. We are definitely looking forward to our lunch (dinner really) tomorrow. Well done Great Wall! Oh, by the way, the beer is really cold too.

qGM8QTZWTS0yZwXQ0Tk9xg.text: I had an old review. I'm gonna update the dim sum section.  I met up with a friend for dim sum after 2 PM on Sunday. There were still enough selections to make us happy.  Chicken feet, shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, baked BBQ buns, Shrimp rice crepe, and egg tarts still tasted good.  The price was still reasonably ($2.19 for small now) by today's standard in major cities... $12 total each double occupancy. Usually it's $17 each double occupancy.

W9adC0q6O7zT7cQPDuuDdg.text: This place will always conjure up wonderful memories for me.  My family would always come here on the weekends for Dim Sum and we continue to come back even 20+ years later.  Some of my favorites here include the shu mai (pork dumplings), the sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf, and the shrimp wrapped in a long noodle.

ugEyr0YK7kZqZ_Cue6xVgQ.text: Quality has gone down hill, dim sum is not good as it used to.  Greasy and low quality.  too bad bc I used to love this place.  My family has been going here for at least 8 or 10 years now.

asGe-ZDZjmGibkthlnRPrw.text: Not quite as good as the dim sum you can find in the Bay Area, where I used to live, but probably the best in AZ, where the average customer has a limited palate.  Usually the majority of customers I see are Chinese, but there are enough non-Asians that you do not stick out.  The staff was always friendly but lately more talkative.   Some have limited English but we have enough familiarity with their Chinese accents we seldom have a problem.  There are a few more choices if you go on a weekday than the weekend, but the weekend is usually very crowded so if you don't like waiting outside for a table, arrive just before opening.

n8HnimBCuODvtbK5MwdwRg.text: i don't get it.  the first impression upon walking in is good: full of cantonese families, and it is a huge place that is completely full.  i expected big things with so many glowing reviews from  californians.  i don't even have  california standards.  i have midwest dim sum standards which is really low.  nothing is quite like i expect.  the tapioca wrapper that they use is not good.  too thick thereby ruining the har kow, fun guo, scallop dumplings, etc.  the pork rib is good but overpowered by sesame oil.  siu mai and sinh juk guen (fried/steamed bean curd wrapper filled with goodies) were fine but nothing spectacular.  the haam sui gok (fried glutinous rice filled with goodies) was the highlight as it was freshly fried and the filling was correct.  the variety is okay; hopefully they just ran out of some of the more common items we were looking for: egg tart, dofu fa, taro puff.  i don't get phoenix.  there are a ton of chinese people, chinese groceries are cheap and plentiful, lots of demand for chinese food.  why isn't it better here?  to be fair china king in chandler was decent when i went a year ago.

IGhcYCpLEm0giGW-UGNT5g.text: This is the real deal guys! My first visit here was on Easter Sunday for early dim sum. The place was already busy when we arrived at 10 a.m., but we were seated immediately. It's always a good sign to see a dim sum restaurant filled with Chinese customers happily munching away. The dim sum was really good and the service was fast and efficient. By the time we left, there was a line out the door waiting to be seated. TIP: Get here early (within 30 mins of opening) and you won't have to wait. This is definitely going to be one of our new favorite places for dim sum!

25jF6TadMm-dIInihr7D8A.text: Very tasty, authentic dim sum restaurant Kinda like tapas with small dishes Steam push carts are wheeled around the restaurant You point to what you like to have placed on ur table Bad, old decor. Was afraid to go ladies room but was clean. Even worse customer service, almost nonexistent  The steam push cart ladies were nice but no English or Chinese Apparantly some are other ethnicity If on budget, to feel full those little dishes add up.   Visited with family of 8 towards end of a busy wkend brunch  We are seriously easy to serve ppl We were constantly looking around the huge dining rm for service. We had to ask several times to different ppl for tea refills, condiments. So frustrating I was losing my temper on a nice brunch w family. . If you really dont mind, super bad service,  then the food is good.

VUtL6dvqwc_07gS1IFRARg.text: It was really good dim sum. The servers know enough english to help you decide on what items you want. It can get pretty expensive if your not careful.

_nNH_TCEgJFlXba9pDf2Fg.text: My husband and I have eaten at great dim sum restaurants in San Fran and even great chinese eateries around the country but Great Wall is definitely a place that should not be looked over in the greater Phoenix area. The place it ALWAYS jam packed for dim sum on the weekends so don't be surprised if you have to wait a while for a table, but well worth the wait for sure.   Last night we decided to try their regular menu and we were not at all disappointed! We actually have the dinner for 2: 1 egg roll and crab puff per person, wonton soup (a HUGE bowl with the best wontons i've ever had!), sweet and sour pork, chicken chow mein (again my husband and I both agreed this was the best chow mein we had ever eaten) and Fried Rice. It was BEYOND enough food for 2 people and was $9/person :) Everything that came out of the kitchen looked delicious...it won't be the last time with go there for dinner....though we LOVE the dim sum too:)

n6tmbnAUkayoE_4Ue0x9lQ.text: Ever since I started getting daily e-mails from my bureaucratic overlords reminding me of the impending layoffs, unpaid furloughs and "department consolidations" I have to look forward to, I've been cutting back on going out and actually enjoying myself. Mostly because they cut all my hours and I still need to find a way to pay my therapist.  So for the last week or so it's (haha, proper use of the apostrophe, bitches) been ramen noodles, rice, ramen noodles, peanut butter, and ramen noodles.   I've been trying to make the most of it. I look up ramen recipes on the internet. I make aesthetically pleasing bentos out of them. I even put pictures of my lunch on my livejournal, perhaps to maintain the illusion that I'm "challenging myself" rather than desperately clinging to the edge of poverty.  Alas, no how I try to psyche myself, there is no pick me up for the buzz kill one experiences when eating 15 cent noodles in front of your computer when your stomach and smug sense of culture are screaming for something...more...  Like dim sum. Like Great Wall's dim sum.  This morning I was stewing another batch of "failure food" when the insane craving for dim sum hit me like homosexual tendencies striking a fundamentalist preacher giving a sermon on how G*d hates Rastafarians.  On the outside, Great Wall looks like another two-bit strip mall attraction. You know, like all the stores next to it. But inside it's like the dining room of Hotel Awesome, where somewhat discontent-looking servers push around carts of delicious and deliver plates of FUCK YEAH to your table where you and your party can divvy them up/fight over them. Whatever fits your interpretation of Darwinism.  To be honest I'm surprised more people don't fight over the food.  For a mound of their delicious lo mein I would probably break a chair over someone's face.   For a plate of their pork buns I would falcon punch someone in front of their kids.  This may seem a little aggressive...but it can be a fucking battle royale in there.  Especially when you don't have anyone in your party who speaks the language.  "Uh, yes, I'll take some of that, no, that, yes the thing with the shrimp in it. Oh, and some of that, too. No. To the right. Yes. Oh shit, where'd our ticket go?"  I remember watching a Muppet Babies episode once where the children were eating gruel or something and they suggested trying to imagine it as something tastier.  I tried that. It's a lot harder than it looks.  You swirl those nickel-and-dime noodles around on your fork and you try to imagine crab puffs or plates of peppered shrimp or mango pudding.  You try to imagine being surrounded by all your friends, plus some people you've just met, plus a whole restaurant of people speaking in their cafeteria voices (i.e. screaming at the top of their lungs).  And then you open your eyes and take a bite.  And you realize that you're alone in front of your computer screen with a mouth full of chopstick because in your daydreaming you drop your ramen all over yourself.   Fuck.  I would crash a mini-motorcycle into someone's groin right now for a plate of their lumpia or shrimp dumplings.  Dammit.  Does anyone need someone to paint their nails and take them out shopping?   I can't keep living like this.

PUQnQ-au-QCgLpDIYZl25w.text: After having eaten at Golden Buddha, China King, C-Fu, and China Chan, I have to say that Great Wall is probably the best place to get dimsum in the Valley.   China Chan comes a close second with better har gau and egg tarts.  The Chinese New Year special dimsum - pig trotters with black moss - was delicious.  Apparently it's super labor intensive so is only offered for a limited time.  The shiu mai, steamed tripe and spare ribs were cooked and seasoned just right.  The taro puff had great taro flavor and tasty filling with only a hint of oil.  The har gau skin unfortunately fell apart and the egg tart crust was not as flaky as China Chan's.  Overall, the flavors were good, fresh and a nice variety to choose from.

xmT4Tei6HwRYMLfHlU1UWw.text: I didn't try the dim sum there but ordered from the regular menu.  Their roasted duck was fabulous, but everything else was just A-OK.  Will probably go there if I am close by, but won't make the drive all the way there just for the duck.

_GOZ881JAiQW0gwSMOIIZQ.text: I had a horrible time there. I have been to many Dim Sum and this place is horrible. On Sunday they opened at 9:00 o'clock, we got there around 1:00. None of the food were ready to be served. People were still vacuuming and cleaning the restaurant. When I am eating, I Don't want people to be mopping the floor and vacuuming near me because who knows what can get on my food. Also there was buckets of dirty water near us and near the bar. It was just disgusting to look at. The vacuum was super loud and all the employees were everywhere, not really doing anything productive, just standing around. They had about 4 dishes ready and in a very limited amount too. When we asked if there was more food, the lady said we had to go to the bar place and order...(what??). Last time I checked,  a Diem Sum is awesome and special because people roll a cart of food around and we get to pick. I guess I was mistaken. Also, the lady was very rude, I understand that she is trying to push out orders or whatever but being rude to your customers is not the way to go. We ordered the chicken feet and still didn't received around an hour later. When we did see the chicken feet, it was going out to the other tables that went in after us. We had to remind them that we ordered like an hour ago. They said "oh" and gave the chicken feet to us. We ordered a few thing to go and it didn't come out right. We ordered two part chicken feet, one came out AND the lady tipped a plate over at our table causing the sauce to spill all over. She was also very rude about it when we told her that there was only one part chicken. After we were finishing up our food (yes the to go's boxes came about an hour early), she came up and said "there's more chicken feet, want some?" In Vietnamese. Now if she was speaking English to us and she doesn't speak it fluently then we would understand but she speaks fluent Vietnamese. The way she was talking to us were like we were dogs. It was very frustrating. Additionally, our table wasn't the only table that was just sitting there with wondering eyes. 2-3 more tables before and after us were just sitting there waiting looking around trying to eat some air to push down their hunger. I walked out of that restaurant extremely unsatisfied and still hungry! (There was such a limit of items that we can eat that we just asked for our check). If I can give 0 star, I would.

BY5J4F-tOjd9ClO-Q28tRg.text: Ugh.. not worth the drive and definitely not worth your time.  You'll get nothing out of the ordinary with Great Wall Cuisine - a few dim sum carts with your standard fare, an outdated banquet hall, and subpar service.  But even that, I can deal with, because I live in PHX and there's like, two places that serves dim sum.  What I can't get with is charging TWENTY dollars for pea shoots.  Are you kidding me????  But I guess it's my fault for ordering off the menu, right?  My fault for assuming that there's no way they'd charge more than ten bucks for sauteed veggies at an old school Chinese restaurant in a deserted strip mall.  SILLY ME!!  I always knew my people were tricksy.  It was just a matter of time before I fell for one.

83NeaoFz4lMl5Pq7M4uSTQ.text: Used to be better. They've gone from okay to really meh. Went for dimsum one Saturday at 12:30pm and the restaurant was packed. After we were seated, we chose the fried squid, fried shrimp with sugar cane, and sticky rice from the dimsum cart. They were stone cold and hard. The manager's response was "it is dimsum; it goes around the room." It only told me that the turnover was not high on certain foods and yet they chose to prepare them anyway and serve them after they are past acceptable. I have had dimsum in other cities and have NEVER had cold food that was supposed to be hot, dimsum cart or not. Just to be fair, the siomai, gai lan and jellyfish were okay. They were tasty and were the acceptable temperature for food going around a large room in a cart. That's the one star you earned. The noodles? It would have been nice if you added a few vegetables aside from the onions.  As for the service, it was fine. Our server was a sweet older lady who was very helpful and attentive. That is the second and final star you are getting from me.  Sad. Where else do we go for dimsum in Arizona? I suppose I will wait until I am out of town where they have real dimsum fare as I will be hardpressed to return here.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. So cold and hard you&#39;ll definitely need to floss afterward.

ZiClrI77AooiwUbRaEMa4A.text: My mom introduced me to this place that she used to frequent during her work lunches. So delicious and authentic! Their dim sum is so good we could not get enough, ended up taking some boxes home.

7Y5xVt6-awEnUqOygZ8q4g.text: Every time I have come here for dim sum on the weekends they never have anything left. The cart takes forever to get to my table, I usually have to wait ten minutes. The cart people always look unhappy. I went today and they didn't even have shu mai and the shrimp dumplings which is the most popular. The server didn't even care, all he said was that they don't have anymore at all. If they don't have it anymore then why don't they make it?! It was only 1pm and dim sum ends at 3pm. I also asked for turnip cake and they said there's no more too. I came hungry and left hungry. Their BBQ pork buns were barely filled with any pork. What a disappointing experience. When I moved to the west side of Arizona, this was the only dim sum place nearby. If you live on the west side, I would highly recommend Phoenix palace instead located in Chandler even though it's further away. Their customer service and dim sum is far better in quality. I will never go to Great Wall again for dim sum.

gdXL3sPWEJJaD0TExsfU2Q.text: Since I came to phx this place has been my family's choice of dimsum but recently flavor have become a bit stale maybe because we might too much there now that the flavor seems to bit  "missing" something. The only thing we get now is the BBQ bun and even that one is fading. Maybe just our taste buds but pls try it out. They really had us for more than 4 yrs. Might need to stay away for awhile and then come back after few months.   :) still like there dimsum. A bit pricey but its the only dim sum I know near phx area.  Update: the flavor is degrading a bit. Their usual spicy pork chop just got erased from our to go. It's so salty now.   Also this came to my mind the pink slip. I think it would be nice if they put a English version of that paper that they come and check every time you order something. Wouldn't that be nice?

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Curry!
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yummy
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Don&#39;t know what it says but dimsum is sooo goood

X26ScZccTN0Mm-mgoUGt-w.text: If you want dim sum then this is place to go to. It is better to go in the morning when everything is fresh, and you don't have to wait for a table.

Rov5ygXWoy76YuC7pHn9xg.text: The dim sum is good. They have a lot of authentic food here compared to other restaurants. The service is not the best though. I always end up refilling my own water and getting my own hot mustard and chili oil. It seems like the employees aren't paying attention. Oh well just tip less

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yummy fish

mQtwi5VFuw03myJxHB99Gg.text: My last visit here can only be described as subpar.  We were seated quickly but the tables were way too crowded. We were a group of 6 but if we were 8 we wouldn't have been able to fit (even though there were 8 chairs) because we were right up to the next table. Pretty uncomfortable if you ask me.   Also it is so loud here it's hard to do anything except eat.   Food is jus pretty bad. It's typical dim sum but a lot of stuff is cold, greasy, and overlooked. If not that, it's just way overpriced.   If you want a nice ambience and good dim sum go to Mekong.

GWdrgagyb4XWXkw7T9p0mg.text: My favorites are the beef shumai, the bok choy, the coconut buns, the dry noodles, and the fried eggplant was pretty decent. We didnt see sesame buns at the time but a great server by the name of Johnson left and came back with fresh ones that were hot and delicious! We really appreciated that! He seemed to be the only one who spoke english and he def went above and beyond to make sure my friend and I got everything we needed. Thank you johnson! Your hard work doesn't go unnoticed.

mIAgz2oJBQq1oIajxD5sJw.text: we went here for dinner and i must say the food is good. i love their crispy noodles, hot and sour soup and their stir fried eggplant. customers are able to modify their order if they're not a fan of meat. the servers are nice and attentive as well. 3 star for the place looking outdated and run down. they also offer dim sum for lunch. over all, a good place to check out.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. crispy noodles with vegetables
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. hot and sour soup without pork
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. spicy eggplant

lKqToaTD2NMajIW6SfemZg.text: Not sure where my old, in depth review went to... I've been coming here for years, best dim sum on the west side. In fact as far as Phoenix goes, it doesn't get any better.    I'm so glad they reopened after their fire a few years ago, those were tough times, had to go all the way downtown to the chinese cultural center & then you have to brave parking, for dim sum that was merely comparable.  The staff aren't real friendly, many speak little english & aren't impressed with my feeble attempts at what chinese I recall, the owner/manager was more friendly years ago, I think she's kind of burnt out & doesn't seem to care, certainly not as enthusiastic a reception as in bygone years, but the food makes it definitely worth it. The dim sum offered isn't as extensive on the weekdays, but at least you can get an early lunch fix; after 1 the pickings slim, & at best only the main contenders. Weekends is where it's at, but there's always quite a wait, & if you want egg custard tarts for desert you best be there early.   Hot tip: you can order ahead & take-out - great when you have out of town guests HOWEVER always carefully check that you received everything you ordered & paid for before you leave, especially the bigger your order is, because there's no going back. Even after nearly a decade as a loyal customer, it's like oh well, so sorry, have a nice day, better luck next time. If you're lucky they'll tell you they ran out of something you ordered, & not charge you for it.

jhPE5qiLloYkfbkC4GZIbw.text: Dim sum - Excellent choice, fresh ingredients. Be adventurous, try the rice noodle - beef, pork, or shrimp. The coconut bun is stab-your-neighbor good. Good price as well. The staff is hit or miss, friendly one visit, rude the next. I do not always care about that, though, as long as the food is good. Menu - Noodles are great. House chow fun with gravy and e-fu noodle are great. Otherwise, go wild. Pick your favorite choice and then try everything around it for fun. (5 stars on good staff days. 3 stars on really bad staff days. Average is 4 stars)

u7TYSBMFQe7kRHqpvu2FEA.text: If you want traditional Chinese food, this is the place in Arizona to go! I love love their dim sum in the mornings.. and I always order the ice fish, bubble fish soup, salt pepper pork chops, and walnut shrimp at night!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Bubble fish soup
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Salt pepper pork chops
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Beef chow fun

3YRfWbKq99JT9TzDkaxcZw.text: I've been here probably about 5 times. Some of the occasions were for lunch, dinner, or for a wedding. Great Wall looks small outside, but when you walk in it is a pretty big restaurant. When I came here for a wedding it was very decorative and the menu if already set up for you. It was an Asian wedding and some of the food that came out for the guests included soup, seafood, fried rice, and dessert. Coming here for lunch is much different. It is not as busy as a wedding would be of course and mostly you see big groups there such as a family. Every entree is family style so we basically all just ordered and shared the food within our party. Food is always delicious and tasty there. I think I just barely come here because I live on the other side of town.   Now, for that Saturday we came here for dim sum. It was my first time here for dim sum, but I heard great things about Great Wall. As we drove into the parking lot it was already full. The wait was maybe about 20-30 minutes for us and looking inside it was pretty packed. So, I thought wow, maybe this place is all the hype. Once we got seated we got shumai (I think that's how you spell it). It's a pork dumpling. We also ordered chicken wings, shrimp dumplings, chow mein noodles, and chicken feet! I know a lot of people that may be unappealing, but the chicken feet was very good. I loved it!   Overall, I can always recommend this place because I basically enjoy the food they have here. I would say when I had the best tasting of  food was during the time I came here for a wedding. The next best is during the time they serve dim sum, but as stated above it does get busy so coming here early would be the best thing if you do not want to wait. Staff was good, but we did keep seeing the same person with the same cart of food like 5 times. It sucks that its a pretty far drive for me to get here or else I'd be over here all the time for dim sum. So, on that note I will definitely be back here again for dim sum and if you NEVER tried or experience it, mine as well get to Great Wall and try it!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chicken wings

T2iI9kNOv9miPakM_wSPJA.text: It's sad to see one of the great wonders of the world be demoted to serving Dim Sum on the weekends. I've got to admit, when they said you could see this thing from outer space, I really expected it to be a bit bigger. It looks a lot different than in Disney's Mulan, but I guess that's 'cause Disney likes to bend the truth sometimes.  I am Chinese, so I was excited to hear other Chinese people speaking in Mandarin at the restaurant. It put me in the mood to start speaking it myself. I soon found out that if you order in Chinese, you actually get exactly 0% off your bill. Many Bothans died to bring us this information.  Some of the individual entree dishes come with rice included. It always fascinated me how the culture that ate the most rice decided to use two sticks as utensils. Literally any other combination of staple food item and utensil would have been more appropriate.  Just thinking about all the salty, greasy, Chinese food is making my mouth feel dry and my stomach quiver in fear. That being said, I'll probably go this weekend because it's the best Chinese food around.  Cheerio!

MNBWOB5eaBOD39VOsOWJ4w.text: The outside of this place seems real sketchy. Actually the inside too.  But it's always packed on the weekends (with people waiting outside the door to get a table)!  So you know they must be doing something right.  Personally, it's not my favorite place for dim sum.  Their chinese broccoli was better than at other places, but some of their other dishes like shumai, sesame balls with fig filling, were not as good as I've had elsewhere.  Also, the inside is crammed!  Table are jam packed next to each other and I had to squeeeeeze in to get to my seat.  Yikes, you won't want to come here if you're claustrophobic and pretty sure the arrangement of their tables breaks some kind of fire code bc if I had wanted to get out of there fast, I couldn't have.  But, this place will still hit the spot if you're craving dim sum so I wish them the best and hope they stay in business so I can visit if I'm ever on that side of town again!  Note, we came at 10 am on a Saturday and there was no wait. but by 11 there was a long line!  so get there early.

uDpBtkZQ7s-Llqwwrr5ceA.text: Pros and con's as follows.  Pros:  overall variety of food is good. Shrimp sushi roll then deep fried-good Some funky sticky rice -too thick and sticky-,not good Shrimp noodles, good. A texture I'm not particularly fond of, but flavor good. Lo mein type noodles--good Duck-good, despite not a lot of meat Twice fried pork, really good. Chicken wings-really good ( not really Asian or Chinese but I really like crispy wings) Shrimp shumai really good Greens-i think they were some sort of asian broccoli.  My favorite things were the tea, sesame ball with sweet filling and shumai.  Con's,:  way too busy and crowded but there's nothing you can do about that. That's just the way dim sum is  I don't like getting passed up by anyone with the carts. Some don't speak any English so you don't know what they are offering and combine that with the din and the language barrier, it got a little frustrating.   Prices- no clue.  I love Asian food and rarely get anything good in the valley so this is quite good. I will go again

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Me

kzQLhuIXd6jpHlc1UBtyQg.text: Turning Cantonese, I think I'm turning Cantonese, I really think so...  Great experience with good food every time!

BpJ0Y26-5ma4KbCJFv5fUQ.text: The space is quite small with too many tables put right next to each other. I just wish that they can open up more space in between. About the food, I love every single food cart going around in dimsum time. However, chicken feet and beef tripe don't taste good to me. I like hot tofu, siumai, hacao, and stuffed eggplants. The dinner menu is also good, especially noodles entrees and Peking Duck with plain bun. Service is great and prompt.   I don't live in the area, but whenever I travel to this side of town - Great Wall is a good choice for my family and I. Of course, we will be back.

chXdFFdlsbBzeevOUA5sjw.text: This was the very first dim sum restaurant that my parents took me to as a young girl. Yes, this establishment has been here in Arizona for a long time. Although the food is good, the service is inconsistently. Be aware that you may have to chase one of the servers down to order your food if you want something beside the dim sum. You don't actually have one server, the servers help whoever they want. So, you must be aggressive and maybe even rude to get what you want. The dim sum carts take a long time coming around, because the restaurant is always busy, especially on Christmas day. The food, again, is good overall. Prices are very inexpensive, but it does add up. While waiting for the dim sum carts to come around, you should grab one of their paper menus and order something from there. They have lunch specials during 11 am-3 pm, which consists of the average and the usual rice dishes. I recommend trying their hot jasmine tea! So good!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dim sum menu
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Menu
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Menu

leii4DRkneYoH7eteKFX-Q.text: Food is great! My only complaint is that there is very limited vegetarian options. I got rice noodles with green onion and bean sprouts and sesame balls. They were both delicious! For dessert, we got egg custard buns and coconut buns. These were out of this world, delicious! Highly recommend putting the diet on hold for these!   It was somewhat difficult to communicate with the staff members and get clear information about what we were offered. However, this just adds to the authenticity of the place!   I would definitely return!

OfUtQ5Oydgicj6oJZWgUyA.text: I'd heard the reviews for this place from those who would know -- a Chinese  (auntie) told me she felt this place was a little unsanitary and much preferred the dim sum at Mekong plaza. I was hoping she might have just been biased, but unfortunately I had to agree. While I didn't notice anything dirty (though the place wasn't exactly spotless), I felt the same about Mekong.  The wait here was quite long, though most dim sum places are like that. We started out with the  (crispy roast duck) and BBQ pork. I looove roast duck but sadly was incredibly disappointed with this. It was cold from sitting in the cart (as was the pork), far from crispy, and bland to top it off. Inexcusable for the price of the duck. They were so unappetizing that we didn't even finish them, though I was able to salvage them later for some leftover fried rice when meal prepping for the week.  The  (sticky rice in banana leaves with meat filling) was alright but tasted a bit off, and the shumai was decent.  The staff was nice enough, and the prices weren't outrageous, but the food is definitely not worth coming for. While I'm not aware of any dim sum places in Phoenix worth raving over (please let me know if you find one), I would stick to Mekong to satisfy your dim sum cravings.

DCctuf62QOoD5TGajV4LiQ.text: One of the most traditional and authentic dim sum restaurants I've ever been to! The staff are super friendly and helpful and always have lots of options on their carts! Some of my favorites include the shumai, beef noodles, and soy sauce/golden noodles. Just discovered a new dumpling the last time I was there, but am not sure of the name (picture below). Overall, this place is two thumbs up!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dumpling

RUBzvGPjzoHkF_nQ8jgNMQ.text: Hands down the best dim sum restaurant in the Phoenix area. The best time to go is around 10 when all the food items are being made, but there can be quite the wait for a table. If you're a first timer at dim sum, try to go with a large group so you can sample the most items! Some of my favorites include the egg tarts, shu mai, and the footballs

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Turnip cake
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Egg tart

2qg7D3kVmXdtYMXmxuJuow.text: The food was good. Came here during a weekday. The first time there was only a few carts. The second time I went earlier and there was more choices. The restroom wasn't so clean.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

vUtd_RDlT-M5z7Zlx6WO1w.text: I finally had a chance to check this place out. I came here to have lunch with my bf, it was around 3pm. When we got there, the waitress told us we can't get Dim Sum because it was already past their dim sum time. I was so sad because I want the  (sticky rice filled with meat), and the waitress was so nice! She said she will ask the person in the kitchen if they still have it and she actually got it for me!!!   I ordered Chicken Egg Fo Young and my bf ordered Beef Cho Fun, it was huge! I couldn't finish it, my bf couldn't finish his either, lol... And I took the rest of it home for dinner!  Their egg rolls were delicious, specially with the sweet chilli sauce they served with them. Now I'm hungry!  The price is not bad at all for that big portion! I will definitely come back and try their Dim Sum!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chicken Egg Fo Young

YlTbl1erM8n8qztODhBjSw.text: Food is really good. I love their Dimsums, legit taste. It is True that they used to have bad service, but it has greatly improved and the staff are trying their best to improve that aspect. Will definitely eat here again.

CI7yFL3WuTTGEIxAwvX7jg.text: We went to this place on a Wednesday for dinner. There were three tables sat and four servers/staff. It took them 10 minutes to seat us, then another 20 minutes waiting for a server to come over while two of them stood talking 20 feet away for us to give up and go to Abacus Inn. Worst service ever.

CJ-J5tBDx0VXpplI7zmJWw.text: Had their dim sum last week.  It was crowded  at 11.15 but the wait was only about v20 minutes.  Food came quickly  and was very fresh . Plenty of selections  . Char sui bow was great . Hargow had plenty of shrimp. Loved the turnip cakes . Dan tart was nice and crunchy.  In 30 minutes we were able to eat all the items that we wanted. Price is about  40 % cheaper than  California.

-trflkKcMafR3XHQiilLvg.text: They should rename this place "The Great Wait". We overheard a recommendation for this place, that the food was amazing. The food is not bad. But not amazing.  And I'm pretty sure they bicycle to the Great Wall to go and get it. Dim sum was good, but the carts were few and far between - to the point where customers were getting up and pouncing in them as soon as they came out of the kitchen. We also ordered the salt and pepper squid (their marquee dish). Not bad. Super salty and super garlicy. Good food. SLOW service.

f24P2X7V99-TXuxVncEq6A.text: Love this place. They are always busy but it goes fast. Consistent food and great service. They have so many options it's hard not to want tit all. They have a full bar and the drinks are strong.

_UreKhdtEcAJ9KSkcFwpXw.text: We love this place, but we have been very disappointed the past couple of visits. We got there at 11:30 and it was packed. We were able to be seated, but were seated on the stage.  This is a horrible area to sit in since it's so hard to flag the carts down. They tend to past you if you're on the stage so if you can avoid it, do so. The variety of dim sum at 11:30 was disappointing.  There were the shu mai, noodles, a few other carts that came around, but that was it. Nothing was coming out of the kitchen until around 12:15 or so  and again, by the time the carts reach you if you're sitting by the stage, they either will skip you or they would run out of selections.  I'm hoping that they know on the weekends that a lot of folks come at 11 and that they have food ready for the crowd.

PgYRMK46e7Uy1JdZkzlIWA.text: A go to place for a dim sum in the valley, especially on Saturdays and Sundays where they serve more variety of dim sum. Get here early as it tends to have quite a long wait for a table. Our favorites are: shumai, hakao, shrimp noodles, kailan with oyster sauce, roasted duck, jelly fish, Chinese egg custard, house fried rice, and custard-filled buns. Aside from choosing from carts pushed around by servers, you can also order off of their menu. Great and quick service.

MXEU0iyK01ShfRU_yf9Usg.text: Came here for dim sum. Turns out it's only served during lunch time. At least 5 tables that ordered after us got their food 30 minutes before us (we were a party of 2). The food was mediocre at best. Should have just gone to PF Chang's. Would have paid the same price for much better food. They will never see us again.

jCig6-gjuyqjH3HDUqNlhA.text: An old time favorite establishment that has outlived many authentic chinese restaurants over the past  30 plus years. The interior has shown its age but overlooked by its consistently good comfort food. This has been and still,  a very popular choice for chinese lunch/ dinner banquets (parties).  They serve traditional  dim sum and are usually packed the weekends. And as always, their cantonese entrees put a big smile on my face and never disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Steamed ginger and onions chicken.

_kT4cmByHB7C8o7fCOU3Ww.text: This restaurant is paramount to the Asian community of Arizona. I've been going here since I was a child and their dim sum and dinner options are great. There are times the service can be spotty, but for the most part the service is great. Food is spot on! The walnut shrimp, pecking duck, and lobster are my favorites! I would rate this place the best Chinese restaurant in Arizona. Staff is always the same familiar faces and they are really friendly. They also host tons of wedding receptions here!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Salt and pepper crab and walnut shrimp
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Walnut shrimp and stir fried noodles (mi xao)
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Ginger scallion lobster

9yqwmyqQEzzbWrWwsaDSCQ.text: This establishment is surprisingly large, so great for groups. The food is great, HUGE fried rice portions and very reasonably priced. Friendly staff, parking outside.

qah8vbAkJkZ76IUuskf_oQ.text: This was my first dim sum experience and it was a lot to take in. I'm glad I went with a friend who is familiar with dim sum as she was able to make recommendations for which items to grab and which ones to skip.   Basically, the staff circles around the restaurant with carts loaded up with food. They stop by at each table and you tell them what you want and they'll mark a card to keep track of what you're ordering. These carts of food are coming around pretty much non-stop so don't get over zealous and grab things as they come to you.   We had a variety of things (sorry I don't know their names) including duck, dumplings, noodles, and several of their sweeter plates. Everything was flavorful and warm as it got to our table. This is definitely a place to check out!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. A gorgeous spread of yummy dim sum foods!

aCPlYBeZlo0ukjPPlsDyHQ.text: This place has really big portions! The crispy noodles are so good! My whole family came and everyone enjoyed their food.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chicken crispy noodles

bOgZNG5YfhNHHC-xl6v7FQ.text: Dim sum and then some!  I absolutely love this place! Every time I'm craving dim sum and especially Cheung Fun! *rolled rice noodles* this is where I go!  The carts are hot and moving quickly with all your favorites, and some soon to be favorites you must try!  This is forsure my go to dim sum spot in the valley!

RRsHLvFxsZ7DcmHO4vek4w.text: This place is great! It's the closet place to me for dim sum that acutally tastes good!

tpR2mmXJFL2gFsR1s7ErQA.text: i tried china chan, golden buddha in phoenix , china king, phoenix palace in chandler, mekong palace dimsum in mesa  but this is the best so far among the other dimsum places here in az.. on sundays its always pack with customers. the dimsum in chicago's china town is still better than here in az

Egmkij9_WO_nusl0sMfyMQ.text: We went there around 1pm and got seated almost 2pm [Sunday]. It was worth the wait! The dimsums are really worth waiting for. Hakaw, Pork Siomai, Bean cured rolls are our favorites!

z_ZzFynYy6O52fptr4psBA.text: Leaving hungry.   Waited 45 min and barely saw any cart come around. We used to love coming here, but last few times it seems to have gone down hill. Less selection, most food are cold by the time it gets to the table. Today was worst. Very rude attendant and no food available makes very unhappy customer.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Coconut bun and sesame ball

eVMw_nPCjBsHtd8ziC2G1w.text: I miss this place! Whenever I'm back in the Phoenix/ Tolleson area I'm making certain to visit. The food is the best by far unless you leave the country.

HsMTZWI4uOq66NC2jWvIjQ.text: It's a great whole in the wall that has tasty dim sum. The only thing I missed was the egg custard tart. That is my most favorite dessert. I think when we got there they may have been restocking the carts. It was busy so I get it. I wanted dim sum for a while so I finally got sum. Lol

RD6_U4ciNOp8Ye_SYweKLA.text: Meh.  Christmas Eve.  Mediocre food.  Horrendous service.  We had to repeatedly ask the waiter where our food was.  From the the first course to the last course was more than an hour, and only after we repeatedly begged the waiter for food. We asked no less than four times about missing courses.  Likely our last visit.

vRiUJhv41eOo5u0FzxUd-Q.text: Not a huge Chinese food fan, but I do like Dim Sum. Finally made it over to this spot because was in the mood for buns and pork belly. Ordered for take out shrimp shiu mai from the Dim Sum menu, they come eight in a container for $2.75, they were delicious. Also the steamed chicken buns, just a dollop of chicken mixture surrounded by a slight sweet dough. Pork belly was soft from the great broth mixed with veggies. Another place that's a keeper.

G5OdbCU79PEcyj7_uTSsgw.text: DIM SUM TIME AND SELECTION ARE POOR ON THE WEEKDAYS. I was told "Dim Sum best to arrive before 2pm". I took them literally and arrived by 1pm a couple times and received poor (read: non-existent) selections. By the time I was seated today I got only got two carts (not counting the tofu cart) with four selections. The food quality is very good but the service is inconsistent/terrible  - you will have to work very hard to get a server's attention (don't bother with the cart ladies) and twice my orders were wrong. Only come here if a) you are very early) b) you have plenty of time c)you have no other choice. Probably good for groups but I wouldn't know as I came here alone. I really, really wanted to like this place but I've tried multiple visits and felt snubbed every time. I won't be back as there are other, better options available go to the place at Mekong Market or Happy Palace.

6lG5zeUl1wu1XXS6aC0lCQ.text: Love coming here for dim sum on the weekends -- red bean cakes, pork and noodle roll, the fried squid with chili's and the stewed tripe are the highlights for us. Would recommend, just hate the wait :p

407qA1aXHXejqfuKK6TwyQ.text: The best Dim Sum in Phoenix. The food is 5 star. I heard Saturday and Sunday Dim Sum are extremely crowded.  Went there a few times,  all in their busy hours. The services are fairly good, sometimes you can not just wait, need to go ask some food from the Dim Sum cart, which is understandable since they are so busy. Not sure how many years it has been there, the food taste has not changed, which is really a good sign comparing to some "fancy" Chinese restaurants that disappeared in few years.  The atmosphere is very traditional like, noisy and crowded, feels like you are in Hong Kong or Guangdong,  a good place for homesick people in the desert.

scR-Bpl9iq-DSUMxwdupkw.text: DIM SUM. Love the dumplings. Love the cart service makes for a unique dining experience. Lunch is a great deal. Cant wait to try the dinner menu.

7d0giJxSXlGt1AlQDfxZfw.text: Some of the best dimsum around. I have been stopping here for nearly ten years off and on!  The same people working here as ten years ago. It's crowded everytime I come with a great diversity of clients.   A must stop if you love authentic dimsum. I would recommend this place to my family and friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

2soMzZN-uiNvmGIA2Wb9hA.text: For those who have eaten Dim Sum in other places like San Francisco will be greatly disappointed in the fare of this restaurant. There was less variety; far less quality to the offering and even extracting the food from the containers was as if the food was welded to the bottom. The servers were not well versed in what they were serving. The pork boughs were more bread than filling and getting the paper off the bottom was most difficult. A great disappointment and not worth the time it took to this get to this restaurant.

Sh6zchHt7Fy7R-wU50xjZA.text: Went here with friends for lunch.   The cracklings rice soup is fun and yum to eat.  The other dishes are classic so come over for whatever Chinese food cravings you have.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Crackling rice soup.
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Beef and vegetables and Crispy pork over veggies
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Buddhas feast

0UN4EMkBTihOxSMW4O1Cpg.text: Mediocre at best. Previous reviewers must have been confused that they were somewhere good.    Hong Kong noodle soup with duck was a decently cooked portion of duck with a brick of egg noodles. The noodles were so over cooked or reheated that they wouldn't come apart and gave up after of few minutes of fighting them.  Fried rice was decent, egg flower soup was decent but I think most people prefer it a bit thicker and not watery.   Sweet and sour pork was good but the dinner combo only has five pieces.  Chicken chow me in was alright, just wish they didn't use so much MSG you can taste it more than the protein in the dish.  Might go back if I was stranded in the hood with no where else to go during a civil uprising.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

cBPGU7TSKUZAoxECnuf3jA.text: Amazing!!  Fast and friendly service, food incredible.   Clean facility.  Highly recommend!!

f0jZexbpeepRBzljb0mJcQ.text: Ahhhhh. The great hangover destination. Great Wall is probably one of the only times I've ever been to dim sum, which I know isn't saying much, because there are many connoisseurs of dim sum, that all agree this place is just so so, it's not SF or NYC. I think it's in a bit of a rough area. I've also been to quite a few dinners here, which I prefer.... For hot pots and salt and pepper crab. Also, the walnut shrimp, that is extra heavy on mayo, and well..... I could eat that for days.  They also have good tea. I remember some weird white flower tea that I really like.  They have a lot of events here (wedding receptions) I've been once or twice on Saturdays when they don't allow the public in, so try and call before hand or waste a drive all the way over there!

dq_xgj0yXxln0e4Tt8ZpFg.text: Great dim sum restaurant, good selection of items as well as the regular menu. Prices aren't that bad, its about average for ala cart $8-10ish and the portion are fair also. Seems to be a busy place from what people have said n the staff even said the same but today when we came in it wasn't busy which was awesome. We got our food quik n our table was taken care of the whole time, my water cup never stayed empty at all our tea was always replaced. I'd definitely come back and even recommend it to friends n fam.

pzwbiYCKox8N8g9EqMqWQQ.text: This is the best place barn on for dim sum in the entire state of Arizona. They have pretty much everything here and the only problem is if you want to eat dim sum and not wait for an hour or two, you better get here early.

ErP7KQLAvrMqc5hgkTl-og.text: If I could give them zero stars I would. The service is absolutely horrid. I don't even think that word truly defines the service. A lady straight up came to our table asked us "what do you want".. We told them and she shoke her head and walked away. We had to ask for food multiple times and only once were we actually listened to.  Fair disclosure we actually frequent this place a lot for dim sum but this one visit was absolutely the worst. I am sure we would go somewhere else of there was any other place that served dim sum in the phoenix area but choices are very slim.

r_NCBqWEozjY8H7cD8xS_Q.text: DIM SUM  on Sunday  IF you can get  in!!   When you have time try the duck.  Delicious!!

ZybLSUW4wRFysxf9PNaFug.text: Great Wall will always have a place in my... Stomach!  Being an AZ native the restaurant has definitely evolved over the decade and it's great that the quality in food has not dropped. Still and will forever always be known as a staple for asian dining.   Dim sum is absolutely delicious, definitely come early for freshness and variety or you will be waiting with the masses in line.  Banquet meals or family style dinners I've had countless times and they have options for everyone. If I weren't so far away in the east valley id be here more often.  Service can be choppy but if you know how to take the system or have a little patience you will be rewarded greatly.

dOvT4ppUAclyTyYFMgkmMA.text: Came with my friend Francis and a bunch of friends. First time here, and wow!  The Great Wall sits right next to GCU, in an unassuming strip plaza. The food rocks, service is fast, and the front of house management is tremendous.   We came for dim sum, and it's worth the drive from eastern Scottsdale. Well worth the drive!

n0bBhgVCn38yBYQdYcBTCg.text: This is probably the best Cantonese food I've had in Phoenix. I've been here plenty of times for the dim sum and it is great. If you want to try different varieties of food and appetizers, then this is your spot.   Tonight, I came for the dinner menu. So glad they are opened til 11 P.M. I got the Pecking Pork Chops (BOMB!) and it came with rice. They where crunchy but juicy and  meaty, a very big portion by the way. My girlfriend had the Walnut Shrimp (BOMB!) and we also ordered the 6 meat dumplings.   Can't wait to go back back and try the rest of the stuff. I will definitely recommend to anyone looking for good Cantonese food. Thank you staff!

1K0pCgU2O4VnKJGumd58mw.text: My family and I always go here for dim sum and for dinner. The food taste alrite and the service need some work. Sometimes they serve you real quick and sometimes they forget your table. I'm vietnamese and they always start speaking in Chinese to me. In my perspective, even if I look Asian like them doesn't mean I can speak the language.   For dim sum, I would only recommend to go during the weekends. If you go during the week, food doesn't taste as fresh and they don't have much dim sum item on the cart either. For dinner, you can go anytime. We ordered lobster and crabs, but it all look small compare to what they said its 3lbs lobster. The lobster and crab meat looks dried and tiny. Other foods tasted delicious and well seasoned.  I would go here only if my family wanted to or if I wanted to go for dim sum on the weekends.
