raKPpySpHD8On0i0doDglQ.text: I've only been here once so this review is only based on my one time experience.  To preface, I am Chinese and grew up in Chinatown in NYC.  Growing up, my family had dim sum every weekend so dim sum is not new to me and I've eaten at many dim sum restaurants.  1 star each is deducted for the quality and cost.  The cost is pretty high for mediocre dim sum.  They do have a huge variety and they come around in their carts.  I do like that they make their buns fresh.  1 star is deducted for my experience as a Chinese person in this restaurant.  I noticed that the non-Asians were seated in the middle of the restaurant which is prime seating as that's where the carts go to first while the Chinese were sitting at the edge.  The cart makes their way around a path and always start at the same path which means those sitting at the end is always getting last pick.  I recommend the staff to switch up their cart routes.  I also noticed that the non Asians were getting better service than the Asians.  Carts passed my table 3x without asking us if we wanted anything while the tables around us who were not Asian were asked every single time.  I cannot say this prejudice came from every staff member but I felt it from some.  I hope that the restaurant trains the staff to treat every customer equally.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

rVkvcbkbXq1TWw1SvFL62g.text: If you're a Dim Sum regular, then you know what you're getting into. The Great Wall is a good place for central Phoenix (I can't really speak for their non dim sum fair).       -- READ FURTHER FOR A BEGINNERS GUIDE --  If you've never been graced by dim sum, then...  Beginners Guide(from an equal amateur): Dim Sum, a Cantonese brunch(intended for breakfast) offering various bite-sized delicacies which are carted past your table in a procession of selections.   As a prototypical American, that had yet to be graced by these mainly savory selections until a few years back, I know the intimidation of the unknown and the risk of the learning curve towards possibly picking the "wrong" food.  For the uninitiated, it's hard to mess dim sum up at a place like this. But, be prepared to wait for a table on weekends. Once your lucky number is called, take your seat, ask for a tiny bowl of chili paste to mix with soy sauce and you are off to the races as the carts roll by. Don't be afraid to ask what's hidden beneath the trays!   First timer? I'd recommend starting with Sui Mai ("Sue-My"), Har Gau ("hah-cow" or shrimp dumpling), beef flat noodles(not your typical noodle), spare ribs, crispy roast pork(pork belly), and crispy roast duck (if it looks fresh). If you want something green... the Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce is delectable. And coconut filled buns or sesame balls are a great way to add a touch of sweetness to finish it all off.  If your looking for a great breakfast/lunch at extremely affordable prices, this is the place! My wife, son and I eat as much as we can and still leave for $30 or less.  If you're a more experienced dim summer, please add your input, corrections or recommendations for the best experience! Thanks and enjoy!

c8gF5hD2fTswKRm7L5dt4Q.text: This place is okay, just okay. They cook with no heart the food is okay the service is okay. It's not uncommon to see the servers have a meal all together during hours of operation, if that happens you're screwed.    When I say they cook with no heart I mean it. For example if you order two chicken plates you get the same chicken prepared in the same way just with a different sauce it's like they perfected the assembly line for restaurants. Everything is prepped and ready made they take the chicken what seems to be steamed use it over and over  the positive is that the food comes out literally in 5 minutes.   When your in the mood for just okay food that comes out fast this is is the place the food isn't bad it's just okay.

Mv2SPhwF_xEujYEPkaLZhQ.text: Been going here for years so I'm surprised I haven't yelped until now.  This is our favorite Chinese restaurant on the West side, or even in AZ.  This is where we grew up eating for any type of gatherings including birthdays, anniversaries, and weddings.  This is where my husband and I got married 6 years ago.  Eventhough it's not the most romantic setting and it's even in a very ghetto area, everyone knows a good wedding involves good food. At least for us Asians.    Now that we live on the East side, we don't go here as often but do visit whenever we can.  Our most recent visit was yesterday and we ordered our usual Fish Maw Soup and Crispy Seafood Chowmein noodles.  Eventhough it's still better than most restaurants, I felt like the taste is not as good as before and also the price has gone up substantially.  I heard that they had replaced the cook so that may have been why.  Anyhow, its still a pretty good place for gatherings and we've had many good memories here.  We will definitely come back whenever we are in the area.   Also check out their dim sums, usually a long line out the door on weekends.

yRVlaX1KrB1bxRyTlHXr_g.text: A pretty decent Cantonese restaurant in the Phoenix area that offers dim sum and traditional Cantonese dishes.  I'm from the NYC area, where there are plenty of fantastic authentic Chinese restaurants.  I wasn't expecting to find much, if any, good Chinese restaurants here while I was visiting family.  Fortunately, Great Wall was actually quite good.  Certainly not the best dim sum or Cantonese food I've ever had, but for what I was expecting, I was impressed.  Dim sum appears to be really popular at this place.  I came on a weekday at 11:15am and was surprised to see a pretty decent crowd already.  The dim sum is served in the traditional carts that get push around the restaurant from table to table.  You'll find most of the common dim sum items at this place.    For dinner, I've had a bunch of typical Cantonese dishes here - ginger/scallion lobster, steamed fish, beef brisket hot pot bowl, peking pork chops, stir-fry Chinese greens, etc.  Most of them are generally on point in terms of flavor and quality of ingredients.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

6bv9gO-lzzyW00lgFZktNw.text: This is probably the best place to go to in all of Phoenix for Dim Sum. I have been here for dinner before on a few occasions, and the family style food options for dinner are okay at best. However this should not take away from the fact that their dim sum is absolutely delicious and that is this restaurant's redeeming quality.  They do dimsum everyday, from opening until 2-3PM (Not sure which one it is, but I'd say until 2 just to be safe. While they open at 11AM on the weekdays, it's best to go early on Sundays when they open at 9AM because it seems like their dimsum menu is a little bit more expanded on the weekends.  In terms of price it is not all that expensive. When I eat here by myself I generally spend $15-20. When I come in a group of 3-4 people, we generally spend $60-80. Compared to other dimsum restaurants, especially in the San Francisco Bay Area, Great Wall's prices for dim sum is a bit lower. So the quality and taste of the various items, as well as the low price just can't be beat.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shu mai and shrimp dumplings!

oQIVZcIZAJecTynyqlqm9g.text: Didn't meet expectations at all.  First, we went there for dinner after reading the reviews. We were really looking forward to eat here. We were seated pretty quickly and handed down the menus. After that our server didn't appear. So, we had to signal some another server to take our order.   Mapu tofu, pork dumplings, and spicy pork chop. These were our orders.None of the food items wowed us. I mean with all that positive reviews, I had high expectations, but the food disappointed. I feel the food tasted below average.   Next, the customer service was  extremely POOR. We had two different servers. One who took orders and the other served. None of them cared to check on us, not even once.   Another thing that was really not fitting to the dinning experience is that there was some kind of event happening on the other half of the area. It  was noisy and the servers seemed to be busy entertaining guests of that event.   In summary, below average food, poor customer service, and dirty utensils/ greasy floors. We left disappointed and completely ignored as customers. Value of money spent was zero. So, one star.

EtUnTOc3p4fuM5icSMbqEA.text: A group of us came to introduce a friend's father to Dim Sum in Phoenix metro.  He lived in SF so he was not a complete novice.  I've been here many years ago, but don't live in Phoenix, so I don't get to come here regularly.  Needless to say the Sun crowd is large and you will have to wait for seating unless you come about 1 hour to closing...  After about a 40 minute wait, we were seated and there was still a good size selection.  We got basically the standards.  Now, something that I was not use to seeing was Chow Fun roll around, granted it was plain (no meat), but it still was nice to have.  I will admit, the har gow and siu mai were not as good as other places I have had, like Mekong.  Their Shrimp Cheung Fun was pretty good here.  They also offered some dishes that I have not seen at other locations, even some Cali ones... like salt & pepper wings.  Personally, I don't eat the cocktail buns (Gai Meh Bow), but I hear it's the best in town and they must be popular, because I saw trays of it come out.  Again, this place has been around for many years serving Dim Sum and they are good and I wouldn't mind coming out when given the opportunity.  They do offer a limited Dim Sum menu during the weekdays, but best if you can wait until a weekend to get the full experience and menu.

TX98n88XK5qmKSHFFCCU3A.text: They have a variety of food available for their dimsum. Usually, there is a loooong line outside on the weekends due to the variety of food that they have. When you come here, make sure that you get some of the coconut bread because that's one of the best dessert that they have! I have been here plenty of times already because the food is great, but I am putting three stars because although their food is good, some of their servers are just rude. Being in the customer service industry, I believe that each person should have a slight friendliness vibe, but some people there seem like they really don't like what they do.  Update from three stars to two stars:  Came in for dinner on a Sunday night, we got seated right away, but man oh man took 25 minutes before someone actually took our order. We had to flag someone down to take it for us, and then in top of that, the food took a while to get to us. They should really have a better system, and hire more chefs if needed if they know they are going to be busy on a weekend.

dYfHZnYi2JPwlqRSQgaVzQ.text: Dim sum: Delicious and authentic! Probably the best dim sum in phoenix.   Chinese food: also delicious and authentic, but i think they use a lot of MSG   Service: not the best. Depends on who you get and what mood they are in that day. LOL Get up and get your own chili oil. Get up and get ur own Togo boxes if needed. Smiling and being nice and polite is not gonna work but be nice anyways. You are there for the food and NOT the service. Lol   Will be back bc I love dim sum!

Z_fCI4x3IcCBjPsylTfntA.text: This is only one of a few Dim Sum places I am aware of and the closest to me. Luckily hubby and I really enjoy it. Although there is always a line the wait doesn't seem too bad. Food is fresh and the prices are reasonable.

upFgjEbsTwFvedC2sGrESg.text: For as long as i can remember, this is one of theee best places for authentic Chinese and Dim Sum in Phoenix!  I've been a customer here for more than 19 years and I can count on one hand the number of times I've been disappointed with their food. Let's get to the thick of it:  1. Chairs are armless and will comfortably hold my obese body. There's plenty of room to maneuver between tables if you request a table situated on the aisles.   2. There are TWO menus - one for group/family meals. The menu is catered to an American customer and staff can be very hesitant to share with non-Asians. If you want authentic food and not the same old sweet and sour, boring beef and broccoli, then out your foot down and ask for the pink menu.   3. The Dim Sum selections are matchless to anywhere in the Valley. There is NOTHING American about Dim Sum!  They bring the food around on trays and you choose and chew. Try something new! It's what makes dining out so fun, right? Dim Sum ends at 2:30 each day with the weekends having long wait times.   4. Bring your young kids and let them visit the half dozen fish tanks containing all kinds of live seafood.

pwAkwrDl5hg3kse4TvN4hA.text: Great Wall is probably the best place in town for dim sum!  It is served daily, however weekends are the best days to enjoy dim sum as there is a much larger selection.  When dining there during the week (for dim sum) I usually order something off the regular menu.    Everything is great, but my favorites are definitely the shrimp dumplings and shu mai.  You must try everything though!    Every time I have been in Great Wall, its busy.  Weekends especially, you should plan on waiting about 30 minutes depending on how many people are in your party.  Speaking of party size, the larger your party, the better the experience.  Its hard to try all of their delicious offerings with just a couple of people.  Great Wall is also open very late!  Midnight on weekends, but dim sum is only available for lunch!  Enjoy!

9iRczIn0AMFmSJAHil4liA.text: This place been around for ages, and still has not change much.  Anyways came here with the family to celebrate my grandmas birthday.  It's her favourite, most of the workers know her too.    The restaurant was clean, well kept, well decorated, plenty of seating, and quite furnished.  The staff were super friendly, attentive, very sociable and has excellent patience especially dealing with some of the family members.  XD service was fast, didn't really have to wait long for the food to come out.  The food was decent in taste, but still have room for improvement.  We ordered a bunch of stuff, from fish, to tofu, greens and mushrooms, chicken and duck.  The price is a bit high, not really worth the value, but it's okay.    The loo was quite clean, and looked great.  The toilet was a little weaker than a common house toilet, not sure if it was broken.  A fine toilet is like the ocean.... It crashes and splashes hard and leave no floaters a float.  They had adequate amount of toilet paper too, so use the loo with peace of mind.  Overall a great experience, if you're into the more traditional Chinese food, this place is for you!  I don't see why I wouldn't be back.  They have a good dim sum too, if you're into that brunch stuff.

jVPulq_CWryD1IAP0SrXmQ.text: THE dim sum place of the West side.  Also where most (especially traditional) Asians will hold their wedding or celebratory banquets, due to size and well liked food.

k7541Ix6gKBs2N6ugJjBpg.text: The Great Wall was my first dim sum experience, making me what you might call a tableau rosa*.  Since I know nothing about dim sum, all I can do is share my overall general biased by my own narrow existence perception of the place.  So here it goes.  As usual, Mr. K has accurately described and captured the essence of this restaurant in his review, so there's that.  Read his review.  What I can add is this.  The food all tasted good to me.  The atmosphere was fun and lively.  The demo is certainly nothing like any place I've ever been to in Phoenix, so those who decry the lack of diversity in this town, perhaps you just need to expand your horizons to include Great Wall into your rotation. And I would go back.  I have to get on the HIGHWAY to drive here, so that is saying a lot.  For those of you who are directionally challenged, it's the first shopping plaza on the east side of 35th Avenue, just north of Camelback.      *It's been years and years and years since high school English.  For some reason I think this means "blank slate."  If not strike "tableau rosa" and insert "blank slate" above.

qBqpBZaYaMUU0A-K4AKnfw.text: I think the dim sum was pretty good but their service was alright.  for some reason they seemed pissed off when they were pushing the dim sum cart.....

V-ERkU3H_SOH0v-QPrG8ig.text: yes, it's True, this is probably one of the better places for dim sum in phx. but, if you've ever had dim sum in more chinese-populated areas (ie, sf/bay area, LA's monterrey park, seattle, vancouver bc....) then, no it's not that awesome. but since i live here, when i'm craving some dim sum, i'll drive over with some friends after church. (note to those not familiar with dim sum - go with a medium sized group, about 4-6 people).  the dim sum is decent and not shockingly, a bit greasy.   recommended dishes: ha gao (shrimp dumpling), siu mai (pork/shrimp dumpling), steamed cha siu bao (a bbq pork bun), cha siu or shrimp cheung fun (bbq pork or shrimp wrapped in steamed wide, flat rice noodles), gai lan (chinese dark green vegetable), don tot (egg custard tart), lo-bak-go (pan friend turnip cake), and the steamed black bean spare ribs. the calamari is pretty good here, and they have pan friend shrimp/chive dumplings, which are my fave.   it's always loud and crowded here on the weekends. and it's typical chinese service - always annoyed, and slightly ignoring you ;) so get here early, or come towards closing - although you will likely have slim pickings for food the later you come.  and please, please, PLEASE stay in your freakin' seat, people! last time i came, people were following the carts around with their bills. they will come to you. just stay seated, sheesh.

Tl7Zp6LDBK0WRqweJCNSFQ.text: Well lets just say I'm not impressed and I will go back one more time to try dim sum, but so far this place has pretty average food and mostly tastes like it comes out of a mix. The dinning room is large and utilitarian but not very fancy but that don't make food good either LOL. Portions are small and the rice is inedible and not very tasty.  Service was poor and infrequent. All in all I do not recommend this place

4v5ZLpmNn13Mze1w_XfWHw.text: Came here for dinner on a weeknight. My brother in law just returned from a trip to China, and said that the food here was very reminiscent of the food served in China. Everyone was stuffed, it was so delicious! Thanks yelp, for leading us to another great find!

YbsdmGsas1oK5YqOayn5yg.text: Really disappointing.  The dim sum was ok, but the selection and service were horrible.  When we arrived around 12:30pm Sunday, it was busy.  We had a group of four and waited about 30 minutes to be seated.  I have no problem waiting, especially for good food and service, but there is no waiting lobby at this restaurant, just a small crowded area by the front door which was hot and you had to stand shoulder to shoulder.  When we were seated, we were offered drinks right away, but that's where the service ended.  If took forever for the first cart to make it by our table and that was only pastries and deserts.   Other carts were circulating loaded with dim sum but they never made it our table.   When they came close, they went flying by our table and would not stop. Gesturing and waiving was to no avail.  It was like we were invisible. When a cart did finally stop, we selected two or three items which were good but that was pretty much it.  From then on, it was always the same woman with the same items.  When we asked the servers to bring more selections they acted put out and never obliged us until a Chinese person in our group had to get up and track down a manager type.  Even then it took forever and the selection that was brought was poor.  I would not recommend this Restaurant to any one.  There are other choices for Dim Sum in the Valley.  Choose one of them.

Tgdv8vcU8IUCtKoESXdsnQ.text: Yum, eat here. Prior to moving to AZ, I was forewarned about the lack of good (dive) Chinese restaurants...my friend was wrong. This place has good, authentic Chinese food. If you happen to go over the weekend for dim sum, you are in for a real treat. Yes, the decor is lacking and the service can be slow, but that's not my top priority in a restaurant.

QIJ-PISoNbZiSGZi41v6Qg.text: Great dim sum with all the classic favorites from ha gua to duck feet.  The place is huge so the wait isn't bad.  The servers are also really nice which is hard to come by.  For Chinese restaruants, they usually have good food and bad service or bad food and good service.  Great Wall has both.

34R0t2dALMohDJnhzFpqJA.text: I have lived in Hong Kong and Singapore (two years each) and I still travel to Asia frequently.  I think the Great Wall is the most authentic and best tasting Chinese restaurant in Phoenix.  It is a popular place for wedding banquets among the Chinese community of PHX, and can get quite loud when one of those events is taking place.  As with most Chinese restaurants, the best meals are on the Chinese menu, not the English menu.  A freind who reads Chinese turned us on to the set meal #1 on the Chinese menu, which is what we order almost every time we go there now!  It is very reasonably priced and with a famly of 4 you will probably be taking some of it home.

o0-6dmZgR-8fZNrshj2XIA.text: I've been to both the evening, regular service, and the mid-day dim sum.  Visited 3 times in total and was never disappointed!  The food is excellent, quality Chinese food and not just decent fast-food-esque Chinese.  Dim sum is also very cheap -for $20, 3 of us had plenty to eat and even took home leftovers.  The only possible downsides are that the dim sum is not a place for vegetarians.  Also, an Asian friend of mine was a little bothered that all the servers directed their questions to her and kind of ignored me and another white girl.  I blew it off because that was par for the course in Japan and I'm used to it.  It's not worth fussing about when the food is so good. :)

_5DYyrOfWQyZk8gjw5JgGg.text: I've been looking for a good Chinese restaurant for almost 3 years since I moved from SF bay area. I had a dim sum lunch today and my tummy is happy, happy. It's a good sign that restaurant was crowded and I saw many Asian customers. I've been dreaming about eating dim sum for a long time. I had sticky rice, shumai, har gow, gailan and sesame balls. I love them all, can't wait to go there again. The price is very reasonable and very authentic. No more P.F Chang or Panda Express, lol

8npjvb0y_9j8Yy26B_3xew.text: Great dim sum. I like the authentic, lively atmosphere. Go with 9 other friends and try everthing. Also, very cheap. There were 10 of us and it was only $11 each including tip.

jQNE3uAsnQNCyJWjJd5pnw.text: Meh.  Just meh.  OK - maybe Dim Sum is something special, but random Tuesday night menu fare is not so good.  We spent way too much money for awfully bland food.  I mean, it wasn't BAD, it just wasn't great.  I can say we won't be going back to order off the menu...  I may give it another try for Dim Sum.  Maybe.

NmL9NwjRX7Pb9cOlaN2vJA.text: I've been to this restaurant many, many times because of their great dim sum, but after today I don't think I ever, ever wants to go back.   I saw a dim sum cart lady drop the sesame seed balls on the floor and pick it up and put it back in the tray, and pretend like nothing happened. She continued pushing her cart while I was looking at her.  When I confronted her, she pretends she doesn't speak English.  What the hack?  Top it off she's completely ignores me and serve the sesame seeds ball to other customers.  I told one of the server looks like a manager, he said he's busy.  Ok, diners you work hard for your money; therefore, you deserve hygienic foods am I right? Great Wall Shame on you!!!

009Ir4BXGtAmAa3M4Hpi7g.text: Food variety is poor during the dim sum and the tastes is not special - I feel that this is generic dim sum for Americans. Also, service is not very good and the restaurant is not clean.

alAvlvbFUqhPa8MowXLpbg.text: Anytime I am in Phoenix to visit relatives...they take me here. It seems like its the best dim sum place they have in the scorching hot Phoenix. Dim sum is good..but not the greatest.

MVUrOvP8ql3sewkIhyKMVQ.text: Had a great Saturday brunch here.  The food is quite good  and they have all the regular dim sum fare as well as fish for the cantonese banquets.  Portions are relatively large compared to other dim sum places, eg pineapple buns are 3 to a dish and large, similar to bakery size.  Chow mein is given on heaping 6 inch high mounds.  Har gow, siu mai are good.  The salt pepper squid looked good.  Sesame balls were excellent and had mung bean fillings.  Phoenix claws were also excellent.   Overall, this was a very good place to take family to.   Now, compared to California dim sum places this would only be an average place but because I don't have to drive six hours to California and the quality is good, I give this place 4 stars.  Prices are excellent and actually cheaper than many other dim sum places.  Excellent value and great portions will fill up any large family.

zsVdltXnPOJEyIuGHSnZuw.text: Dim sum in phoenix.  What can you really complain about?  Average everytime.  It is obviously not going to match the quality that you will get from chinatown in SF.  Shrimp dumplings, shiu mai, and bbq pork buns are typical dim sum food.  Get those and you cant really go wrong unless you feel adventurous.  Then try any since many are good too depending on the person's taste.

HZDaueh-J8Wam0r-CYmaog.text: Great Dim Sum!! It's very popular and my wife and I find it THE PLACE to be after early church on Sunday. There are so many dishes that it's hard to find a favorite. The do serve noodles and rice is a rarity, if at all. We come every Sunday. Great food!! Try the chrysanthemum tea which is next to impossible to find anywhere else.  You have to ask for it though or else you'll get the standard jasmine tea.  Otherwise just sit back and enjoy

pshq-t4WU7kOAs6qCTrwNA.text: Best place for some traditional Dim Sum available daily til 2pm. Food is good, service is okay, but make sure to get there early on Sunday otherwise you might be standing outside for a bit as it gets pretty busy during Dim Sum time. Also a favorite for Asian banquets! Love me some Dim Sum!!

4NAcQr428qn_PuBO-bdd-g.text: Xie has no clue what they are talking about.   Great wall is a great place and is used by many chinese for weddings. I mostly go there with family and enjoy large meals (sorry dim sum people) we have always enjoyed the great food and good wait staff. the only problem i really have is.... the menu... the American menu is small, really look a the Chinese menu its huge and things most people will never know about try the shrimp and walnut in mayonase sause and the scalups and green beans with exo sauce (i'm probably spelling those sauces wrong)

M577CGT4gP5GrY9cTTtSsQ.text: Dim Sum in Phoenix is like asking for rain in the desert.  It's few and far between, and you settle for finding water rather than asking for rain.  As far as dim sum goes, Great Wall is one of the best you'll find in Phoenix; it ain't the rain, but it's good water.  They have a line-up if you're not there early (a good sign), serve all the basic dim sum dishes using the traditional cart service.  Not the best dim sum I've ever had - but then, I've had dim sum worldwide - but certainly good considering this is the desert.  Within Phoenix I'd give it a 5 star, but my rating system is based on what I've tried worldwide in my many travels - so only 4 stars.  If you're in Phoenix and looking for Dim Sum, this is one of the few good watering holes around that can satisfy that thirst.

Rimk02teuF86Q_m7nHMq0Q.text: I went on a weekday a little before lunch time for some dim sum.  The place had maybe 8 tables occupied.  We were seated quickly.  There were more dim sum carts than there were workers.  Since I didn't know the name of some of the items of I wanted, I ended up using my iphone to show the waiters a picture of the food.  A lot of the dim sum items were packed with meat, which ended up being too overwhelming for me.  The sticky rice seemed bland.  The daikon cubes were flavorless.  My favorite item would have to be the tripe.  I've had better luck at asian supermarkets that sold fast food dim sum.  Does AZ have anything like that?

DPPq0k6ZZ3XgyGcXlwbhxg.text: Wow - yesterday's meal was quite a disappointment to say the least.  We sat for 20 minutes before someone finally rolled by our table with a cart of food.  I would have grabbed several of the dessert rolls had I realized that this was going to be the only chance at getting something to eat.  My bad, we only snagged the Chinese broccoli thinking that one of the other 4 carts in the restaurant would eventually make it to us.  Another 15 minutes later, another one did, but the attendant proclaimed he was out of food and what was left was cold...never stopping.  When it was apparent that the reloaded cart was heading back to the other side of the restaurant despite our dialogue about feeling faint and promising him we'd be happy with cold dim sum at this point - we had to get up and leave.  Five stalks of broccoli.  Yum.  How is this possible when the place was packed at lunch time on a Sunday?!  To add insult to injury - there were 7 people in line in front of us - so we left a $10 bill with the check for 1 item on the counter....only to be chased after by the cashier who felt we needed to get back in line.  Just unbelievable. I won't be making the trek back there again.

uKTCm5ig5xwgSD-LD8aF8Q.text: What a treat to have such good dim sum.  The variety is great, the food is tasty and reasonable in price.  We were in Hong Kong last year and they have stopped serving from carts.  It's nice to see that the tradition has not been lost in the US.  Stand out items would include any of the dumplings.  I would avoid the congee though.  Usually restaurant congee is fantastic, this was the same as you can make at home.  I'm normally a taco shop only kind of guy when I go home to Arizona, but I would definitely spend some calories here.

KjLi6bo8Rb9RINEkv3HRFw.text: Stopped by Monday for our first trip here. At least 50 people waiting outside. We won't be back.

ohZFxHQoPPpj-tqScjUN3A.text: Make sure you go early on the weekends, or be prepared to wait if you have a large group!  This place is very busy, but it is a large dining room and you should be seated fairly quickly if you are 2 or 4 people. The weekdays are less busy, but they don't always have that large of a selection. A nice variety of dim sum and they also have good bbq meats. Having grown up in Vancouver and SF, it is tough to get 5 star dim sum in AZ, but this place is good and they have the authentic girls going around with the carts.  I would recommend it if you are a dim sum fan visiting the PHX area, or craving dim sum and do not want to drive far. The place could use a facelift as it seems a bit dirty inside and the bathrooms are not that clean. This place was the only place I knew in PHX when I moved here that had dim sum, but now there seems to be plenty of others to try.

1leQU_x8WiHhzxMzX1KrrQ.text: I must have gone on a bad day .....  Shortly after walking in, we were seated but no one came to take our drink order for at least 10 minutes and then it was only because we said something to a waiter walking by.  The Dim Sum selection was very small and the quality just wasn't that good.    Who charges for refills on a fountain drink anymore?  They did have a shrimp/crab egg roll that was real good!  I think you will find me at C-Fu Gourmet from now on.

64mkjOKjRC897Gb8Hkel-A.text: From pork dumplings, fried eggplant, duck, softshell crab! What a variety. Took a while for the carts to roll our way but the place was packed on a Saturday at 11:30 and a line when we left. Authentic Dim Sum - you wont get a lot of help or translation so know what your in for aand have fun. The duck was the only dissapointment- had to hunt for the meat. The second cart coming around looked better- so hit or miss on that Im sure. They are open 11 - 11 and 1am Saturday.

wk_GKCK2w1PqLLoK3c5q0g.text: Went for dim sum and enjoyed it immensely.  The worst thing about it was the wait staff wasn't very attentive and didn't do much except refill the cups when they noticed they were low (which wasn't very often).  The dim sum was plentiful and there was a lot of variety - however, unless you watch for the carts that just came out of the kitchen and only order off that one there's a good chance you'll get lukewarm or cold food.  I couldn't eat the ice cold duck and ended up taking it home and microwaving it later.  If they would just work on the heat issue and the wait staff, I think they have a shot with the city slickers.  ;)

iew-8wg43MGbJarA8QQLag.text: Food was good, especially for my very first time being here. Theme seemed very authentic chinese, even though I never had authentic chinese food. Price was moderate, but service could use some work.

VjLKSZGqqEjPE1DyGiJO7g.text: BEWARE:  They automatically charge  everyone in your party for tea whether you ordered it or not!  They do this when you go to pay the bill.  This is done purposely. You have to tell them NOT TO CHARGE YOU.  Very arrogant in cheating people this way.

t4T5t3iE2oJIcFl5jWi5MA.text: I thought this place would be Great when I pulled up and there were a ton of people outside on Sunday morning 11ish! Upon going inside I saw that 95% of the patrons were Chinese. To me, that was an even better sign. Then the food started coming and coming and coming..... 9 dishes later, the two of us were fat and HAPPY! The food was great and all the servers that came by our table had warm, personable attitudes. Oh yeah, we will be going back!

l1CbQRZY4Dkz1V6rccualQ.text: Not the best dim sum in the world but pretty good and reasonably priced ($7 per person for 4 with hungry eaters at lunch). If you go at "awkward" times they sometimes will only be able to serve steamed items but the myriad choices are fun to share for picky eaters and the adventurous alike. Love the chicken feet and some sort of shrimp dumplings!

a_S4aHJ2Q7meZ-SwNWNrfw.text: They get 5 stars because of dim sum and proximity to my house.  We've been 3 times, once during the weekend when every table was full but the variety of food was better.  If you've never had dim sum, you may be surprised by how infrequently the carts come by so load up on the first time by.  Don't hesitate to ask the server to lift the lid on every single item in the cart and don't feel pressured to get anything you don't want, no matter how many times the server asks you if you want chicken feet.  I like the har gow, shiu mai, fried shrimp egg roll, turnip cake, tofu skin stuffed with meat, noodles, soy sauce chicken, curry puff and anything that looks like a steamed dumpling and egg tarts for dessert.

AyQCf7j3pNheTezs_Z8GsA.text: This place is hardly the best Asian resturant I've visited in AZ. Their takeout is horrible. House Fried rice (bland, 1 shrimp), dumplings (mushy). Not good at all. I won't revisit.

XywH-7bNWjfhnGPpbh5yrQ.text: Best place in the valley for dim sum.  They are always consistent.  I've been coming here for over 10 years.  Since I'm allergic to MSG and dim sum always contains MSG, I often order off the menu and request no MSG.  I'll eat some of the dim sum and suffer the effects of MSG afterwards.  My dim sum favs - har gow, sui mai, char sui bao, and coconut dessert.  Dinner - best peking duck with the buns and steamed fish.  Overall, good place for chinese.

CuxchkD1afkRNHJnsNoqOw.text: I might be bias but it's only coz my family and I have been regulars at the Chinese dim sum joint since the late 90s. At one time it was Great Wall vs C-Fu in Chandler and now with the emergence of more Asian power centres, as well as an influx of Asians into the city, there are more dim sum places like Phoenix Palace by Lee Lee, Golden Buddha in the Cofco Center, China King in Chandler, and China Chan up north.   This place in my opinion is pretty good, and cheap. You just have to know when to go. The best time is at 11 on Sunday. Anytime after that expect a long wait, and before that (dim sum begins at 10a) it's ok but all the good stuff and most popular items and specials come out at around 11:30 in time for the rush. If you come in after 1. Expect alot of popular stuff gone =( . I'm partial to this place because my family has developed a good relationship with the servers at this place. We're not the typical dim sum diners since we also order certain items from the menu in addition to dim sum. I like their beef chow fun w/o gravy or the seafood chow fun with gravy but no fish. The salt and pepper squid is decent, and totally not a fan of the Chinese Brocolli with oyster sauce on the carts so we order the Chinese Brocolli with garlic sauce, much better and way yum! We also order a la carte so we can get rice with our meal because rice with your dim sum makes it better. Oh, and if you order roast pork, order it off the menu and not on the cart, it's a better cut and less fatty. And that calamari on the cart is not the same as the salt and pepper squid.   So when I'm craving some shu mai, char siu pao, bbq pork buns, steamed bean curd, and sugar cake, i head over to Great Wall for sunday brunch... and love the endless refills of jasmine tea! see ya at Great Wall!

OivKwiSML5oYG5_0R75wmA.text: My family recently purchased a second home in Phoenix . We are Chinese and we are from Vancouver so we know what good Chinese food is like. This place is awesome and authentic.  Every time we are in Phoenix, we stop by here for dim sum

d2Sg0wmFo7w7zyKBWByDBA.text: Customer service was nice but without incoming food, there's really no point lol. All in all, I recommend the shu mai & sesame seed balls... cause that's all my family really got to try.

BqVSmRMfDA6EHpz_uM99xQ.text: One of the best dim sum places here in Phoenix, AZ.  If you're looking for dim sum (Chinese breakfast), then you should go on Saturday when it is slightly less crowded.  I would GREATLY advise you to avoid Sunday especially after 11 AM.  It is super packed, because everyone gets out of Church or just waking up.  You will be waiting for atleast 30-45 minutes for a table.  Food is served by waiters/waitresses pushing the cart of food around. It is a mad house when you get in, but the food is pretty good as far as Phoenix standards.  Can it compare to California, New York, or Toronto, Canada?  Hell no! But since we are in Phoenix, we are limited to "Great authentic" Asian food.

-CIKUheSMTRWYMRPsCGAEQ.text: If you hate being interrupted and enjoy getting sick from your meal, this is your place. Gather 'round, and let me tell you a story about why you should never go to this place.  My family and I went to Great Wall Cuisine for Dim Sum Brunch. What could go wrong? Literally, everything. We waiting for about an hour for our table, after being quoted only 15 minutes. We, a party of about 12, were seated in the middle of the most crowded part of the restaurant, with 10 chairs. We had to get our own chairs.   I asked for water, which I'm still waiting for.  The food was pretty terrible. The only good thing was the Shu Mai. Everything was salty and dried out (probably from sitting on the cart). We also had to chase down servers to get food. I literally watched a a guy with a cart walk back in forth in the EMPTY section for 10 minutes so he wouldn't have to interact with anyone.   We saw a cart with several items we wanted on it, but instead of letting us pick from that cart, they were SAVING it for themselves to eat. With a restaurant pretty full, all of their employees sat and ate.   So, in conclusion, any one have a good recommendation for Dim Sum? Because this isn't the place.

3Tt11bi5wk14CpTVvVVBFg.text: Came for dinner and back for a dim sum breakfast the next day. Service is fast and the food is authentic. We really enjoyed the round table settings.   For dinner, I highly recommend the steamed chicken. It practically melts in your mouth. Order the soup of the day. It won't disappoint.  Dim sum had all the classics including roasted pork ready to be served as soon as we got there. Will definitely return.

WqWjfpiensd-lwUsP3K4dg.text: I'm back to update my review on Great Wall.  The new news is there is none !  Great Wall continues to serve fresh hot authentically made old school dim sum from rolling trolleys.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Tower of soy sauce noodles in the foreground.  Shrimp egg rolls , barbecue pork buns, lotus leaf sticky rice and siu mai in the background

s2BlpotStyjguYvzk-vEyA.text: We only come here because this is the only dim sum place in Phoenix.  I've been here countless times and each time there is always something wrong.  The last few times, were especially disappointing.  We had an event party, they dishes that we pre-order were pre-made!  That was bad!  Giving them ample time to prepare the food, we were served refried roast duck!  We order 6 ducks, everyone complained the ducks were soaking in grease with fried skin.  The chicken was just as bad if not worst, parts were still pink and parts were foul smelling.  We also had buddha's delight that was artificially redish pink color, strange looking and taste disgusting.  The rest of the dishes weren't much better, the only thing that was half decent was the walnut shrimps.  Don't recommend, don't come unless you are dying for dim sum, but don't order off the menu.  And check your bill, they have been adding on $4-6 by 'accident.'

gXJbI_-nXBgXdp2onvmedQ.text: Have been here mainly for large celebrations such as wedding receptions, Chinese baby red egg, funeral memorial meal and Chinese New years. So we have never eaten here ala carte. When you eat there for a large celebration it is generally between a 8 to 10 course meal. When eating this way you eat "family" style so you get to try multiple dishes and get a little of each dish and then spin the dishes around on a lazy Susan to share with the others at your table. The servers were okay but the restaurant itself is good when they have a banquet style.  Nothing to bring you back because of the decor or service, would probably only come here for the banquet.

k3C1iX43oOhV6Ld2l-TlfA.text: Have only ever come here for the Dim Sum which is awesome. Staff isn't SUPER friendly as has been mentioned but the service has always been great, and I actually did once get a cart lady who was just hilarious and awesome and introduced me to my new favorite dumpling. Saturday around noon seems a lot less busy than Sunday. Looking forward to going back soon with more people simply so I cab order more food.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Those pork ribs were amazing.

3RRoDaPSdVYsrvxOzLOtbQ.text: What an interesting place. It was packed when we went on the 1st day of 2017. We went for dim sum and although it was our first time and a bit confused we ended up enjoying the experience.   We snagged some steam dumplings, Peking Duck, veggies, noodles, BBQ pork stuffed sticky buns and other delectables form their push carts they have rotating around lunch time.  I will definitely be back some time and I enjoyed the experience.   Judging by the amount of asians in the restaurant I would say this authentic enough.

a9adpm7wGBiyjgq_Ey82Gg.text: I went here with my Japanese/Hawaiian friend. Also, I walked in and was one of the 2 or 3 caucasian people in the whole restaurant. It says a lot when those of the culture expressed in the style of food are eating there regularly. The scene is chaotic, and I think that's what bothers me the most about this place. Chaos makes me anxious. The food was okay. Nothing was hot when it made it to my table. Also, plan on sharing a table unless you want to wait. This place is crazy busy - make some new friends - talk about the food. The chaos of the tables being close to each other, the carts trying to get through, and everyone trying to make sure that they get what they came for just makes for an anxiety driven situation for me.

rf8WbZnvOpSAl53qMypKmA.text: The food is terrible. We tried the dim sum. We were disappointed and overcharged. We won't be back.

6yJ1ZnyhIh99To6feiim-g.text: Great and probably the best place to get good dim dum!  If you're coming on the weekend I would advise to come early! There's usually a 20-40 min wait which is why I gave a 4 out of 5.   Otherwise they have a lot of great options!

Clfu9BHeSe3RKS1nQKIi6w.text: Best dimsum in AZ! Been going to Great Wall since I was a kid. I really like the ha gow, su mai, chicken feet, egg tart, and the BBQ pork buns... just try everything from the carts lol. The noodle dishes are also good if you order it off the menu, we usually get the 'beef chow fun'.  The food is always fresh, staff is usually attentive and the restaurant is quite clean. There is usually a wait if you go on weekends and holidays (especially Chinese New Year).

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dim sum

bThhR4njOr9LbiJwRdihzQ.text: Best place for dim sum in the valley, best bang for you buck! The only thing I can complain about is there service is a bit slow. Something they need to improve on. Other then that food, is great!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Roast duck, pork &amp; seafood dim sum, &amp; some yummy green vegetable.

l3YxzYHAiIOHZjsKXpXokw.text: Service was very slow and they were out of some items. No apologies from anyone. I'll give it another shot soon.

T_S7dStRTLqcHazC-xLyCQ.text: Everything about my food experience was great! What originally drew me to making the drive to try this restaurant out were the reviews posted here. What made me a believer was the taste and quality of every dish we ordered. I always try to find Asian restaurants where you see other Asian families frequenting....I mean, who eats at a restaurant when you can cook the same dishes better at home. My family and I were the only non-Asian people there on a fairly busy night.  The portions are large enough to share and still have left overs. Comfortable seating as well. The only major issue that we encountered is that there is no handicap accessible ramp or space between the front parking spots to get a wheelchair through.

Uz4dL5HCR87NKmA8GZebWg.text: This place has been here for years. For years! I have been coming for years. For years! I still think this place has the best combination of quality dim sum, decor and other menu items. The variety here is just awesome.   Golden Buddha, China King, Mekong Plaza, they were decent. Those places were good because you don't really want to travel that far for dim sum and those places were in their respective areas. Except Golden Buddha closed.   But for a complete experience, go to Great Wall. You should go on Sundays around 10:30am. That's when their menu is at it's fullest. Asian people go out Sunday mornings haha. There might be a wait but carts will come by more often, more items and you get to see a lot of Asian people. There are also items that are not on carts. Like giant noodle dishes. Don't miss out on them!

4_bx7iu9v0lngVtjDYAJIw.text: I've been craving Dim Sum for such  a long time now and had to say this place is worth the wait and the drive from Tucson. The quality of food here and the service it pretty good, even when it's busy!  ****Environment: The place is pretty big with lots of round tables that can seat up to about a party of 8. The table wares are pretty clean and the bathroom so is the bathroom. Usually places like this doesn't have the nicest bathroom but here it was actually very decorative and modern.  *****Food: The food was great. It's really hard to find a good dim sum place with good quality dishes but I believe I found the place and this is it. I've had great BBQ baked buns, chicken feet, shu mai, rib tips and definitely my new favorite the duck tongue. The flavor and seasoning was all there not too bland or too much!  ****Service: The service was very prompt, and definitely made sure there wasn't an empty plate on your table. They would seriously take away any empty dishes within 1-2 minutes. They were friendly as well.  Overall if you are a dim sum fan, I would definitely recommend this place!  [ Taste it, Love it, Yelp it! ]

BS31_pXKoCNvMpiMRL-UtQ.text: If you are if their race they will cater to you otherwise don't go in. No offense. I love Chinese food just not here. Food was cold and we waited until ,everyone got there plate which was 1 every 15 min. Food lacks flavor and is sloppy. They messed up on the food and were arguing in there language over us. Then we waited 1 hr had to leave and take our plate to go so he sneezed on it. Gross!!! Place needs a good cleaning smells bad and is dirty. I should have left in the first place. But was on time crunch.  6 people no one ate yuck!!

7T8ZUyvyUQD-jMteDpTIdA.text: Food was delicious. Services wasn't to great when we where there it was difficult to get anyone's attention to place an order. The baked buns was a hit with the other half as well as the dumplings. Next time we're back in town we definitely be back for some delicious food.

31BS6mVq7UrIBbklSwFIBQ.text: Ehhh, we came here for dim sum on a Sunday morning.  The place was pretty busy at 9AM.  I gotta say I was not impressed with the food or the service.  The food didn't taste fresh to me.  The presentation was subpar and our pot of tea went dry without the waiters' attention.  The checkout process is beyond embarrassing.  You have to take your cheque and queue at the register near the front door.  There were two parties in line in front of us and it took over 10 minutes to pay and get out the door.    Their ha-gap were OK, but we tried 9 other dishes and I would pass.  The price is competitive with Mekong but I think the quality and service at Mekong is far superior.

xbSmufOwF7e50llh8rovlQ.text: Chicken feet on point...not standard to give you the chili sauce and mustard sauce so make sure you ask!

ecGht_PwNj99Y9Xy_-Oasw.text: Go with a group and get the dim sum at the big round tables and you will be able to try a million delicious dishes and have a blast. Great tea too. The servers go around with plates on carts and you can just pick whatever you want. Deserts are great too!

eiEe3C4HpBeFtUslEadkYg.text: The menu was loaded with so many of the dishes that I truly like that it did become somewhat difficult to choose....but I managed...I ordered hot & sour soup (the bowl), chicken chop suey...and while I wasn't sure exactly what Salt and Spice Shrimp was, I was hoping it to be salt & pepper shrimp.  First out of the kitchen and onto my dinner table was the hot & sour soup...a huge steaming bowl. Let me say, I have had hot & sour soup all over this world and while it varies in taste and consistency, this soup tonight was outstanding...absolutely outstanding. Next out of the kitchen was this salt & spice shrimp...wow, these were not shrimp at all...these were gulf prawns...huge...took two hands to pickup. The shrimp came with the heads and tails, and shells...not a problem for me, but perhaps a bit squeamish to others. No issues, I hoisted up one shrimp and gave the head a slight twist pinched the tail and dropped it into my mouth. Oh my goodness...these were awesome. Perhaps the serving was a dozen shrimp, I didn't count them, but there was quite a few. Remarkable...!!! Last out of the kitchen was the chicken chop suey...let me say that this was not the actual name on the menu, that escapes me, but it was a chop suet. It was also fantastic. But to be honest, with the soup and the shrimp, there wasn't much room left for the chicken chop suey. I needed a "to go box" to bring the left overs back to the hotel.

V31VQ8ns0PXdulwpypKkLg.text: If you live in the West Valley, you are out of luck when it comes to finding Dim Sum. The closest you'll find is the Great Wall on Camelback and 35th Ave. The only other one that I know of in Phoenix is C-Fu on the east side. I enjoy the Great Wall's Dim. The Sumai and Howgow are very good and it is so reasonably priced. I've tried the Spicy Salted Squid and consider it to be pretty good. I would order it again, but I've had better in Portland, OR. I would recommend this to you if you're looking for Dim Sum. Not much competition out there though.

0dzq3m_rwRQCaAJlzFkyKg.text: Note Correct Address is 3446 West Camelback, adjacent to Grand Canyon University campus.  Mediocre dim sum if you're from Southern California. Don't expect much variety on weekdays, as it isn't that busy for the chefs to prepare a lot, although requests can be made. I wouldn't bother.

W5UNHcbd8ye5J5YBYoJqqA.text: Our usual visits here are for either dim sum or lobster. My wife loves the lobster in black bean sauce and shrimp. The pricing is average and the service level can vary. If you're a guay lo, don't expect it to be like a trip to the olive garden. It's very different in both cuisine and culture. So enjoy yourself and make sure to go with friends or family!

eZdo27ulBX4KlWpgzQqL3g.text: When my great- grandpa was alive, we'd come here once a month and spend our Chinese New Years' here as well. A lot of memories tied here for me! I stopped in last week for the first time in years. My pops, and I had the Chow Fun, Snow peas, and scallops, with a bit of Dim Sum!  It's still as tasty as I remember it being as a  kid. Nostalgic bliss to my taste buds!  Plus, there on deck with Dim Sum practically everyday, what's not to love?? One of the last authentic spots for legit chinese food!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Snow Peas, and Scallops, Mmmm...
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chow Fun, Pork and shrimp Shumai, BBQ Pork buns, and some bomb-a$$ tea!

nGKgUYMXNo_KOjpU7dYw4A.text: I read all the good reviews on yelp and it was the only reason i gave this run down restaurant  a try. The food was ok, ive had much better cheaper. The service was the worst i have ever experienced.  Our waiter, who i believe  was the head waiter, took our order and brought out my dish 10 minutes before my companions. We shared it and didnt think much about it. But that waiter never came back. I saw him walking the floor and gestured for him twice, ignored both times. A diffrent waiter and bus girl helped us. After the meal was over i waited 20 minutes  to get our check which the front cashier brought us. I will never go back.

72pATWpjix2Wy1eFjxiw3A.text: While Phoenix in general is not the place you'd go to for dim sum, this place serves its purpose well. They have the old fashion carts doing around the place. The tea is hot and steeped well. The place is always busy on the weekends and depending on where you sit; you may or may not get certain dishes such as the popular hargow. The servers do try to accommodate any requests by remember who you are and saving dishes for you but it's basically a luck of the draw to see what you will eat.  Regardless, the food is authentic and great.

_e8yqF13z0RtTXo0hYz5Ig.text: Dim Sum was very tasty. It reminds me of Hong Kong for some reasons. Service may be a bit slow, but it was worth the wait. I like the food variety. Chicken feet were meaty and soft to eat. Overall, I enjoyed it.

wCVgXMR_hcNR9L-g67cUJw.text: I was part of a HUGE event. There were well over 30 tables, with 10 at each in other words a packed house. We were all served the same thing, and there were 8-9 courses..maybe more...all were very delicious and ver coordinated in presentation. All tables were served at the same time.   The beef and crispy chicken were very tasty as was the pork. I enjoyed the pre-salad and mushrooms also. Would come back again. This was part of the Asian Chamber of Commerce Lunar New Year Banquet, also very well put together.

7xF2jR6M61lKzhX3sWRbMw.text: I think when you have great company to go along with great food, those calories don't count. Right? Well, that's how I'm looking at things today because Great Wall not only made my tummy very happy, but I'm graciously looking forward to going back again soon to mack on their delish cuisine.  Robert M and I met some of his coworkers there this morning at 10:30 and were treated to some of the best and most affordable dim sum in Phx. Like, San Francisco good and affordable. I won't pretend to know the names of much that we ate but I can tell you everything was mighty fine. And the four of us were stuffed by the time we stopped eating and for $14.07 a person. Somebody hit me!

QhYWET4z_L5FKRmmPQ0vkQ.text: We loved it. Lots of choices and great bustling atmosphere. Everything was very fresh and not too greasy.

-GTE2_9kXhoAV7M_q3-fqw.text: It's an entire day later, and I think I'm still digesting this meal. Man, I'm so full.  First off, huge props go to Sarah K, Pierre T, and Jeffrey O for meeting me out in nondescript west Phoenix for Chinese food. I've been trying for two whole years to get people to meet me here for dim sum and the thought of "dining in west Phoenix" turns off just about everyone (especially most native Phoenicians I know who are surprisingly "west side"-phobic.). So a big thank you to you guys for indulging me.  Next, the restaurant itself. Imagine a giant banquet-hall sized Chinese restaurant actually filled with mostly Chinese customers. Families seated around big round tables: grandma, grandpa, mom, dad, and the little kids. In Phoenix, this is a rare sight, and as opposite to seeing Grandma Ethel eating fried wontons with sweet & sour sauce at the Abacus Inn as it could be. So you know from the get go that Great Wall is doing something right with authenticity.   We sat down and were immediately brought tea, and if you've ever been to dim sum, you know that servers are constantly wandering around, pushing carts full of goodies. Steamed dumplings, fried dumplings, sweet dumplings, savory dumplings, buns, giant flaky egg rolls, stir fried kai-lan (Chinese broccoli), chicken feet, custard and other desserts, lo mai gai (sticky rice), noodles, the list goes on and on and on. We picked a variety of dishes as they went by (sans chicken feet), and went to town.   I'd say the dim sum we had was pretty decent. Not the best dim sum I've ever had, but obviously I liked it all enough because I was a nonstop eating machine until I was ready to burst (which was frustrating because there were so many more dishes being carted around that I wanted to try but I just. Couldn't. Do. It.) To be fair to Great Wall, probably next time I'd come earlier than 11 am and request a table closer to the kitchen in order to get the dim sum as warm and fresh as possible, instead of picking dishes that have been carted around the dining room for who knows how long.   The atmosphere was great - there's a certain cacophony in big dim sum halls that I really enjoy. Tables full of families and friends talking, laughing, and enjoying their food as more than a dozen servers are hovering around with their carts. And the best thing about us finishing our meal with us stuffed to the gills? Only $11 plus change per person. You really can't beat that.  All in all, a great change of pace from all my dismal Chinese restaurant experiences in Phoenix. And a restaurant like this will no doubt also have a full-on Chinese menu along with their standard Americanized menu for lunch and dinner, so I'll definitely have to swing by and try that as well.   So if you're ready to try Great Wall for some weekend dim sum, let me know and I'll be more than glad to join you.   Just not today.   Because I'm still full.  4 stars.

_LS67lnOeT-Al9OIc8IQRA.text: I've gone to the Great Wall twice in the past few weeks and both times were fun, crazy, and memorable. We went on Sunday within the 10am hour and we were sat almost immediately and were rolling our chopsticks within 10 minutes. If you're one for new experiences and can tolerate a little disorganization then you will be just fine. Don't expect to be catered to because this place can be a free for all once the crowds kick in (11:30am) . You gotta be quick with what you want and don't stand around asking the cart staff in-depth questions like What's that?, What's in that?, and is that spicy? Be quick, look, and nod because you are holding up the line for the rest of us! Because Me soo hungry!  Don't be startled by the slowly moving cart with the 2 foot mound of noodles making its way through the eagerly awaiting crowd. Oh and yes, you will see Chicken Feet, lots of them. However, if you're not that adventurous then there are plenty of other treats to chose from. Just throw caution and pretense to the wind, dive in and enjoy!   Unfortunately I am not able to make any specific reccommendations because I don't know how to spell or pronounce most of the items on the carts... Sorry!

7ZuEM93y0tL7xd8lDDsAmQ.text: Typical traditional Chinese restaurant. Heard its the better of the food restaurants here that are open late. Foods not bad, restaurant could use a facelift and a better sign outside/Door, but good thing I dont live in AZ.

mdpcpz8g8YoYLe0VhDG67Q.text: Don't eat here expecting any kind of service. Keep track of your orders, they will "forget" a dish or two, but still charge you.  Otherwise, the food is fast, fresh, authentic, and one of the best places for large groups of people to eat dinner or dimsum.

tenNo8Q9_ro9V2ddwfu4hg.text: Horrible customer service!!! One of their many incompetent servers took our dim sum ticket when they picked up our dirty dishes. When we went up to pay for our food the lady gave us a huge attitude blaming us for loosing the order ticket. After yelling at us I front of their other customers one of the servers finally found the ticket dripping in food sauce in one of their dirty dishes cart. We didn't get our drinks until we were almost done with our food. All around a horrible experience please do yourself a favor and go to another Chinese food place instead!!

FvB46dI8WUeh6yAG2WlB6A.text: I have eaten at the Great Wall a few times now but always part of a banquet or function. So this might not apply for a regular experience. Most of my Chinese friends and organizations have functions there so I am assuming that the local Chinese believe that this is good food.  Food is very good and plenty of it.  Love that creamy shrimp,carrots and walnut appetizer. Duck is good. Mushroom dish is very tasty. Service can be slow but when a couple of hundred are in the room, you can't expect them to be perfect.   I have yet to try the dim sum but have heard from my Chinese friends that is the best in Phoenix.

F8_XkX2_fHnLYXnSSDOwPg.text: Great Chinese - Cantonese restaurant, both dim sum lunch and dinner order to share style!

bQLA7j-zjQbmBkAfrqnzBg.text: Dim Sum!  The food comes out fast, service is always friendly, the place is big and they have all the stuff that I like.   Come late on the weekend and be prepared to wait.

JsNMyJguq2LCjDklbrPQuQ.text: By far the best in the Phoenix Area for Dim Sum. We've been to the 2 places in Chandler. They have a great selection and spot on service. If you come on a Sunday expect a wait. Even if it's 30 minutes, it's well worth it. My wife and I would eat here every week if we could!

xJ5PXQ6IG4kHPB_OpX1CTg.text: Very very few restaurants that offer Dim Sum in Phoenix. Great Wall does it the best.  I'm from NYC and grew up going to Dim Sum in Chinatown. Great Wall serves many of the traditional items found in big cities that do it right. Servers push their metal multi level carts around the dining room, full of varied selections of little samples (appetizers) which is what Dim Sum means! Whatever you choose from the carts that are circulating around the dining room, the food is prepared properly every single time. Never have I had dry chicken or a shu mai that wasn't done up to par. It's all on point! Don't miss : BBQ pork buns (grab these as soon as you see them! They run out fast!) Roasted chicken Roast duck Shu Mai And for those who know these- the sesame balls with sweetened bean paste inside!! I know it sounds gross and it's really an acquired taste but man I love those!!! Lol

SFDQsEYpQkXmiNJMw3EPpA.text: Best Dim Sum in Phoenix, and a local landmark for Chinese food! My family has been coming here for years and always will!

wYFgaphp19j1lK43La-JMw.text: This is a classic Chinese Cuisine with authentic food close to town. We come here to celebrate a birthday dinner or dim sum. The food is excellent in Arizona standard. I have been coming here for 20 years now. Sometimes we run into old friends or family which is nice too.  We love the food. They have the best Bao and BBQ Duck in town. Sometimes we drive 35 miles to buy duck!

kYvYxlSff7AaoEqimSCHyg.text: The food here is really good, but the service isn't that great. Half of the time they don't even speak English and acknowledge us when we needed more drinks. We ordered about 5 plates and they were delicious (Peking duck, fried crab, beef chow fun, steamed fish, and chow mein), we also had 2 sodas and our bill was about 125 dollars. I think the food might be a lil overpriced but it's fine with us because the food here is great. Definitely will come again for the food but not the service. It was basically nonexistent.

V9fhitZCaURtuvbhn2VzqA.text: Ok dim sum.. . nothing exceptional.. we have been here about 5 times.  They open at 10 but if you get there right when they open your selection for dim sums are not that good and you have to wait a long time between carts. We arrived around 1pm (they close at 3) and they stopped making food and there were only 3 carts going around. Pretty much trying to get rid of what they had made already.  When i asked the owner if they were making more food, she said no, they were not making any more because they were getting ready for a party that night. I guess we weren't that important.  The people who do the carts do not make eye contacts with you (Could be cultural) so you have to holler at them as if you are trying to catch a cab in NYC. They have a lot of people working (walking around to fill your water, pick up empty dishes and change tables) so you can always grab one of them and ask for what you want but I had a challenge with that too because I don't speak Chinese or Vietnamese but luckily they did  have staff that I can communicate with. Wait staff are very helpful and friendly. Probably why I return to this place.

Dle603VmwSEx4xYrW9H2Lw.text: Authentic Chinese food as close you can get in Phoenix. Service is above chinese average which is pretty low. 4 Yelp Snow pea tops with garlic 4 Yelp a bit over done and tons of garlic. Chicken egg foo young 3 Yelp never had chicken sit on top of the egg foo young. A bit sweet in the sauce not as savoury.  Shrimp with lobster sauce 3.5 Yelp too much sauce.  Overall 3.5 Yelp not the 4 star as rated.

EQLsMD4AAKdMvERsnqSkhg.text: Huge, spacious restaurant with every table filled and a long long line of people waiting to be seated for their turn to partake. It was worth it; big selection of tasty morsels. Prices were reasonable and service was very good. Definitely a place I would come back to and recommend to me friends and family

umKq9oCbdhRCGUhGliBAIQ.text: My wife and I arrived here around 11:00 there was an extremely  Long line, but it moved fast. Inside the place was packed. There wasn't any additional seats, they were booked to capacity. When we checked in with the hostess we were asked if we would be willing to be seated with other people. We said no problem but when our name was called we ended up with just the two of us at the table.  The dim sum experience is not for everyone.  Those not accustomed to the noise and crowds should stay away. The place was Jam packed with Chinese families which was a good indication of how the food would be.    All the carts came around frequently. Service was standard for a Dim Sum restaurant. Nothing much to complain about or compliment.  This place was really crowded. It was a bit uncomfortable because the tables are really close to each other, and the aisle aren't hat wide. With the carts going around the place it can get super cramped and uncomfortable. Oh, it was also super noisy, but that shouldn't be a surprise for such a crowded establishment. The servers pushing the carts around were hard to understand so I have no idea what we had or what was in the food but I can tell you we enjoyed all the dishes we picked.  None of the dishes really stand out. The food was good, not spectacular, but Just your standard dim sum fare. With the exception of drink refills because no one came around to refill our beverages.  FOOD: The menu is standard Dim Sum. PRICE: Expensive -This accounts for why I rated the place only a three. My wife and I spent $30.00 on lunch and didn't really have that much food. I can't imagine what families must spend here on a big meal.   ABIANCE: Nothing fancy but you don't come here for the ambiance you come here or the food. SERVICE: . CONCLUSION:  The food was decent and the price was high for what you get. The decor was non existent and all tables/chairs were all covered and not the most comfortable. However the Great Wall managed to satisfy that dim sum craving but was not even close to the best I've ever had. The search continues. RETURN  FACTOR: 90- 95%  ************************* What does my OVERALL rating mean?*************************  5 stars -Highly recommended.  I would be willing to drive out of my way to this business. It is that good. This place represents their industry or cuisine very well!  4 stars - Highly Recommended. I would frequent this business.  3 stars - Not that good but not that bad. Just average. I wouldn't mind going again.  2 stars - I would not recommend this establishment to friends or family.  1 stars - DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND DO NOT patronize this business. I would RUN AWAY from this place and you should too! DON'T WAST YOUR HARD EARNED MONEY AT THIS ESTABLISHMENT

fuYUPv4a0KPx4V5v-YlpaA.text: They were busy for Chinese new years eve . We were seated quickly . The  rice poridge was nice hot and tasty.  . Shrimp  ball was great . Had their  crispy roast pork . . Some of their normal dishes did not come by . Spent about 20 a head . Lines were out the door when we left

Fl3CmeXlrWc6S7NGIjGoSQ.text: This place is alright! I went here with my family this week to have dim sum. It's my second time coming here. The first time I came was for a relative's wedding.   Atmosphere: 3/5. It's a old restaurant, so the decor is kind of worn out generally. I wouldn't recommend it as a wedding venue, but it's possible? They have a section of the restaurant that is sort of a "stage" area with the red curtains as backdrop. It's pretty old-school asian.  Food: 4/5. Not the best dim sum I've ever had, but it's pretty darn good for dim sum in the Phoenix Area, considering there aren't that many. I liked the "desserts" (egg tart, bbq pork pastry, taro pastry), and the shrimp entrees the best.   Price: Pretty good price. Dishes range from $2 - $6 a plate for dim sum (or the ones we got anyways).

m2BdU36-Wak_F4y5QWrdjg.text: fresh, hot, wonderful. Loved every dish I have tried. Large portions, excelent service every time. A fan for more than 15 years!

P1n2oJAcfoPwnqpw4Ta3vQ.text: This is my favorite place for dim sum. I come here on the weekends and it is always very crowded. They have all the normal stuff and I have not found a better place for dim sum in the valley.

K-3eAC1KlyhQt2SZ_alkfA.text: Yum, yum, YUM! So grateful to have found this place. I've gone on the regular hour and the food was always good. Service is very chillax, so relax and enjoy the food. Now the best part for me was when we go and enjoy the Dim Sum, (variety of small plates you choose), which is served daily from 11-2p. Sundays are crazy, the line is so long, but people seem to happily wait. Either way it's fresh, tasty and much better than any other Asian restaurants around. Now what are you waiting for....? Go! Go!

5dpTAODPSOIl-0lfAbfWPA.text: Why would you name a restaurant after a thing designed to keep people out? Just like china this place is huge inside, and even has tanks of live fish.  The menu is huge, and this is just the menu for the gringos. If you know Chinese there is a whole menu of family meals that you can order from.   There are many vegetarian dishes not just the usual tofu and veggies, they have a large selection of exotic mushroom and veggie dishes.  I had the golden mushrooms with tofu $7.99 a house specialty. Mitake mushrooms a light brown sauce and huge pillow of soft fried tofu. It was nice ans somewhat light  We also had the black mushrooms with Chinese greens. $9.99 This dish had a very earthy taste and the greens were very fresh but hard to eat with chopsticks.  Another great dish was the veggie hotpot that had some really interesting textures along with the noodles and veggies.   Service was a bit lack luster, but maybe that was due to the wedding in the other side.   The shopping center it is in is a bit run down too so you are assured you are paying for quality food and not the building.   Bottom line great selection good flavors good value mediocre service.

jUFn2j_i-ONYIaGrnmWGPg.text: This is the BEST place for dim sum in Az. One of the most exciting parts is that they don't only serve dim sum on the weekends. They have great tea, fabulous Chinese broccoli, and MANY other dishes that are very fresh in spite of coming to you via the traditional carts. I always recommend coming here if you are looking for dim sum in the Phoenix area!!!!

58JTI9kkW8JMEIpDMQRsmA.text: Introduced to Great Wall from family. Found the food authentic as it gets, a big plus coming from Hawaii.  For all the kama aina to try, if you don't  know the word it doesn't apply. The staff are helpful and remember us everytime we dine. The food is hot, flavors real and staff are quick to help.

II3m0eWApxIQWiF12w6yQg.text: I'm a dim sum lover. Boston, Chicago, Denver, Columbus, OKC.  All good. This place is good enough in a craving pinch when you live in Phoenix and don't feel like driving to Chandler.  It's 7 min from my house so I will go back.    Dim sum staples all there... Shu Mei, BBQ Pork Bao, Sticky Rice, Chinese Broccoli was ok, nothing special.  It just doesn't seem made fresh.  I don't know if it was pre made a few days before or just bought from a supplier in mass. Just didn't taste "prepared that morning" fresh.  Also, was hoping for more pan fried options.  The place was full on a Sunday so that's good.

u7zUOitVgXxt-9a_B7NxMw.text: Something that my friend calls football pork (bread) was our favorite item in the menu. We have been here a couple of times after my first review and I am not longer as excited about Dim Sum, lol. But the food is still good and it is fun to try so many different items. We have been there only during weekend, I think Sunday all the time, and there is always a wait in the morning (brunch/lunch time).  The mango desert with carnation like milk is also very good.  I try to be patient with this type of situations, but for English speakers, be aware there may be a language barrier with some of the staff. : (

XqTp-HFzsdb3YY9bDAbS6A.text: Always great find but really disappointed having to pay for refills on ice tea. I drop them a star for that

t6wGsu1pJzINb3hBx8W4PQ.text: I came here around 3pm on a Saturday and it was dead. I had heard great things about their dim sum and I was dying to try it! I grew up in San Francisco eating dim sum in some of the best hole in the wall shops so I wanted to absolutely love this place!  Well, I didn't realize that they only do dim sum BEFORE 2:30 (every day). That was a fail on my part. We decided to stay since we were already there and starving. We ordered the egg rolls, wonton soup, kung pao chicken and bbq pork chow mein (all pretty standard dishes). My two star rating is based on the fact that their dishes lacked flavor! The kung pao was so bland and didn't pack any heat at all! And I'm not one who enjoys eye watering, mouth burning heat but I at least expected there to be a bit of a kick. The chow mein was greasy and the bbq pork was dry. The only thing that I actually enjoyed was the wonton soup. I wish I had ordered more of that!  Most everyone mentioned the lack in customer service and honestly, that usually doesn't bother me. But when I have to get my own take out box or my own water because no one cares to check up on us, that's when it gets a bit annoying.  I may go back and check out their dim sum but I'll be sure to bring my own drinks and Tupperware with me next time.

g_Xv8DsOol8sKPBgh7z-tg.text: Since my move to AZ I have been to Great Wall on several occasions and each of them have been pretty good. This is your typical Chinese restaurant that has dim sum on the weekends, closes for banquets/weddings, and serves really good Chinese and Vietnamese food. Everything is good here. I love the har gow and siu Mai, and I also really enjoy the jellyfish dim sum dish though I noticed it lacked the seaweed accompaniment that I'm used to. The bread and buns are tasty! I haven't found an Asian bakery around the area so eating dim sum desserts will have to do. Definitely a great spot for dim sum.  Be forewarned that it gets pretty busy on dim sum days. It seems like every Asian family in the area comes here so that speaks to how good the food is. Additionally, there are a lot of options for dim sum, way more than I'm used to do you may have to look through every cart until you find something you like, which shouldn't be very hard. I can't wait to revisit by go-to dim sum spot!  PS. Here's a tip for dim sum novices. If your teapot is empty, flip the lid upside down on the teapot. That's the unspoken way to get a refill on your tea.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Egg tarts!

pgnrIWgf8a-UVYLUgrZcGA.text: The best authentic Chinese food in the valley! The only place that I have found Chow Funn! Deliciousness all around!

fWrzfTbNs6aYEuX_cYAZsA.text: What happened? Have been coming here for years- decades even. Always the best dim sum.  Our last visit was awful. They had a very limited selection and they hardly came by. I felt bad for these 2 guys at a table in the corner who only got food if they frantically waved down someone. And it was not a racial issue because they even spoke Chinese. The cart with the shrimp in the crispy wonton skin never came by so we asked a man who was taking orders for another table. He brought theirs but never brought ours. As we were leaving, I saw the lady with the shrimp we wanted standing outside the kitchen and people were having to walk to her! I figured it was because it was Chinese New year and maybe they were tired from celebrating.  Just went back today. Usually there is a huge crowd out front of people waiting. It was empty. It was a sign. Again poor selection. And then we got the pineapple buns- 2 out of 4 were empty! Literally no filling! I wish I had snapped a pic but didn't want to make a big deal of it since it was a celebration meal with the family. But we brought home some coconut buns and my brother bit into one and it was empty too! I got a pic of it. I cut the second one and it too was empty!  So disappointed. No wonder all the customers have disappeared. I wonder if they got new owners or something.   Guess we are going to have to drive even farther to the east side for good dim sum.
