Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Empty coconut bun my brother bit into.

0xXTvgKRkn1dGGsJNhFWlQ.text: The Great Wall has been my go-to dim sum house for as long as I can remember. Since I was a young child my family has spent countless birthdays, holidays, and Yee banquets dining at The Great Wall. With that, perhaps I'm biased. But this restaurant is by far my favorite restaurant of all time. The food is good tasting, and I've made countless memories dining surrounded with my family.  Since moving 800 miles away to Pocatello, Idaho; a small town with no dim sum houses or chinese restaurants worth a visit, I have found myself having to make my own dim sum. Learning from the internet and frequent calls to my grandparents, and constantly tweaking the recipe with The Great Wall as my standard. If anything speaks to the quality of this restaurant, it is that since moving away, missing their food has motivated me to spend countless hours in the kitchen, making har gow, siu mai, hom sui gok, and many more of my favorite dishes. If I could give six stars I would.

xCy-QP6r4KlhElWrZ58jLg.text: i feel like they dont really have alot of variety in the dim sum BUT i have nowhere else to compare it to.  I really like the chili sauce they give you, the dim sum with just shrimp in it is my favorite just because its a simple dumpling and with chili sauce YUM. I tried the porridge which was okay and the chicken feet... not a fan although my bf says the sauce is very flavoring. they had these buttery looking bread things that i thought was dessert but inside of the bread had this red saucy chicken which didnt taste too great.. i just thought it was a simple bread.... ): disappointed.   its really hard to understand everyone because (idk if its because im asian) and they try to speak to me in chinese or vietnamese (im korean) or if they really strong accents.. i just dont know what theyre saying...   although one of the servers was asian-american and spoke chinese and english fluently which made things alot more comfortable for me and i appreciated it alot more than i should ^^   food-wise, it's an okay place for dim sum, id come back just because there arent many dim sum places in the valley but if i had another place to compare it to maybe theyd be better? not sure...

5hQFnPDoWcipAg5kHxGHlA.text: My top Chinese restaurant in Phoenix so far. Their dishes have signature taste. Even a normal appetizer such as craft puff is amazing. Everything is flavorful and excellent.   We came here on Christmas day. Luckily, the restaurant opened. We had great dinner time here, specially after having a long tour waking around in Phoenix Zoo. The food tastes even better when you are hungry.   Sometimes people recommend me eat during dim sum time. I tried it, but I prefer the other thing. Since you have been here for many times, you know  your favorite order and don't need to pick randomly.   The price is little bit high, but it worths. As long as they treat you well and your family like their food,    Great Wall restaurant is always the top one in my list.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yummy

yM8NUPtp6UlRzLRP-hotug.text: Excellent Chinese food. Every dish is delicious and authentic. Thank you for the fabulous dim sum!

J5Kg3BZ9tYXbFWhHvVKNeQ.text: I've been going here with my family for years since Golden Buddha closed for dim sum.  This place has many of the traditional dim sum dishes and sometimes they would bring out specialty dishes either on the carts or by server to the tables but that is few and far in between.  One of the specialty dishes I always look for when I come here is their calamari.  The past few times I visited, they have not made it and it always saddens me because it is one of my favorite things to order.  I've never had any issues with the food and service from the staff is usually fair.  This is a great dim sum place for not being in LA or SF.  Tip: get here as early as you can on weekends.  Like as soon as they open kind of early.  They do get very busy very quickly and is not uncommon to wait 30 minutes to an hour if you come during peak times.

MpyrbgaraBbP-V36WScy7A.text: Haha.  I come here to eat all the time but for some reason why I never write a review until today.   I usually go here with my friends and finally for dim sum. Dim Sum here are pretty good. I've tried their foods from the menu too and it alright too.   The only problem I have are the workers here. They are not attentive at all. Waters are never refilled after the first time, the plates and dim sum holders are nasty. They need to wash their dishes better.   I am not Chinese, so it's hard to communicate with the ladies their who doesn't really speak English. (Not trying to be rude). But not everyone who comes here are Chinese so it is very hard to talk with the workers here sometimes.   The cashier lady is just a no no. She is always asking for tips. I understand you work for tip but let the customers handle it themselves, you don't need to tell the customers to tip.  The food is good. Mainly go for dim sum.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

nZdIf_4eGWFH9UGDy9w2SQ.text: I come here for Dim Sum.  My daughter will often request their "shrimp in noodle." I like to make them eat the Chinese broccoli.  My son loves the shu mai.  My husband likes the chicken feet.  And when I'm craving Peking Duck, salty pork, or Wonton Egg noodle soup, I'd also come here.

3_EXZuTHz5MWFK1RLciAoA.text: The food is just not good. I've been there FOUR TIMES and each time I have left feeling like Panda Express would have been a better choice. Also, the price. Normal entrees like orange chicken is something like $15 not including tax or tip. And the service acts as though you are inconveniencing them by being there. In no way am I trying to be unkind or attack the establishment, I simply would not recommend it.

u6gP00uP-HL9Itbh6ebWmA.text: Most amazing dim sum!  We are the only white, non-asians in the restaurant, so you know it is authentic! So amazing@!

qzsKI6NwwVlXGiBtrwnOLQ.text: Best Dim Sum (Chinese breakfast) in Phoenix hands down, all my friends and family come here for the Dim Sum and we keep coming back. I've also been to countless dinner and wedding events here and the food is equally as yummy! The food is always consistent, we've never had a complaint about the food. Service though is not quite up to par, it's very casual and light. Great wall definitely had great Chinese dishes other than dim sum, they have great Peking duck and other lunch/dinner dishes. They also have tons of seafood, crab, lobster, etc... that can be a little more on the expensive side but regardless, pricing is amazing, you'd be surprised at how much you can get for $50 here!

PaYto49fvSB1wtjslokwyQ.text: My family have been a long time customer of Great Wall. The dim sum is always delicious & the dinner entrees are good. The wait for dim sum on the weekends & holidays can be over an hour & they do not call you based on first come first serve. It is based on the number of people in your party & which tables are available at that time. Dinner is slower & there is never a wait. The only down side is customer service can be a hit or miss.

KTxbxwhkXW7Tom9CSOyY-g.text: Recently went here during the weekday for lunch and was surprised how different the service was compared to the weekend. The options for dim sum are very limited during the week, the bao was quite different as the bun had a sweet taste to it rather than the plain white flour which is more salty. The weekends are quite busy and they open at 9am The staff was pleasant, the prices are reasonable. This restaurant is quite a distance from my house so I doubt we would go back especially during the week. May consider going back on the weekend as there are limited places for dim sum in the valley.

a1PodEAwPMWzFB-_IiiCsA.text: No siu long bao/soup-filled dumplings, so we gave it a miss.

5MoqLLHMofYrUCJdJsJLMA.text: I'm from San Francisco and very spoiled from fantastic Chinese food! I'm always on the search around here for delicious Chinese food. A friend suggested we try the dim sum at Great Wall in Phoenix. I have to say it was pretty good! There were Asians eating there which is a good sign! There were wonderful dumplings, not a great variety but what was there was good! We had egg rolls with shrimp inside, shrimp dumplings, rice noodle with bbq pork, tofu skin stuffed with mushrooms and veggies, we had a lot! There were lots of desserts we had the oval bun with pineapple, that was really good!  I'm going to come back again to have lunch and try their noodles. The lunch specials I saw go by looked really good.

pmXzhpTSulE_n7DJRapEhA.text: Came here for dim sum on Christmas eve.   It was crowded which is a good sign, however, the dim sum is not up to standard.  They had a decent variety of dim sum but the taste is not there.   Very disappointed as this is suppose to be the best dim sum in town.   Maybe I cannot compare as I am from California but still I expected better.

Vv2xEFEqfp-aKmZkkEZBfQ.text: I've been craving this place since I left! This place isn't fancy and isn't the newest and cleanest looking establishment, but the food is freaking authentic and flavorful! I was lucky to have been meeting up peeps who already got a table, so I didn't have to deal with the wait. Phew! So I have no idea what the process is like for that, however it was jammed packed in there and full  blown busy. Plus there were a huge wait on a sat. afternoon around 1:30 pm.   Most authentic Asian restaurants arent known for the customer service, but they do a good job in acknowledging us there and having my water glass full, so I guess I can't complain too much haha.   I need to make another trip back and try more, but I highly recommend the noodles, fried jalapeno chicken wings, dumplings, BBQ pork, and the little buns with the sweet custard inside. LOVE!

EEOpQZ53JiqXiUHH0wSbkw.text: I just happened upon this place looking for an Asian food store. Saw a big crowd and was curious. Turns out the place is AMAZING! There was a wide variety of dim sum and everything that I got was tasty and delicious.

iWRCZ5DOBrxM4KMR73z7Ig.text: I really enjoyed my first visit here. But first, you need to be prepared to wait... And wait... And wait. They were calling number 65 and we are number 101. We arrived at around 11 am and sat at around 12:15 but this was on a Sunday. But once you are in, the fun begins. This isn't like your regular Chinese restaurant. The servers push a cart filled with food and if you pick something from their cart they will sign your ticket. Now, as for the food, you have got to try the shrimp dumplings and their chow mein. It's so delicious. You also have to try the pork barbecue buns, the sesame balls and the buns that has a red dot. It's filled with a custard like filling, it's so good. My husband and I ordered waaaay too much food. It cost us 40 dollars and we have so much leftovers to bring home. We'll be back soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Left to right, shrimp dumpling, pork ribs, pork BBQ buns, chowmein

GruI7qDeqD-CeX31Q2NKBQ.text: Was here today with friends,  arrived 10:45 we had a 30 minute wait which went by fast. When we finally got seated the food arrived quickly, however, it wasn't the food we wanted. We watched the servers leave the kitchen and they always took the same route so by the time they finally got to us they were out of many Dim Sum.  After a while the servers stopped checking on us we inquired about more food but went on deaf ears so we left but the bill came to $82 bucks.  Not too sure how it got to be that much not too sure if we will come back BTW only 3 of us eat.

OrZkIe8uzHDaNXMQWBEjvA.text: My mother in law says this is the best Chinese in town. I don't know if I can agree.  I've had much better dim sum at Mekong and Phoenix Palace. A lot of the carts had the same things and we had to wait a while for the "good stuff."

O-yTrQRt9aftzUUGyb-yvA.text: Like any other good place, the weekend can be a long wait. But it's worth the wait. I really love all the selections they have, and the employees are nice. Chicken feet is my favorite !!!

opnkSZ-c2WrjKqr9SjzeIQ.text: Food it good. Dined in once and it was nice. I usually do take out. I always get the Hong Kong noddles either shrimp or chicken. They are bomb ! Over all it's a good place.

Se3NK8j6-KV4hgnWJ-IALQ.text: The food is plenty and of variety. It is cleaner than other buffets I've gone to so I never mind going back.

ugR6qsgnAJuJlcI5-Y7wHg.text: (Jerry Lee Lewis - Great Balls of Fire)  You shake my taste and you rattle my brain Too much food drives a man insane You serve me buns, oh what a thrill Goodness gracious Great Walls Cuisine  I order Shu Mai and some Chinese Broccoli You came along and you poured me hot tea You changed me plates, looking good Goodness gracious Great Walls Cuisine  Great Wall has been and one of those restaurants that brings back memories for me.  My first dim sum experience in PHX but also many other Chinese events are held here year in and year out.    Dim Sum is a staple here at Great Wall and is always jammed pack on a Saturday and Sunday morning.  I can say Great Wall has had it's up and down days, but since Dim Sum is rare in PHX; I always come back.  I shoot for the basics here Shu Mai, Sticky Rice & Chicken, BBQ Pork Buns, Pork Belly, Chinese Broccoli, Egg Custard, and Sesame Balls.  Overall, it's what you expect from any Dim Sum place.  I would say your best bet is to stay safe and know what you're getting.  At the price you're getting Dim Sum here it's totally worth your while for veteran Dim Sum connoisseurs.    The place itself is decorated like your basic Chinese restaurant as you can imagine in any American movie; yes the red signs and fish tanks.  Service has improved through the years and that's a relief! - Enjoy!

8h99g_IzynIR-823nVz12Q.text: We are dim sum aficionados. I have eaten dim sum in most American cities, plus Vancouver and Winnipeg. Seattle and San Francisco are the best and occasionally cities like New York and Minneapolis surprise us. Phoenix has never recovered from the demise of C-Fu and China Doll. While C-Fu still exists, it hasn't served good dim sum in over ten years.   Great Wall. Hmmm. I want to love this place. I've eaten there every 2-3 years for twenty or so years. I've never found it to exceed average. The service is good. The vibe is cool. Some of the dishes are ok. The baked Barbeque pork buns are good. The pork shumai is pretty good. The shrimp dumplings are ok. But the rice noodles are flavorless and starchy. The deep fried shrimp balls were fine.   So Phoenix, with a healthy dim sum tradition, hasn't had memorable dim sum in 5+ years. Why?  Great Wall may be the best of a mediocre handful of dim sum joints but that just seems sad. I guess I'll try the food court in Mesa, Mekong Palace. I have heard good things, but only from Phoenicians, whose taste I'm starting to question.

lHSI9e1A-7iVmJlkgm0RXw.text: This is the best Chinese food hands down,I've been coming here for 10+ years and it's never failed to amaze my taste buds

w2OBK1l2VsgVjvP6tGRQEQ.text: I was told to go to Great Wall because it was the most authentic chinese place in the west valley. Upon entering, the dining room was huge with gigantic fish tanks. Mostly empty at dinner time.   Handed immense menus, with an intimidating list of items. Server was absolutely disinterested in talking to us, and seemed somewhat impatient when asked for recommendations, as if we were dullards totally unfamiliar with the process of ordering something. He pointed to a series of items that appeared arbitrary, but I just just kinda went along with it because I really wanted to see what they had to offer. I was unimpressed by absolutely everything that was brought out, with the most offensive being a plate of sweet ribs that managed to be tough, greasy, sticky, and oily at the same time. Not everything was terrible, but none of it left a positive impression.   Maybe there's something worth ordering here, but I didn't have it.

we1RD5G0xn-jL8TbnwmTjQ.text: Best authentic tasting Cantonese food in the valley. Dim sum carts abundant with different dishes to sample. They even have set dinner meals for 4,6,8,10+ depending on the size of your party. The set meals come with appetizer, soup, main entrees, a noodle or rice and fruit at the end off your meal.   Favorites: har gow, siu mai, pork spare ribs, shrimp wrapped in ho fun, shrimp and chive dumpling, fresh baked roast pork buns, pineapple coconut bread, sticky rice. Order the salt and pepper squid, beef ho fun noodle and the seafood chow mein.   After you have experienced the food at this restaurant, you may never go back to the Americanized Chinese food places.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Fgts5wj2HpEQZDkil4Nhgw.text: Though the food is good. Please watch what they charge you according to menu price. For just egg fried rice and mangolian beef $27! I didn't think about it till after. The lady in the front tries to pull a fast one. Not happy for being a regular customer.

i8R7hMpcVtdIpa1yON1jmA.text: Great Wall Cuisine serves Dim Sum by day. If your not familiar with Dim Sum I read that it translates to leisurely Chinese Brunch. Servers stroll the large dining room and some of the servers stop at your table and say, "Want Something?"   Some of the food we tried was DELICIOUS like the appetizer super crispy fried chicken and the tender crisp Chinese Broccoli possibly called Yu Choy.   Some of the food I found was for an acquired taste like the mushroom and bean stuffed tofu skins and the sticky rice.   Some food looks familiar but is different than expected like the sesame balls that I had at many places stuffed with sweet bean paste but here they were stuffed with fruit.  There is a slight language barrier with some of the help because for some English is a second language.  I asked the cashier when they serve the menu so I could order off a menu next next time and try the fresh fish. The cashier just recited the restaurant hours to me.  The very large dining room looks like a banquet hall and looks like it holds over 300 people. They sat us on what looks like a stage. I was able to leap up to the table but it would be too difficult for some people.  We shared 5 plates of food and it cost around $27.00

Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Plates I tried
Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dim Sum Cart Service

IFBTgdVWxRgHDF9aSQlHxQ.text: The restaurant is a little plain on the outside, and could certainly use an upgrade and a nice tidy on the inside. If you can look past that though, you will find one of the best Chinese food spots in Phoenix. The food here is fantastic! We started with crab puffs, egg flower and wonton soup. The soup was served piping hot and was fresh and tasty. Crab puffs were also very good, but a touch greasy. After the appetizers we were excited to see what dinner would hold and we were not disappointed. We ordered Kung Pao chicken, walnut shrimp and Singapore street noodles. The Kung Pao was amazing. The sauce was fantastic and just the right amount of spicy. The walnut shrimp was perfectly plated and flavorful. The Singapore street noodles were delicious, but a bit hotter than the spicy Kung pao. It was a great first experience and we're so glad we tried it.

IX1AcMlO_JNyrwdljBQaig.text: This was my first time here at the great wall an the dim sum was amazing the different type of dim sum was very good an the sumi was great I plan on returning

photos.caption: Photo of Great Wall Cuisine - Phoenix, AZ, United States

8f8tPN1PFzimV2C0a1-o5A.text: The dim sum it's not too bad, they have a very good duck nice and tender, and go well with a good white rice.

UGEP7AcxjAobB92t3fSrpQ.text: This is my favorite dim sum place in Arizona. I'm such a huge fan of Great Wall. They never fail to provide deliciously prepared fresh food. If you love shu mai, spareribs, roasted duck, congee (rice porridge), char siu bao and many more traditional dim sum dishes: THIS IS THE PLACE.  And please don't get me started about the baked goods. The custard buns are my favorite. Dinner is great here too for groups. You can order different dishes and share with your guests. There is plenty of dishes to choose from. If you are able to come during lunch, they do have lunch specials.    Some people are not huge fans of the service at Great Wall, but I think it might be more of a cultural aspect or language barrier. But between me and you, I consider it part of the experience. :) As silly as it sounds, there is no other place like Great Wall, and it well worth it for the food.

ofZmRzabRAfoacA2-ZcQBg.text: I have eaten at Great Wall since they first opened and I must report that the food and service are sorely lacking as to be not recognizable from the past. The overall rudeness of the wait staff beyond belief.  I went back last week for Chinese New Year's and had a wonderful experience with the staff and great dim sum. They must have been having a real bad day earlier in the year. I'm very pleased because I did not want to lose this place as its the last dim sum place in Phoenix. All the others are in the east valley.

gTMliWe2SVHAg1TgyIhPfQ.text: Fantastic authentic place for Dim Sum. The prices are reasonable and the food fresh. Lots of choices and they have a standard menu.  Theses one of those places thats tucked away in a shopping plaza that looks slightly questionable, but you know the food will be good. Everything checked out good as I looked around and it seemed like I was one of the only non-Asian persons there, which is a very good sign that I am in the right place! When they have live fish tanks in the back where you can pick or buy your seafood you know its the real deal!  Service was a bit slow, but they were fairly busy when I was there for lunch, overall everything was good.  I would go back again next time I get the Dim Sum craving.

DGqM94J4S3HYBCAy1RVxqA.text: In my opinion this is a hidden gem best dim sum in the valley. Very affordable as well. Good service nice hot tea perfect lunch time getaway.  I would recommend to try it out on the weekday to get comfortable with the items. There are servers with carts that go around the tables and you get to pick what you want until you are full.

ZzLOahxWx3ZHFqFPU1Q6lQ.text: Dimsum is top of the line but discovered discrepancy in bill by $20- . Strongly suggest you meticulously  review each item ordered ...those chinese characters can be deceiving ...

kbz3ykfvWh_QPhwtTyBvDA.text: So i had never had Dim Sum before being taken here as a birthday lunch with my buddy. My buddy happens to be a connoisseur of some weird dishes so I was apprehensive half the time he put something new down in front of my and told me to eat it. However only on one occasion was I disappointed (I am not a chicken feet fan). The food here was really tasty and flavorful.   I really liked the shark fin dumplings (named for the shape according to my buddy), the shrimp in noodles, and the sweet tofu at the end.  For a first experience at Dim Sum this was a good one and has me wanting to go back to try some more. The one thing I wished they had was something that made it a little easier for me to figure out what was in each dish, although this time it wouldn't have mattered much.

dizMta23pl1yzYYTHIsGWw.text: Amazing food, amazing experience - will be back! Get the noodles with pork, get the squid & jalapenos, get the tripe, get the squid again. You won't be disappointed.

5_8g7VukacyEzhEKmTN2pw.text: This restaurant is in an industrial neighborhood. My motivation to come here Are the throng of Chinese who frequent this restaurant. The dimsum selection is slightly better than what I've had in the other three dimsum restaurants in Phoenix.

AJ8BLn8BLgjG1f5jvUeYJw.text: They really are improving things big time!!! All meat has been fresh and delicious. The tanks look clean! Love this place!

QmrF8fWqfpvmqOE8vwkJtg.text: I love dimsum, but whenever I go I always go in a large group and let the other people point and order for me. This visit was the same. Went with a party of 5 on a busy Sunday afternoon, and fortunately got seated right away. My friend is well versed and immediately started ordering off the carts as soon as they went by. Unfortunately, I can't recommend any of the names of the dishes because I don't know them! :( Well besides the general dumplings and steamed buns. There was this super delicious eggplant one though!   After eating for a little under an hour, our final damage ended up being about $10 per person. I was completely full and will definitely come back again!  Located in a strip mall with plenty of parking. Come with a big group and try all the dishes.

Rgz8PvFexxk1B_2afGxc3g.text: I love Dim Sum! I have been to this place tons of times for the past 20+ years? It's hard to find a good Dim Sum place around the valley and I just went again today at 11am and it took 20 minutes to get a table.  The wait is because the food is good and mostly affordable as you order and they mark items on the little pink sheet that keeps track of the price of what you've ordered.  Since it's Dim Sum, and I don't have a lot of places to base it on, the place is busy and you need to let the people walking by know what you want which is unlike other places.  I don't know of a better dim sum place in the valley, I'd recommend coming here!

0mDlDeOBYAauDA0uX7ScBQ.text: Decent Chinese food(I recommend the shrimp lettuce wraps), and good service(at least tonight for me). You'd better know how to order.

w2ZrlzOTnWyI7tGHfp7A5Q.text: Great Wall Cuisine is an amazing restaurant that I've been to numerous times and was never disappointed. Despite the fact that the food is a little bit pricey (the seafood) but its varieties of Cantonese and exotic dishes makes it well worth it. Many of the dishes are traditionally Asian dishes but there are some dishes that can appeal to a more general customer. My personal favorite dish is the walnut shrimp because its taste is exquisite and is always well prepared.  There are many great dishes that Great Wall provides but their crown jewel is their dim sum. Their dim sum is arguably the best in Phoenix and its only downside is that it's only sold during the mornings until 3 PM. Even that fact can be made into a positive argument for the restaurant because  it creates a special feeling of excitement for the consumers to anticipate as they rush into the restaurant surrounding by people with the same intention of snagging a good table and order some of the fresh dim sum.  Great Wall is not a perfect restaurants and has some faulty areas and one of the negative area that Great Wall has is in their customer service. Most of their staff are usually casual and relaxed, that could be argued as a good thing, but in a busy restaurant environment it negatively affects them because it makes them look inefficient. However, something as minor as that can easily be improved on and make the restaurant as a whole. Overall, Great Wall Cuisine is a marvelous restaurant filled with amazing dishes and that I would definitely recommend.

canENPvFqHZeITss4VJ1GQ.text: After hearing that this is THE place to go for dim sum in the West Valley, I come here with the girlfriend. Now I know why people say that - because there is literally NO other place for dim sum within a 20 mile radius at least. Service was meh, and the food was very inconsistent. Some of it was warm while others (such as the turnip cake) were cold. Decor was lacking and it was very dark and dingy on the inside. It was the kind of venue where you would have a cheap Chinese or Vietnamese wedding and you can tell right away that it's cheap. I likely won't be coming back as I'd rather drive the extra 20 minutes to get better dim sum in Mesa or Chandler.

K-9th5Mot9odmBu6TmdGjA.text: It's Saturday and we decided to go to Great Wall for dim sum. I had heard about this place from my cousin, but didn't have a chance to try it until today.  We got a late start and by the time we got to Great Wall it was close to 1 pm.    The place is fairly spacious and we were seated right away. We noticed that they had a live fish tank with lobster, dungeness crab, assorted fish and even shrimp.  The bustling dim sum carts came to us pretty quickly.   We tried the following items:  Steamed spareribs- small cubes of spareribs steamed in a black bean sauce. It was actually pretty tasty and not super fatty like some places. Would order this again.  Long noodle (churng fun) with shrimp-  the noodles were too thick for my liking even though the shrimp was nice and crunchy and it had a light soy sauce over it. Probably won't order this again unless the noodles are rolled out thinner.  Baked pork bun- these buns looked great, all nicely golden brown with a light layer of sticky syrup to give it a sheen. The bun itself is soft and tasty, but I had to take literally 4 bites of the bun to get any "char siu" or bbq pork filling. Slightly disappointing.  Cocktail bun- these buns seem to be quite popular, as the lady took one quick round trip around just half the room and they were gone. 3 buns come in one order. These are long shaped buns with some sesame on top. Inside are sweetened coconut filling and the bun is soft. A good combo and better than many other places I've tried.  Chinese tamale (jung) - A lotus leaf surrounds the savory goodness of rice, pork and green beans and chinese sausage (lap churng). They also have the option of peanuts instead of green beans if you want.  Fried taro puff-  Mashed up taro is stuffed with minced pork, green onions with 5 spice powder and fried up with this puffy coating. I thought the taro puff here was a bit harder or denser than some places I've tried.   Steamed shu mai- is perhaps one of the more famous Chinese dim sum items as it is steamed shrimp and pork dumpling. However, the shu mai at Great Wall is mediocre at best.  The shu mai is a bit denser than I am normally accustomed to and the skin falls off easily as you pick it out from the mini steamer.  Pan fried turnip cake- this was surprisingly better than expected. It was pan fried to a nice golden brown on both sides and you could taste the dried shrimp, lap churng and bits of turnip. Definitely recommend trying this.  Congee / Porrdige - we tried the 1000 year old egg with salted pork porridge and it was fine. Lots of chunks of egg and pork mixed in the porridge.  The bill came out to be a little over $27 for 3 people - not bad at all.  I haven't tried their dinner items so this review is just for their dim sum. Over all, one of the better places that I've encountered while visiting the Phoenix area. Would come back for dim sum again and will give this place a try for dinner sometime soon.

yX1Oc8aJLBDFLAENN2LomA.text: First time here and it was super delicious! Got my dim sum fix! It was just my bf and I and we only spent a little over $35. Not to bad for these type of places.

b7W1XAlu-w4GQDzMTxeOCQ.text: Meh, I'll give it three stars.  I do not really recommend this place over C-Fu and Mekong unless distance is an issue.  I went to Great Wall around 1pm on Monday (a holiday, and they were pretty full) for dim sum,  I tried (using.the English/American terms): Rice cake Bbq pork bun Shrimp dumpling Pork dumpling  Coconut custard bun (the best item I ate)  Everything was decent.  Not amazing, not very warm and steamy, but just solid three star food.  The coconut custard bun/bread was actually much better than C-Fu's though, which was a delight!  They were out of many things or only had two of something so you had to choose a third item of another type (which may be one you didn't care for).  I was unable to try the sesame seed balls and custard tarts because of this.  They also did not have a lot of what was on their takeout menu, but to be fair C-Fu only has their full selection on weekends, so maybe Great Wall follows this same practice.  There was nonexistent wait staff (since we only had dim sum and didn't order from the normal menu?), and we had to ask one of the cashiers/hosts for water.  I was tempted to just grab a pitcher myself!  I actually did grab my own to go container (I do this all the time at C-Fu).  Some of the cart attendants/servers were very nice, but a little difficult to understand.  Decently priced, but very sketchy location (their shopping center is pretty empty and anchored by a thrift store).  Lots of people (almost all Asian) were around and the immediate parking area was quite full though.    At least it was almost right down the road from the business Costco, so I was finally able to go there (was tempted to check out Los Altos Ranch Market too, that's for next time though).

x_js2-GeW-SmhKoUdduYdQ.text: I wasn't too thrilled with trying this place as soon as I stepped inside.  The place gives me the skivies.  Food was ok nothing great.

MOzeRdhkw136bq9xY7C93w.text: The food tasted pretty good however, it was cold. When exiting I asked the person who seated us and she said next time tell them and they will heat it up. I really don't want my crispy wontons heated up in the microwave so I'm not sure that this would be a good solution. It did bring me back to my days in New York where there truly is delicious dim sum in Manhattan, in Chinatown. I long for it and keep hoping I will find something that's comprable. Great wall maybe it I will go back to check it again

Jqcjzst0rdzHv2XOewmDVA.text: 1. Get there by 10am on Sundays! 2. Seaweed Salad is awesome! 3. Order the oolong tea with the meal, your tummy will thank you. 4. Shrimp dumplings, roasted pork, congee, bbq sweet buns, the shrimp and leek rolls ...all awesome 5. Feeling adventurous...chicken feet, tripe, warm tofu with sugar syrup..

ThmwrAON9Xf5MFYrTy1PEg.text: Dimsum is top notch, and the lunch cuisine is on the tasty side and very reasonably priced.  However the service is atrocious.  A good portion of the servers are not fluent with english and they tend to focus on the tables that speak Cantonese/Chinese etc rather than dividing their time equally amongst all paying customers.  It took me 25 minutes just to flag down a server to order lunch, and I asked for more ice tea three times and was never served.  Ended up walking over to the server station and pouring my own.  The service alone warrants 1 star but the dimsum quality is so high that I cant help but offer a 3 star rating nonetheless.

1rdHwKo7cxSKppSgbSpNgg.text: I went here for dim sum and it was pretty awesome! A couple months later as I'm getting my home renovated, I recommended this place to my general contractor.  He looked at me with disgust and stated that he did repairs at this restaurant and when he went up to the attic it was INFESTED with Rats!!! The attic isn't part of the health inspection and he said he has seen a few other restaurants with the same issue.  I will not be eating here again.

FrpWcCLzb6vEAXTcRLE7aQ.text: I took my lunch date to this place since she haven't date dim sum in AZ before. This was the closest location in the west side.  When we get there, the parking and restaurant were packed. A good indicator I think.  Got my table relatively quicky.  We ordered many various dishes from sticky rice to shumai. It was pretty good.  My date were looking for some BBQ chicken feet and it was not available. A little bummed but it did not ruin the experience.  The only negative thing I can gripe about were the noodle. It simply sucked. We barely touched it. It was a little wasteful. Something learned....we will not order noodles again...  Overall, I can't wait to bring here again

K1mgUgkW6psJStZtDdrcSQ.text: We went in with a lot of expectations considering the great reviews on yelp - and we were starved - so we would liked the food if it even remotely good!  The place -  the restaurant had a strong smell that was not pleasing to say the least The service - Bad! they were running a vaccumm cleaner while we were having our meal!! Te food: horrible - it had no taste - we ordered a noodle soup and a veg main course... the noodle soup tasted like boiled water with noodles..  I've been to Shanghai and I know this was neither authentic nor good!!

WkY32szSuUCa-_nbLWfTgw.text: Great dim sum place, if you came on weekend or holiday please came early or you will have to wait in line. Love to come here for dinner as well. I always get their salt and pepper pork chop and green bean XO sauce, they are heavenly. Don't expect good service though, couple of the waiter are nice but most of them are kinda rude; but I came for the food not the service. Just wish they are a little closer to home, have to drive around 30 min to get here.

sQzfs5wWRd3HKOqwB4V-FQ.text: Came here about 4 months ago and was very impressed.  Today, not so much.  Shrimp noodles used to have 4 shrimp, now they have 2....  shu mai noodle was very starchy. Left an aftertaste in my mouth.  Disappointed.

Kk1-7Em357tuDzLIIjv1BA.text: FINALLY checked out this place.  Much to our surprise, we didn't wait that long to be seated (we arrived at about 12:00 PM on a Saturday).  Really great and authentic cuisine!~ I would have given 5 stars had the service been faster - we waited 20 minutes or so for the steamed pork rib.  Overall, this is a fantastic place for dim sum~

YF6pDH43Cy88-nxGEvrK6w.text: Was very hard to get service, even though they are coming around with the carts, they just kept on passing us by. The Dim Sum was very greasy and soggy. It was so bad, we did not take home leftovers & just left them on the table.

vTZt9k7Qc7mb8u4qkufAiA.text: I think I have a discerning taste for dimsum being Asian and all so it's hard to find a really good dimsum place in Phoenix.  A friend recommended this place and it's pretty decent.  I can't say it's the best I ever had but I'd say pretty decent for Phoenix standards.  The only place I have to compare this place to though is the Golden Buddah @ the Chinese Cultural Center and I'd say Great Wall is definitely better.    We got there at 10am and were seated immediately.  However, they didn't have all the selections out until close to when we left, around 10:45.  It was disappointing but the foods we did have were good.

B7AY_lgLziQ2lVyIn6c-BQ.text: Almost best Chinese restaurant in Phoenix. Served morning tea during lunch time and my favorite is chives dumpling. Whenever I went there it was sold out... But it deserved waiting 10 min! Soup is only served on weekends.

RA6G4dHxrOrA1mATkMSTgQ.text: Poor quality Dim Sum. You will get slightly better at C-Fu Gormet or Phoenix Palace in Chandler (both at Warner and Dobson). That said, none of these restaurants compares to the quality of many large city Dim Sum restaurants like Yang Sing in San Francisco.   The Great Wall clams would be much better without the horribly bitter sauce dripped over them. And someone needs to teach them how to make sesame balls which should have a sweet yellow bean puree without a bitter after taste. We had several other dishes -- none up to par.  This was our third and last visit.

0BKm_En22lKPs8TQwNbEBg.text: Let me start off by saying that "Oriental" does not pertain to people so, unless you want to get punched in the face, I suggest you refrain from using that word. Secondly, if you plan on visiting an authentic Chinese restaurant, expect them to speak very little English. It's no different than if you were to visit a Mexican restaurant and most everyone can only speak Spanish; it's a given.  With that said, the food here is the best it can get in the Metro Phoenix area for the price. I've been to other dim sum places in Chandler and they never compare to Great Wall. We go here at least once a week to get our shu mai fix and we make sure to bring friends along. Today, there were eight of us and we spent $40 (that's $5 per person for the mathematically challenged).   Make sure to order a few shu mai (shrimp/pork dumpling), har gao (shrimp dumpling) and rice cake before they get snagged by other hungry patrons. They also have the best custard buns around.

XhpqYo1XStTymZHmmAy5_Q.text: Showed up at 9 and place was already pretty busy. I wish I could say that the dim sum was spectacular but sadly, the baking soda used to revive the shrimp in the oversteamed ha gao still lingers on my palate. Great Wall is plagued by the same factory-made dim sum that everyone else in PHX serves. In its favor, everything was hot. Owners speak Cantonese, staff mostly Vietnamese and Cantonese. Strange bring your check to the counter system for total and payment.

D5p_fiVTbQBBUl-muxslMw.text: Nothing special. The Mekong Palace still better but this is my second dim sum. Still looking..

YWgA7wF05qyasPDQH4XyeA.text: Who knew in midst all of the Mexican restaurants, you'd find a diamond in the rough for Chinese food.  Arizona doesn't have many Chinese restaurants to begin with, however this place rivals the places in CA.  It's not the place for ambience or mood, but the food is the most important for the Chinese and this place is great for dinner or dim sum.     Notes for ordering dishes: I loved the garlic pea sprouts/shoots.  Not all Chinese restaurants this vegetable, but this place makes have it fresh and crunchy and just enough garlic flavor to give it that extra pizzazz.  What I noticed is that this place serves unique fried noodles.  Perfect for vegetarians, this place actually cooked crispy fried noodles unlike most other Chinese restaurant that just comes out with soggy noodles.  Another dish I recommend is their spiced salt tofu. (jiao yan tofu).  Well anything with the spiced salt (jiao yan).  They deep fry the small pieces of tofu or whatever other "jiao yan" producing a crunchy crust and mix it with a salty seasoning and jalapenos.  Great for an appetizer!  My family and I also had their steamed whole fish.  Light flavor and prepared beautifully with the entire moist fish out on the table.  Just the sauce and rice alone tastes just as good.  Be sure to try their walnut shrimp.  Be sure you have a big mouth to fit one of these jumbo shrimp in one bite.  The sauce covering the shrimp has just the right amount of tanginess and sweetness that I'm looking for without being too thick.  And the sweet crunchy walnut complements the dish as well. Ordering the right dishes can make or break your experiences.  For this restaurant, be sure to pick seafood, their specialty.  They have live fish, crabs, etc in clear tanks so you can pick out your dinner victim.  And of course pick fried anything, especially with their spiced salt (jiao yan).  Notes for dim sum: Great Wall actually has a unique set of dim sum choices that you can't find anywhere in the valley (at least the Chinese dim sum places I've been to).  Although it's a bit more expensive than the other places in the valley I've been to, but it does taste better overall.  Even the basic dim sum dishes like shrimp dumplings, shumai, and chicken feet simply taste better and I would even say taste better than some CA restaurant.  Who'd thought?  Because the dishes are small, you can try many of them and of course I would go for the fried stuff.  :-) However be careful.  Keep your eye out for the moving carts, if what you want has been sitting there for a while, wait for a new batch.  Cold Chinese food just doesn't taste as well.  Only the tin dishes that are covered are fine, because their still hot after the servers make their rounds.  Go on the weekend for a wider selection and be prepared to have a wait.  But the wait isn't that bad compared to some places I've been to in CA.  Great to go with a medium sized party so you can taste more variety, but not have to wait a long time for a table.  Overall, this is a great place to get great Chinese food if you live in the valley and don't want to make a 6hr journey to LA just for good Chinese food (which I have done before).

5SfU4cVCKxNabhNL3Zx6Nw.text: Great Food! Terrible custom service.. i think it might be because its a family owned. they can be rude sometimes... or maybe they just do not speak that much english. But A+ for the cook!

wxwb-RLhQbHpOeSCkBUXWQ.text: The sweet and sour chicken was very good and flavorful, but if you're wanting good Chinese food, keep driving. There's definitely better Chinese restaurants out there. The service was terrible here at Great Wall and the hostess/waiters/waitresses were rude. They had no problems taking my empty plate, but couldn't refill my glass with water. Sat through my whole meal without a refill. Phoenix is hot too!

SYpQnh0P8DgorJqHzbv9eA.text: Dim Sum review only***  Food is a 4-star rating, but the location and the decor of the restaurant isn't as pleasant. Located in the corner of the a big strip mall, you can't believe how big the restaurant is from the outside, which has no windows, with a small glass door... There is always a line for dim sum during the peak hour, but definitely worth to wait, if you have an asian friend who knows what to order can tag along, that is even better!  Very good dim sum and cheap price, just don't expect a fancy place. Have fun~

GtdSKYhaHTxFuYlkbquuLw.text: The service needs improvement. While it may get busy at lunch time hey can do better. We had to flag down a server a couple times. The food portions are good but my rice tastes burnt. Also,the bathrooms are super clean. I may go back and try the dim some sometime
